summary_llm:
The play opens on Christmas Eve in the Helmer household. Nora Helmer, in high spirits, returns from shopping, having bought many Christmas presents. Her husband, Torvald Helmer, playfully scolds her for being a "spendthrift" and using pet names like "little lark" and "little squirrel." He reminds her of their past financial struggles and his strict aversion to debt, emphasizing that a home based on borrowing lacks "freedom or beauty." He has recently been appointed manager of the Bank, a position he will take up after the New Year, promising a large salary and an end to their need to economize. Nora tries to wheedle money from him for herself, but he insists she cannot save. He also teases her about secretly eating macaroons, which he has forbidden due to concern for her teeth.

Doctor Rank, a close family friend, arrives, followed by Mrs. Linde, an old school friend of Nora's. Nora is delighted to see Christine Linde, who has changed greatly, appearing paler and thinner. Christine reveals she is a widow, her husband having left her nothing, and she has no children. She has spent the last three years working tirelessly to support her bedridden mother and two younger brothers, but now they are gone or self-sufficient, leaving her life "unspeakably empty." She has come to town seeking regular office work. Nora, overjoyed by Torvald's new position, promises to use her influence to help Christine get a job at the Bank.

Nora then confides a great secret to Christine: she, not her father, procured the two hundred and fifty pounds needed for Torvald's life-saving trip to Italy years ago when he was gravely ill. She explains that Torvald's "manly independence" would have been humiliated if he knew he owed her, so she pretended the money came from her dying father. To secure the loan, she forged her father's signature on a bond, as he was too ill to sign it himself and she couldn't tell him of Torvald's critical condition. She has been secretly paying off the debt through small jobs like needlework and copying, and by saving half of her housekeeping money. She is proud of her sacrifice and the "tremendous pleasure" of earning money, feeling "like being a man."

Just as Nora expresses relief at being "free from care" now that Torvald's new salary will allow her to pay off the last of the debt, a lawyer named Krogstad arrives, seeking to speak with Torvald about "Bank business." Christine recognizes Krogstad, revealing they knew each other "many years ago" and he was a solicitor's clerk in her town. Doctor Rank, emerging from Torvald's study, describes Krogstad as a "morally diseased" man who committed an "indiscretion" in the past, which cost him his reputation. Nora, realizing Krogstad has a subordinate position at the Bank, becomes uneasy.

Krogstad confronts Nora, revealing he has been dismissed from his post by Torvald. He asks Nora to use her influence to ensure he keeps his job, hinting at her secret. Nora initially tries to dismiss him, but Krogstad reminds her of the bond and her forgery. He points out that her father's signature on the bond is dated three days after his death, proving the forgery. He threatens to expose her if he loses his position, stating that his "one false step" was "nothing more or nothing worse than what you have done." Nora defiantly claims she acted for love, but Krogstad insists the law cares nothing for motives. He warns her that if he loses his position a second time, she will "lose yours with me." After Krogstad leaves, Nora is terrified, especially by Torvald's earlier pronouncements that deceitful parents poison their children's lives.

In Act II, Nora is consumed by anxiety, fearing Krogstad's exposure. She asks the Nurse if children forget their mother if she goes away, and recalls the Nurse's own story of leaving her child for work. Mrs. Linde returns to help Nora mend her Tarantella costume for the upcoming fancy-dress ball. Nora reveals Doctor Rank is dying from a hereditary spinal disease, a consequence of his father's excesses. Mrs. Linde mistakenly suspects Rank lent Nora the money, but Nora denies it, admitting she needs to "make an end of it with the other one."

Nora desperately tries to persuade Torvald to keep Krogstad, arguing that Krogstad could harm his reputation by writing scurrilous articles. Torvald refuses, citing Krogstad's past forgery and, more importantly, his overly familiar manner with him at the bank. He sees Krogstad as a moral danger and cannot tolerate working with someone who addresses him as an equal. Despite Nora's pleas, Torvald sends the letter of dismissal to Krogstad via the maid. He then assures a terrified Nora that he will protect her from any danger, taking "everything upon myself."

Doctor Rank then arrives, revealing that his illness has worsened significantly and he will soon die. He confesses his love for Nora, which she gently rebuffs, realizing she can no longer ask him for financial help. Krogstad, having received his dismissal, returns and drops a letter into the Helmers' locked letterbox, informing Nora that it contains a full account of her forgery. He intends to use this leverage to force Torvald to reinstate him in a higher position at the bank. Nora is distraught.

She confides in Mrs. Linde, admitting the forgery and Krogstad's letter. Nora expresses a desperate hope for a "wonderful thing" to happen, implying Torvald might take the blame. Mrs. Linde, upon learning the full story, decides to intervene. She reveals her past relationship with Krogstad and goes to speak with him, hoping to persuade him to retrieve the letter. Nora, meanwhile, distracts Torvald by insisting he help her practice the Tarantella dance, preventing him from checking the letterbox until after the ball.

In Act III, Mrs. Linde waits for Krogstad in the Helmers' living room after the ball. She reveals to Krogstad that she left him years ago not out of heartlessness, but to support her sick mother and brothers, as his prospects were then hopeless. She proposes they reunite, offering him a home and someone to work for, as she feels her own life is empty. Krogstad is deeply moved and overjoyed, accepting her offer. He then expresses a desire to retrieve his letter from Helmer's letterbox. However, Mrs. Linde stops him, insisting that the truth about Nora's actions must come out, as it is necessary for Nora and Torvald to have a "complete understanding" free from "concealment and falsehood." Krogstad agrees to let the letter remain.

Torvald and Nora return from the ball. Torvald is in a jovial, possessive mood, admiring Nora's dancing and beauty. Mrs. Linde bids them goodnight. After she leaves, Torvald checks the letterbox, finding two cards from Doctor Rank with black crosses, signifying Rank's imminent death. Torvald expresses sadness but also a sense of newfound intimacy with Nora, saying they are "thrown quite upon each other now." He wishes for a "great danger" to threaten Nora so he could prove his love by sacrificing "his life's blood."

Nora insists he read his letters. Torvald reads Krogstad's letter, which reveals Nora's forgery. He is horrified, calling Nora a "hypocrite, a liar—worse, worse—a criminal!" He blames her father's "want of principle" and fears his own reputation and future are ruined, as Krogstad now has power over him. He declares their marriage is over, but for the sake of appearances, Nora must remain in the house, though he will not allow her to raise the children, as he cannot trust her.

Just then, the maid brings another letter for Nora. Torvald seizes it, reads it, and shouts with joy. Krogstad has returned the bond, regretting his actions due to a "happy change in his life" (his reconciliation with Mrs. Linde). Torvald is "saved!" He tears up the bond and both letters, burning them in the stove, declaring that "it doesn't exist any longer." He then "forgives" Nora, explaining that her actions, though misguided, were done out of love. He views her as a "frightened little singing-bird" and a "helpless darling," promising to protect her and guide her, seeing her "womanly helplessness" as doubly attractive. He believes their life will return to normal, and she will become both "wife and child to him."

Nora, however, has changed into her everyday dress and asks Torvald to sit down for a serious conversation. She tells him that in eight years of marriage, they have never had a serious discussion. She realizes she has been treated like a "doll-child" by her father and a "doll-wife" by Torvald, existing only to perform tricks and having no life of her own. She declares she has never been truly happy, only "merry." She tells him he is not the man to educate her, and she is not fit to raise their children. She must educate herself and understand the world, and for that reason, she is leaving him and their children.

Torvald is shocked and forbids her, citing her "most sacred duties" as a wife and mother. Nora counters that she has "other duties just as sacred"—duties to herself. She no longer believes she is primarily a wife and mother, but a "reasonable human being" who must think for herself. She questions the law that condemns her actions, finding it "foolish." She tells him she no longer loves him.

Nora explains that the "wonderful thing" she had hoped for was that when Krogstad's letter was revealed, Torvald would step forward and take all the blame upon himself. His reaction tonight, however, showed that he was only concerned with his own reputation, not with her. She concludes that she has been living with a "strange man" for eight years. She removes her wedding ring and gives it back to him, asking for her own, declaring they are free from all obligations to each other. She states she will not see the children, believing they are better off without her. She refuses his offers to write or help her.

Nora states that for them to ever be together again, the "most wonderful thing of all" would have to happen: both of them would have to be so changed that their life together would be a "real wedlock." She says goodbye and leaves the house, and the sound of a door shutting is heard from below. Torvald, left alone, sinks into a chair, whispering "Nora! Nora!" before a "hope flashes across his mind" about "The most wonderful thing of all—?" as the door shuts.

summary_llm:
Alice's Adventures in Wonderland begins with Alice sitting by a riverbank with her sister, feeling bored and sleepy. Her attention is suddenly caught by a White Rabbit with pink eyes, who runs by muttering, "Oh dear! Oh dear! I shall be late!" To Alice's astonishment, the Rabbit takes a watch out of its waistcoat-pocket, looks at it, and hurries on. Burning with curiosity, Alice follows the Rabbit down a large rabbit-hole.

The rabbit-hole plunges steeply downwards, becoming a very deep well. As Alice falls, she observes cupboards, bookshelves, maps, and pictures lining the sides. She takes an empty jar of "ORANGE MARMALADE" from a shelf and places it in another cupboard to avoid dropping it on anyone below. She speculates about her immense fall, calculating distances and wondering if she will emerge in New Zealand or Australia. She also thinks of her cat, Dinah, and wonders if cats eat bats. Eventually, she lands softly on a heap of sticks and dry leaves, unhurt.

She quickly sees the White Rabbit again, still hurrying and exclaiming about being late. Alice follows it into a long, low hall lined with many locked doors. On a small glass table, she finds a tiny golden key, but it is too small for any of the main doors. She then discovers a low curtain she hadn't noticed before, behind which is a small door about fifteen inches high. The golden key fits this lock. Opening the door, Alice sees a beautiful garden but is too large to fit through the small passage.

Returning to the table, she finds a bottle labeled "DRINK ME." After prudently checking it is not marked "poison," she drinks the liquid, which has a mixed flavor of various foods. She immediately begins to shrink, becoming only ten inches high. Delighted, she realizes she is now the right size for the small door, but then remembers she left the golden key on the glass table, which she can no longer reach. She tries to climb a table leg but it's too slippery. Frustrated, she cries.

Her attention then falls on a small cake under the table, marked "EAT ME." She decides to eat it, hoping it will either make her grow larger to reach the key or smaller to creep under the door. She eats a bit, but her size remains unchanged. She then finishes the entire cake.

Immediately, Alice begins to grow enormously, becoming over nine feet tall, her head striking the roof of the hall. She quickly grabs the golden key and hurries to the garden door, but she is now too large to even look through it with one eye. She sits down and begins to cry, shedding so many tears that a large pool forms around her, four inches deep and covering half the hall.

She hears the White Rabbit returning, splendidly dressed with white kid gloves and a large fan, muttering about the Duchess. Alice, desperate, attempts to speak to it, but the Rabbit is startled, drops its gloves and fan, and scurries away. Alice picks up the fan and gloves and begins fanning herself, which she soon realizes is causing her to shrink rapidly. She hastily drops the fan, stopping her shrinkage just in time, finding herself about two feet high.

However, the little door is now shut again, and the key is still on the table, out of reach. As she laments her predicament, her foot slips, and she falls into the pool of tears she had created. She swims about, wishing she hadn't cried so much, and encounters a Mouse who has also fallen in. Alice attempts to speak to the Mouse, first in a formal address, then in French, which frightens the Mouse as she mentions "chatte" (cat). Alice apologizes but continues to talk about her own cat, Dinah, and her prowess at catching mice, further offending the Mouse.

The Mouse, trembling, agrees to tell Alice why it hates cats and dogs if they can reach the shore. The pool becomes crowded with other creatures who have fallen in: a Duck, a Dodo, a Lory, and an Eaglet. Alice leads the group to the bank.

On the bank, the wet and uncomfortable party discusses how to get dry. The Mouse, taking charge, proposes a "Caucus-race." The Dodo marks out a circular course, and everyone runs when they please and stops when they please. After about half an hour, they are dry, and the Dodo declares that "Everybody has won, and all must have prizes." Alice is designated to give the prizes, distributing comfits from her pocket to everyone. For Alice's own prize, she offers a thimble, which the Dodo solemnly presents back to her.

The Mouse then begins to tell its "history" (which Alice repeatedly mishears as "tail" and interrupts with comments about its actual tail). The Mouse recites a poem about a Fury and a mouse going to law, but Alice's interruptions about "knots" (mishearing "not") offend the Mouse, and it walks away. Alice calls it back, promising not to mention cats or dogs. The Mouse returns, but Alice soon forgets her promise and describes her cat Dinah as an excellent mouse-catcher and bird-eater. This causes all the birds and animals to flee in terror, leaving Alice alone and sad.

Soon, the White Rabbit reappears, frantically searching for its fan and gloves and muttering about the Duchess and execution. It mistakes Alice for its housemaid, Mary Ann, and orders her to fetch a new pair of gloves and a fan from its house. Alice, intimidated, obeys and finds the Rabbit's house. Inside, she finds a fan and gloves, and also a bottle. Despite no label, she drinks from it, hoping to grow large again. She grows so rapidly that her head hits the ceiling, and she becomes stuck, with one arm out a window and one foot up the chimney.

The Rabbit returns, calling for Mary Ann. Unable to open the door due to Alice's elbow, it decides to enter through the window. Alice, hearing it approach, spreads her hand out, causing a shriek, a fall, and broken glass. The Rabbit then calls for "Pat" (a Lizard named Bill), ordering him to remove Alice's arm from the window. Alice repeats her action, causing more shrieks and broken glass. Soon, a group of creatures arrives with ladders, planning to send Bill the Lizard down the chimney. Alice kicks her foot down the chimney, sending Bill flying out. The Rabbit then suggests burning the house down, but Alice threatens to set her cat Dinah on them, causing a sudden silence. Pebbles are then thrown through the window, which turn into little cakes on the floor. Alice eats one, shrinks, and runs out of the house into a wood.

In the wood, Alice encounters an enormous puppy. She distracts it with a stick and escapes when it tires. She realizes she needs to find a way to return to her normal size. She then finds a large mushroom, on top of which sits a large blue Caterpillar smoking a hookah.

The Caterpillar asks Alice, "Who are _you?_" Alice explains her confusion over her identity due to her frequent size changes. The Caterpillar is dismissive. Alice tries to recite a poem, "How doth the little busy bee," but it comes out wrong. The Caterpillar then makes her recite "'_You are old, Father William_,'" which also comes out entirely different. The Caterpillar asks what size she wants to be. Alice expresses a desire to be a "little larger" than three inches, which offends the three-inch-tall Caterpillar. The Caterpillar eventually crawls away, but not before telling Alice that one side of the mushroom will make her grow taller and the other side will make her grow shorter.

Alice breaks off a piece from each side of the mushroom. She nibbles the right-hand bit and shrinks rapidly, her chin hitting her foot. She then eats some of the left-hand bit, and her neck grows immensely, like a serpent's, rising above the treetops. A large Pigeon flies at her, screaming "Serpent!" and accusing her of trying to steal its eggs. Alice protests that she is a little girl, but the Pigeon is unconvinced, believing all egg-eaters are a kind of serpent. Alice, still holding the mushroom pieces, carefully nibbles them until she returns to her usual height. She then sees a small house and shrinks herself to nine inches before approaching it.

At the house, Alice observes a Fish-Footman and a Frog-Footman exchanging an invitation from the Queen for the Duchess to play croquet. Alice tries to enter, but the Frog-Footman gives nonsensical reasons why knocking is useless. Frustrated, Alice opens the door and enters a smoky kitchen. Inside, the Duchess is nursing a constantly sneezing and howling baby, while a Cook throws kitchen utensils at them. A grinning Cheshire Cat sits by the fire. Alice asks the Duchess why her cat grins, and the Duchess explains it's a Cheshire cat. Alice attempts to discuss the Earth's rotation, but the Duchess interrupts with "chop off her head!" The Duchess sings a violent lullaby to the baby, then flings it at Alice, telling her to nurse it, and leaves to play croquet.

Alice struggles to hold the oddly shaped baby, which grunts and has a pig-like snout. She realizes the baby is transforming into a pig. She sets it down, and it trots away into the wood. She then sees the Cheshire Cat again, sitting on a tree branch. Alice asks the Cat which way to go. The Cat replies it depends on where she wants to get to, and that everyone here is mad, including Alice, the Hatter, and the March Hare. The Cat vanishes and reappears several times, eventually disappearing completely, leaving only its grin behind for a while. Alice then walks towards the March Hare's house, shrinking herself to two feet high before approaching.

At the March Hare's house, Alice finds the March Hare and the Hatter having an eternal tea-party, using a sleeping Dormouse as a cushion. They claim there's "No room!" but Alice sits down. They offer her wine, but there is none. The Hatter asks the riddle, "Why is a raven like a writing-desk?" but has no answer. The Hatter explains that he quarreled with "Time" after singing at the Queen of Hearts' concert, and now it's "always six o'clock" (tea-time) for them, forcing them to constantly move around the table as tea-things get used up. The Dormouse, after being pinched awake, tells a nonsensical story about three sisters living in a "treacle-well" and drawing "treacle" and things beginning with "M." Alice's questions lead to more absurd arguments. Frustrated by their rudeness and illogic, Alice leaves the tea-party in disgust, seeing them trying to put the Dormouse into the teapot.

She finds a door in a tree that leads back to the long hall. This time, she remembers the golden key and the mushroom. She shrinks herself to about a foot high and finally enters the beautiful garden.

In the garden, Alice observes three gardeners (playing cards) painting white roses red, fearing the Queen of Hearts, who wants only red roses, will behead them if she finds out about their mistake. The Queen's procession arrives: soldiers, courtiers, royal children, guests (including the White Rabbit), the Knave of Hearts, and finally, the King and Queen of Hearts. Alice refuses to lie down like the gardeners. The Queen, upon seeing Alice, demands to know who she is and who the gardeners are. Alice, surprisingly bold, says it's "no business of mine." The furious Queen screams "Off with her head!" but Alice dismisses it as "Nonsense!" The King intervenes, and the Queen orders the gardeners' heads off. Alice quickly hides the gardeners in a flower-pot, saving them.

The Queen then asks Alice if she can play croquet. Alice agrees. The game is chaotic: the croquet-ground is uneven, the balls are live hedgehogs, the mallets are live flamingoes, and the arches are doubled-up soldiers who constantly move. The Queen frequently shouts "Off with his head!" or "Off with her head!" Alice feels uneasy and looks for an escape. She sees the Cheshire Cat's grin appear in the air, followed by its head. Alice complains to the Cat about the unfair game. The King, curious, asks Alice about the Cat. The Queen orders the Cat's head to be removed, and the King goes to fetch the executioner.

Alice returns to the game, which is in complete disarray. She finds the executioner, King, and Queen arguing about how to behead a head without a body, as the Cat's body has not appeared. Alice suggests asking the Duchess, who is in prison. The Queen orders the Duchess to be brought. As the executioner leaves, the Cat's head fades away completely.

The Duchess returns, linking arms with Alice and speaking affectionately, constantly finding morals in everything she says. The Queen suddenly reappears and warns the Duchess, "either you or your head must be off." The Duchess vanishes instantly. The Queen then asks Alice if she has seen the Mock Turtle. Alice hasn't, so the Queen takes her to find it. Along the way, Alice hears the King pardon all the imprisoned players.

They find a Gryphon asleep, and the Queen orders it to take Alice to the Mock Turtle to hear its history, then leaves to oversee executions. The Gryphon chuckles, revealing that the Queen never actually executes anyone. They find the Mock Turtle, who is sitting sadly and sighing. The Mock Turtle, with tears, agrees to tell its history. It begins by saying it "was a real Turtle" and describes its schooling in the sea, taught by a "Tortoise" (because he "taught us"). Their subjects included "Reeling and Writhing," "Ambition, Distraction, Uglification, and Derision" in Arithmetic, and "Mystery, ancient and modern, with Seaography," and "Drawling, Stretching, and Fainting in Coils." The Gryphon adds that its Classics master taught "Laughing and Grief." They explain that lessons "lessen" each day.

The Gryphon then suggests the Mock Turtle tell Alice about games. The Mock Turtle describes the "Lobster Quadrille," a dance involving lobsters as partners, advancing, changing partners, throwing lobsters out to sea, and swimming after them. The Mock Turtle and Gryphon demonstrate parts of the dance and the Mock Turtle sings a song about a whiting and a snail. They explain that whitings have their tails in their mouths because they were thrown out to sea. The Gryphon adds that whitings "do the boots and shoes" and are made of "Soles and eels."

Alice then begins to tell her own adventures, starting from seeing the White Rabbit, her size changes, and her failed recitations. The Mock Turtle and Gryphon find her story "very curious." The Gryphon orders Alice to recite "'_Tis the voice of the sluggard_,'" but Alice recites a nonsensical version about a lobster. She then recites another verse about an Owl and a Panther sharing a pie. The Mock Turtle and Gryphon find her recitations confusing and demand explanations. The Gryphon suggests the Mock Turtle sing a song. The Mock Turtle, sobbing, sings "Turtle Soup." As it begins to repeat the chorus, a cry of "The trial’s beginning!" is heard in the distance. The Gryphon takes Alice by the hand and hurries off to the trial.

Alice and the Gryphon arrive at the court where the King and Queen of Hearts are on their throne. The Knave of Hearts is in chains, accused of stealing the Queen's tarts. The White Rabbit, acting as Herald, reads the accusation. The King, as judge, orders the jury to consider their verdict, but the Rabbit insists there is more evidence.

The first witness is the Hatter, who arrives with a teacup and bread-and-butter, having been interrupted during tea. His testimony is rambling and confused, involving conflicting dates for when he started tea and the "twinkling of the tea." Alice, meanwhile, begins to grow larger again, causing the Dormouse, sitting next to her, to complain. The King threatens the Hatter with execution if he doesn't give clearer evidence. The Hatter is dismissed, and the Queen orders his head off, but he escapes.

The next witness is the Duchess's Cook, who refuses to give evidence. The King cross-examines her, asking what tarts are made of. She replies "Pepper, mostly," while the Dormouse, from behind, interjects "Treacle." The Queen, enraged, orders the Dormouse to be beheaded and suppressed. During the ensuing confusion, the Cook disappears.

The King, relieved, calls the next witness. To Alice's surprise, the White Rabbit reads out her name. Alice, forgetting her immense size, jumps up, knocking over the jury-box and scattering the jurymen. She hastily picks them up. The King asks Alice what she knows about the business. Alice replies, "Nothing whatever." The King declares this "very important," but the White Rabbit corrects him to "unimportant," and the King agrees.

The King then reads "Rule Forty-two: _All persons more than a mile high to leave the court_." Everyone looks at Alice, who is now very large. Alice denies being a mile high, but the King and Queen insist she is, nearly two miles high. Alice refuses to leave, arguing it's an invented rule. The King, flustered, tries to get the jury to consider their verdict.

The White Rabbit interrupts, having found a paper, which he claims is a letter or verses written by the prisoner. The paper is not addressed and has no signature. The King concludes the Knave must have meant mischief. The Queen declares this proves his guilt, but Alice vehemently disagrees, stating there's no meaning in the verses. The King orders the verses to be read. The White Rabbit reads a nonsensical poem about "them," "her," "him," and "you," and tarts.

The King attempts to interpret the verses, connecting lines to the Knave and the tarts, and making a pun on "fit" and the Queen's "fits." The Queen, impatient, demands "Sentence first—verdict afterwards!" Alice loudly protests, calling it "Stuff and nonsense!" The Queen, turning purple with rage, screams "Off with her head!"

Alice, now at her full size, defiantly retorts, "Who cares for you? You’re nothing but a pack of cards!" At this, the entire pack of cards rises into the air and flies down upon her. Alice screams and tries to beat them off, and then finds herself lying on the riverbank, with her head in her sister's lap. Her sister gently brushes dead leaves from her face and tells her to wake up from her long sleep.

Alice tells her sister about her "curious dream." Her sister, after listening, kisses her and sends her off for tea. Alice runs off, marveling at her wonderful dream. Her sister remains by the river, leaning her head on her hand, and begins to dream of Alice's adventures, picturing the strange creatures and events of Wonderland, and how Alice, as a grown woman, would keep her childhood heart and tell these tales to other children.

summary_llm:
The provided text, "Anna Karenina," details the intertwined lives of several aristocratic Russian families, focusing on marital discord, societal expectations, and personal quests for happiness and meaning.

**PART ONE**

The story begins in the Oblonsky household, where Prince Stepan Arkadyevitch Oblonsky (Stiva) has been discovered by his wife, Darya Alexandrovna (Dolly), having an affair with their French governess. Dolly declares she cannot live with him, plunging the household into three days of turmoil. Stiva, while regretting being caught, does not repent the affair. He vaguely hoped Dolly would be more understanding due to her age and his perception of her as a "worn-out woman." His valet, Matvey, informs him that his sister, Anna Arkadyevna, is arriving from Petersburg, hinting she might help reconcile the couple. Dolly, through Matvey, states she is leaving. Matrona Philimonovna, the nurse, urges Stiva to beg forgiveness for the children's sake.

Stiva, physically at ease despite his unhappiness, attends to some office work and reads a liberal newspaper. He then interacts with his children, Tanya and Grisha, noting Tanya's discomfort when he feigns ignorance of the quarrel. After dealing with a petitioner, Stiva decides he must speak to Dolly, despite believing it would be false. He enters her room, where she is packing to leave. Dolly, torn between anger and love, and the practical difficulties of leaving with five children, is hostile. Stiva, overcome with tears, begs for forgiveness, but Dolly calls him "loathsome" and a "vicious father." A child's cry softens her, and she rushes out, threatening to expose him. Stiva is mortified by her "vulgar" outburst.

Later, Konstantin Dmitrievitch Levin, an old friend of Stiva's from his youth, arrives at Stiva's office. Levin, a country gentleman, has resigned from the district council, which he views as corrupt. He has come to Moscow to propose to Kitty Shtcherbatskaya, Dolly's younger sister, with whom he is deeply in love. He idealizes Kitty, seeing himself as unworthy due to his unconventional life. Stiva, aware of Levin's feelings, teases him but encourages him to pursue Kitty. Levin, filled with hope and despair, goes to the Zoological Gardens where Kitty is skating. He is captivated by her beauty and grace. They skate together, and Levin, in a moment of emotion, tells her his stay depends on her. Kitty, remembering Vronsky, skates away.

At the ball that evening, Kitty is radiant but anxious, sensing it will be a turning point. She fondly recalls Levin but is drawn to Vronsky, who is present. She notices Anna Karenina's captivating presence and Vronsky's humble devotion to her. Kitty realizes Vronsky has chosen Anna. When Vronsky asks Anna to dance the mazurka, Anna, with a subtle glance at Kitty, asks if he won't dance with Princess Shtcherbatskaya. Kitty is crushed, realizing she has refused Levin for a man who has now abandoned her. Anna leaves the ball early, telling Vronsky she must rest before her journey, her eyes setting him "on fire."

Levin, leaving the ball, feels "hateful" and "a nobody" after Kitty's rejection. He decides to visit his brother Nikolay, a sickly, dissolute man. He finds Nikolay in a dirty hotel room with his mistress, Marya Nikolaevna, and a friend, Kritsky. Nikolay, irritable and cynical, rails against society but insists on respect for Marya Nikolaevna. Levin is disturbed by Nikolay's condition and his views. Marya Nikolaevna reveals Nikolay drinks heavily. Levin, promising to help, leaves.

Vronsky, on the train to Petersburg to meet his mother, encounters Stiva. Stiva reveals Levin proposed to Kitty and was rejected. Vronsky feels triumphant. Anna arrives, and Vronsky is immediately struck by her beauty and "suppressed eagerness." A railway guard is crushed by a train, an event Anna sees as an "omen of evil." Vronsky gives money to the widow. At home, Anna confronts Dolly about Stiva's affair, expressing genuine sympathy. Dolly, initially cold, softens and recounts her pain. Anna tries to console her, explaining men's infidelity. Anna, after reflection, says she could forgive such a betrayal. Dolly feels reconciled.

Anna spends the day at the Oblonskys', facilitating Stiva and Dolly's reconciliation. Kitty is captivated by Anna. Anna, on her way to get an album, sees Vronsky in the hall. A mix of pleasure and dread stirs in her. Vronsky, seeing her, is embarrassed and refuses Stiva's invitation to come up. Anna finds his visit "strange and not right."

At the race-course, Anna is tormented by her husband's presence and his "loathsome, never-ceasing voice." When Vronsky falls during the steeplechase, Anna cries out and loses her composure. Alexey Alexandrovitch offers his arm, but she ignores him, fixated on Vronsky. An officer confirms Vronsky is unhurt but his horse is injured. Anna hides her face, weeping. Alexey Alexandrovitch, shielding her, again offers his arm. Betsy intervenes, saying she will take Anna home. In the carriage, Alexey Alexandrovitch confronts Anna about her "unbecoming" behavior. Anna, with defiant determination, confesses: "I love him, I am his mistress; I can’t bear you; I’m afraid of you, and I hate you." She breaks into sobs. Alexey Alexandrovitch, his face rigid, tells her he expects her to maintain "external forms of propriety" until he takes measures to secure his honor. He leaves her. Anna receives a note from Betsy confirming Vronsky is in despair. Anna is glad she told her husband everything.

**PART TWO**

Kitty, recovering from her illness at a German watering-place, is bored with society but fascinated by Varenka, a selfless Russian girl who cares for the sick. Kitty longs to be like Varenka. Nikolay Levin and Marya Nikolaevna also arrive, making an unpleasant impression on Kitty. Nikolay has a public outburst at a doctor, and Varenka intervenes. Kitty is impressed by Varenka's calm. The princess, Kitty's mother, learns Varenka's history (adopted by Madame Stahl) and approves of their friendship. Kitty and Varenka become close. Varenka reveals a past love affair where the man's mother opposed their union. Kitty, confessing her own shame over Vronsky, calls her past efforts a "sham." Varenka reassures her. Kitty's idealized image of Madame Stahl shatters, and she longs to return to Russia.

Alexey Alexandrovitch, after Anna's confession, feels betrayed and humiliated. He immerses himself in official work to suppress his pain, becoming cold and sarcastic towards Seryozha. Countess Lidia Ivanovna offers him spiritual consolation, urging him to find support in God. Alexey Alexandrovitch accepts her help, and she manages his household and tells Seryozha his mother is dead. Alexey Alexandrovitch convinces himself he is experiencing salvation.

Vronsky, after Anna's pregnancy, realizes their situation is untenable. He suggests Anna leave her husband and they unite their lives. Anna, however, refuses to abandon Seryozha, fearing disgrace. She insists he never speak of it again. Vronsky, angered by her refusal to face reality, feels his love for her cooling. He is also torn by his ambition, rekindled by his friend Serpuhovskoy's success. He decides to remain in the army and not marry.

Anna, distraught by her inability to see Seryozha, writes to Countess Lidia Ivanovna, who sends a cruel refusal. Anna resolves to see her son on his birthday, even if it means deceiving the servants. She goes to her former home, bribes a footman, and finds Seryozha. He recognizes her and embraces her, crying with joy. Anna is overwhelmed. The servants, trying to prevent Alexey Alexandrovitch from meeting Anna, intervene. Anna, unable to say goodbye, whispers a term of endearment to Seryozha and tells him to love his father. Alexey Alexandrovitch enters, meeting Anna at the door. She glances at him with repulsion and hatred and rushes out.

**PART THREE**

Sergey Ivanovitch visits Konstantin Levin in the country. Konstantin finds Sergey's intellectual theories about country life and peasants irritating, preferring his own practical, hands-on approach. They argue about district affairs and the importance of education for peasants. Konstantin, after an argument with Sergey, decides to go mowing with the peasants, finding joy and peace in the physical labor. He reflects on his newfound faith, realizing that he knows what is right and wrong not through reason, but through his heart. He sees Kitty in a passing carriage and realizes he still loves her.

Levin and Kitty, now engaged, communicate using chalk. Kitty confesses she always loved him but was "carried away" by Vronsky. Levin assures her he has "nothing to forget and to forgive." They are completely reconciled. The family discusses wedding plans. Levin, an unbeliever, finds the required confession painful but endures it.

Vronsky and Anna, after three months of travel in Italy, are bored. Vronsky takes up painting, and Mihailov paints Anna's portrait. Anna is secretly jealous of the nurse Vronsky uses as a model. They decide to return to Russia.

**PART FOUR**

The Karenins live as strangers. Alexey Alexandrovitch, after his political defeat and Anna's confession, is distraught. He seeks a divorce, but his religious scruples and concern for Seryozha complicate matters. He consults a lawyer, who suggests "adultery by mutual consent," which Alexey Alexandrovitch rejects. He decides to keep Anna with him, concealing the affair and punishing her.

Anna, after her confession, is terrified of disgrace and losing Seryozha. She decides to take Seryozha and leave. She writes to Alexey Alexandrovitch, asking him to let her have their son. He replies, insisting on maintaining appearances and warning her of consequences. Anna is horrified by his "generosity." She then meets Vronsky, reveals her pregnancy, and he suggests she leave her husband. Anna refuses to abandon Seryozha.

Alexey Alexandrovitch, influenced by Countess Lidia Ivanovna and the clairvoyant Landau, refuses Anna's divorce. Anna, in Moscow, is consumed by jealousy and anger towards Vronsky, believing his love has waned. She accuses him of being cold and heartless. She contemplates suicide, having had a dream of a peasant muttering French words. Vronsky, angered by her accusations, tells her his patience has limits. Anna, seeing his hatred, believes he loves another woman and that "all is over." She bursts into sobs, begging him to cast her off. He assures her of his love, and they reconcile.

**PART FIVE**

Levin and Kitty are married. Levin is overwhelmed by happiness, but finds married life different from his dreams. He is surprised by Kitty's domesticity and their quarrels. Kitty, in turn, is jealous of his past and his work. They reconcile, experiencing new happiness.

Levin's brother, Nikolay, is dying. Levin and Kitty travel to him. Kitty, with her practical care and spiritual conviction, cleans the room and persuades Nikolay to receive extreme unction. Nikolay dies. The doctor confirms Kitty is pregnant.

Alexey Alexandrovitch, after Anna's departure, is distraught. Countess Lidia Ivanovna offers him spiritual consolation and manages his household. He convinces himself he is experiencing salvation. Anna, in Petersburg, tries to see Seryozha, but Lidia Ivanovna refuses her request. Anna, humiliated, resolves to see Seryozha on his birthday. She goes to her former home, finds Seryozha, and they embrace. Alexey Alexandrovitch enters, meeting Anna at the door. She glances at him with repulsion and hatred and rushes out.

**PART SIX**

Dolly and her children spend the summer with Kitty and Levin. Sergey Ivanovitch and Varenka are also there, and Kitty hopes for a romance between them. However, Sergey Ivanovitch, after almost proposing, backs out, feeling he cannot be false to the memory of his deceased love. Levin, filled with jealousy, confronts Kitty about Vassenka Veslovsky's flirtation. He sends Veslovsky away.

Dolly visits Anna at Vronsky's estate. Dolly is impressed by Anna's elegance and Vronsky's luxurious home, but is also disturbed by their irregular position. Anna reveals she will have no more children due to a doctor's advice, which Dolly finds "immoral." Vronsky confesses to Dolly his desire for a divorce and legitimate heirs, urging her to persuade Anna to write to Alexey Alexandrovitch.

Anna and Vronsky's life is strained by quarrels. Anna is jealous of Vronsky's waning love and blames him for her suffering. She contemplates suicide. Vronsky is frustrated by her inability to endure their deceitful life. He agrees to leave for the country with her.

**PART SEVEN**

Levin and Kitty are in Moscow, awaiting Kitty's confinement. Levin is uneasy and aimless in the city, while Kitty is calm and happy. Kitty meets Vronsky at a social gathering and maintains her composure. Levin is troubled by the meeting but reassured by Kitty's honesty. Levin struggles with financial worries and his sister's unsettled business. He meets Professor Katavasov and Metrov, discussing his book on agriculture. He then visits Lvov, Kitty's brother-in-law, and discusses children's education.

Levin attends a concert, finding the new music confusing. He then goes to the club, where he feels a sense of comfort and reconciliation with Vronsky. Stepan Arkadyevitch suggests they visit Anna. Levin agrees, despite his doubts. He is struck by Mihailov's portrait of Anna and her captivating presence. He feels tenderness and pity for her.

Anna, in Moscow, is consumed by jealousy and despair. She believes Vronsky's love is waning and he is tired of her. She contemplates suicide. She has a nightmare of a peasant. She sees Vronsky talking to another woman and believes he loves her. She confronts him, and they quarrel. She decides to end it all. She goes to the railway station, recalling the man crushed by the train. She flings herself under the wheels of a train, and the light in her eyes is "quenched forever."

**PART EIGHT**

Two months after Anna's death, Sergey Ivanovitch's book is a failure. He immerses himself in the Slavonic question, finding purpose in helping the Servians. He travels to the country with Katavasov, observing volunteers leaving for the war. Countess Vronskaya, Vronsky's mother, tells Sergey Ivanovitch about Vronsky's despair after Anna's death and his suicide attempt. She blames Anna for ruining Vronsky's career. Vronsky, consumed by suffering and toothache, joins the volunteers, seeking death in war. He recalls Anna's bloodstained body.

Levin and Kitty are at Pokrovskoe. Kitty is delighted by her baby, Mitya. Levin, despite his earlier unbelief, finds a new faith and spiritual peace, realizing that he knows what is right and wrong not through reason, but through his heart. He works on his estate, finding meaning in his duties. He and Kitty are happy in their love and family life.

The text concludes with Levin's profound spiritual revelation. He has found a "positive meaning of goodness" in his life, despite his continued intellectual doubts and personal struggles. He accepts that his life will still have its imperfections, but his faith, born from suffering, has taken firm root in his soul. He is filled with love for his wife and child, and a sense of purpose that transcends his previous intellectual and worldly pursuits.

summary_llm:
Raskolnikov, a young, impoverished former student, lives in a tiny garret in S. Place. Deeply in debt to his landlady, Praskovya Pavlovna, he avoids her due to his irritable, hypochondriacal state and a secret "project" he contemplates. One exceptionally hot July evening, he leaves his lodging, acutely aware of his fears, yet determined to carry out his plan. He is going for a "rehearsal."

He arrives at a large house, where he knows an old pawnbroker, Alyona Ivanovna, lives. He notes that a German clerk is moving out, leaving the old woman as the sole occupant on her floor. He rings her bell, and the diminutive, withered old woman, with sharp, malignant eyes, opens the door. Raskolnikov, introducing himself as a student, presents an old silver watch to pawn. Alyona Ivanovna, after deducting advance interest, offers him a meager sum. He is angered but accepts, his true "object" being something else. Before leaving, he casually asks if her half-sister, Lizaveta, is always at home with her. Alyona Ivanovna responds with suspicion. Raskolnikov leaves, feeling intense repulsion for his "atrocious thing" and enters a tavern, where he drinks beer to clear his head.

In the tavern, he encounters a drunken, disgraced former government clerk named Marmeladov. Marmeladov, a man over fifty, confesses his life story to Raskolnikov. He describes his educated wife, Katerina Ivanovna, and her three small children, all living in extreme poverty. Marmeladov admits to having sold his wife's belongings for drink, even though she is consumptive and works tirelessly. He reveals that his daughter, Sonia, from his first marriage, has been forced into prostitution ("yellow ticket") to support the family, after Katerina Ivanovna, driven to distraction by hunger, taunted her into it. Marmeladov confesses that he recently stole his last earnings from Katerina Ivanovna and spent them on drink, even taking Sonia's last thirty copecks that very morning. He delivers a passionate, religious monologue about forgiveness and suffering, particularly for Sonia. Exhausted, Marmeladov asks Raskolnikov to accompany him home.

At Marmeladov's squalid lodging, Katerina Ivanovna, emaciated and feverish, is pacing and coughing. She screams at Marmeladov for returning drunk and searches him for money, finding none. She drags him by his hair, causing the children to cry in terror. Other lodgers mock them. As Raskolnikov leaves, he secretly places some coppers on the window for the family, but then regrets it, thinking "they have Sonia and I want it myself." He reflects on the "percentage" of society doomed to such fates and wonders if his sister Dounia might become one.

The next day, Raskolnikov wakes late and irritable. His landlady, Praskovya Pavlovna, is threatening to report him to the police for unpaid rent. Nastasya, his servant, brings him a letter from his mother. The letter details Dounia's recent ordeal as a governess for the Svidrigaïlovs. Mr. Svidrigaïlov, her employer, made "shameful proposals" to Dounia. His wife, Marfa Petrovna, wrongly accused Dounia, struck her, and sent her away, leading to widespread slander against Dounia. However, Svidrigaïlov later provided proof of Dounia's innocence, and Marfa Petrovna publicly cleared her name. The letter then reveals Dounia's engagement to Pyotr Petrovitch Luzhin, a wealthy, conceited man who stated he preferred to marry a poor girl to ensure she would be grateful and subservient. Raskolnikov's mother and Dounia are coming to Petersburg, hoping Luzhin will help Raskolnikov's career. Raskolnikov is furious, seeing Dounia's marriage as a sacrifice for his sake, comparable to Sonia's fate. He vows to prevent it.

He leaves his room, feeling a menacing reality to his "project." He sees a young, drunk girl being pursued by a gentleman. Raskolnikov intervenes, giving a policeman money to help the girl, but then has a change of heart, telling the policeman to let them be. He reflects on his own potential for "vice." He then finds himself near the house where the old pawnbroker lives. He overhears Lizaveta arranging to be away at seven o'clock the next day, leaving Alyona Ivanovna alone. This unexpected opportunity solidifies his resolve.

The next morning, after a restless sleep, Raskolnikov prepares for the murder. He makes a noose to conceal an axe under his coat and a fake "pledge" to distract the old woman. He goes to steal an axe from his landlady's kitchen but finds Nastasya there. Frustrated, he finds an axe in the porter's room. He proceeds to Alyona Ivanovna's flat. He rings the bell, is let in cautiously, and then strikes the old woman on the head with the axe, killing her. As he searches for valuables, Lizaveta unexpectedly enters. He kills her too, in a panic. Overwhelmed by fear and loathing, he washes the axe and his hands. He discovers the outer door was unlocked the entire time. He slips back into the flat when two men (Koch and a young man) arrive, ring the bell, and realize someone is inside but not opening. They go to fetch the porter. Raskolnikov hides in an empty flat on a lower floor, then escapes unseen. He hides the stolen jewels and money under a stone in a deserted yard.

Back in his room, Raskolnikov is consumed by fever and delirium. He receives a summons to the police station for an unpaid IOU to his landlady. At the police station, he is relieved to find it's only about the debt. He faints during the interview, overhearing the officers discussing the pawnbroker's murder and the initial suspects, Koch and Pestryakov. He realizes they suspect him.

Razumihin, Raskolnikov's friend, visits him, bringing new clothes and money from his mother. Razumihin explains he paid off the IOU. He also reveals that the police suspect Raskolnikov, and that Zametov, a police clerk, was particularly interested in Raskolnikov's strange behavior and comments about the murder. Raskolnikov, in a restaurant, deliberately teases Zametov, hinting at his own involvement in the murder, and describes how he would have hidden the stolen goods (under a stone). Zametov is visibly shaken.

Later, Raskolnikov encounters Svidrigaïlov, Dounia's former employer, who has unexpectedly arrived in Petersburg. Svidrigaïlov reveals he knows Raskolnikov's secret, having overheard his confession to Sonia through the wall of his adjoining room. Svidrigaïlov, a cynical and depraved man, offers Dounia 10,000 roubles to break off her engagement to Luzhin, claiming he has no further designs on her. He also reveals that Marfa Petrovna left Dounia 3,000 roubles in her will. Raskolnikov is appalled by Svidrigaïlov's depravity but also intrigued by his knowledge.

At a tense meeting, Dounia confronts Luzhin, who tries to accuse Sonia of theft, planting a 100-rouble note in her pocket. Lebeziatnikov, however, exposes Luzhin's scheme, having witnessed him plant the money. Raskolnikov then reveals Luzhin's true motive: to discredit him and Sonia, and regain Dounia's favor. Dounia, disgusted, breaks off the engagement and orders Luzhin to leave.

Katerina Ivanovna, Marmeladov's widow, is evicted from her lodging and, in a fit of madness brought on by consumption and despair, takes her children to beg in the streets, forcing them to sing and dance. Raskolnikov and Sonia find her. Katerina Ivanovna collapses, bleeding from her chest, and dies in Sonia's room, entrusting her children to Sonia. Svidrigaïlov, present at the scene, offers to provide for Katerina Ivanovna's children and settle 1,500 roubles on each. He tells Raskolnikov to inform Dounia that this is how he is spending her 10,000 roubles, further confirming he overheard Raskolnikov's confession.

Raskolnikov, tormented by his secret and Porfiry's psychological games, goes to Sonia. He confesses to her that he murdered Alyona Ivanovna and Lizaveta. He explains his "Napoleon theory," believing certain extraordinary individuals have the right to transgress moral laws for a greater good. He admits he killed for the "daring" to prove he was not a "louse," but now feels he murdered himself. Sonia, horrified but compassionate, urges him to confess publicly, to "kiss the earth" and say "I am a murderer" to find redemption through suffering. Raskolnikov, though initially resistant, is deeply moved by her unwavering love and faith.

Svidrigaïlov, after giving his betrothed 15,000 roubles and making arrangements for Katerina Ivanovna's children, commits suicide by shooting himself in the head in front of a watchman.

Raskolnikov visits his mother, expressing his love and asking her to pray for him, but without revealing his crime. He then sees Dounia, who knows his secret from Sonia. He tells her he is going to confess, but still struggles with the idea of his crime. He gives Dounia a portrait of his deceased fiancée (his landlady's daughter).

Finally, Raskolnikov goes to the Hay Market. Remembering Sonia's words, he kneels in the middle of the square and kisses the earth. He sees Sonia watching him from behind a shanty. He then walks to the police office and confesses to Ilya Petrovitch, stating, "It was I killed the old pawnbroker woman and her sister Lizaveta with an axe and robbed them."

**EPILOGUE:**
Raskolnikov is sentenced to eight years of penal servitude in Siberia. His trial is straightforward, as he confesses clearly and precisely, even detailing the hiding place of the stolen items. The court attributes his crime to "temporary mental derangement" and "homicidal mania" due to his poverty and hypochondriacal state, especially since he made no use of the stolen money. Extenuating circumstances, such as his past good deeds (helping a student, rescuing children from a fire), lead to a merciful sentence.

During the trial, Raskolnikov's mother falls ill with a nervous disorder and partial derangement of intellect. Dounia and Razumihin move her out of Petersburg and create a false story about Raskolnikov's departure for a business commission. Pulcheria Alexandrovna, however, develops her own fantasy of Rodya being a great statesman with powerful enemies, constantly reading his article and obsessing over his past good deeds. She dies of brain fever within a fortnight, having subconsciously known more about his terrible fate.

Two months after Raskolnikov's sentencing, Dounia marries Razumihin. They plan to move to Siberia within five years to be with Raskolnikov. Sonia, using the money Svidrigaïlov gave her, follows Raskolnikov to Siberia. She visits him regularly in prison and at work, providing practical support and maintaining correspondence with the Razumihins. Raskolnikov is initially sullen and distant, but Sonia's visits become a necessity.

In Siberia, Raskolnikov remains unrepentant, viewing his crime as a "blunder" rather than a moral failing. He feels isolated from his fellow prisoners, who despise him as a "gentleman" and an "infidel." He is troubled by a dream of a world consumed by a plague of madness. After a period of illness in the hospital, he is discharged.

One warm spring morning, at work on the river bank, Sonia appears and sits beside him. He is suddenly overcome with emotion, falls at her feet, and weeps, embracing her knees. Sonia, understanding his love, is filled with "infinite happiness." They are both renewed by love, looking forward to a "new future, of a full resurrection into a new life," despite the seven years of suffering ahead. Raskolnikov picks up Sonia's New Testament, the book from which she read him the story of Lazarus, and reflects on her convictions. The story concludes, marking the beginning of Raskolnikov's "gradual renewal" and "regeneration."

summary_llm:
The story begins on a spring afternoon in 19--, with Gustav Aschenbach, a renowned writer (officially von Aschenbach after his fiftieth birthday), taking a long walk in Munich. Overwhelmed by his demanding work, which has prevented him from achieving his usual midday rest, he seeks restoration in the outdoors. After walking through the English Gardens and surveying the lively Wirtsgarten at the Aumeister, he starts home. Feeling tired and observing a storm approaching, he waits for a tram at the North Cemetery.

While waiting, Aschenbach notices a man in the portico of the Funeral Hall. This man, of medium height, thin, smooth-shaven, pug-nosed, and red-haired, with a foreign appearance, stares militantly at Aschenbach. Aschenbach turns away uncomfortably but finds himself affected by the stranger's exotic look. He experiences a sudden, intense "youthful longing after far-off places," a desire for travel that crystallizes into an hallucination of a tropical swampland, filled with exotic and dangerous imagery.

Aschenbach, who usually views travel as a mere hygienic necessity and has confined his life to Munich and his country house, recognizes this urge as a desire to escape the "steady drudgery" of his work. He admits his recent work, though technically masterful, lacks emotional fire. Fearing a boring summer in the country, he decides a change of air is needed, settling on a three-to-four-week stay at a pleasant resort in the South. As he boards the tram, he looks for the strange man but he is gone.

The narrative then provides background on Aschenbach. He is a celebrated author, known for his powerful prose epics and treatises, knighted on his fiftieth birthday. He is described as a disciplined artist, not of strong constitution, who achieved greatness through tenacious effort and minute revision. His work often features a "new hero-type" characterized by "intellectual and youthful masculinity" that endures adversity. He had evolved from youthful skepticism to dignity in his writing style, which became more formal and conservative. A widower with a married daughter, he lived a respectable middle-class life. His face, marked by his intense artistic endeavors, showed the effects of "imaginary and spiritual adventures."

About two weeks after his Munich walk, Aschenbach departs. He first stops at an island in the Adriatic, but finds it unsatisfactory due to bad weather, a provincial hotel, and a lack of a sandy beach. Feeling restless, he suddenly decides his true destination is Venice. He quickly leaves the island and boards an old, sooty ship bound for Venice.

On the ship, he encounters a dirty, hunchbacked sailor and a ticket seller resembling an "old-style circus director," who effusively praises Venice. On deck, Aschenbach observes a group of young people from Pola. Among them, he notices a man in a bright yellow suit who appears youthful but, upon closer inspection, is revealed to be an old man disguised with makeup, a wig, dyed facial hair, and false teeth. Aschenbach is horrified by this deception, feeling a "dream-like estrangement" and a "peculiar distortion of the world."

The ship sails through grey, damp weather. Aschenbach rests and dreams vaguely of the strange figures he has seen. At lunch, he eats quickly, eager for Venice. He hopes for bright skies, but the weather remains dreary. He reflects on Venice's usual splendor and wonders if a "new enchantment" awaits him. The ship passes the bathers' island and enters the port. While waiting for a health department barque, Aschenbach observes the old dandy from the ship, now painfully drunk and making repulsive, suggestive gestures. Aschenbach feels a "numbness" and a sense of the world becoming "grotesque."

The ship finally proceeds through the San Marco canal, and Aschenbach is struck by the magnificent view of Venice's buildings. He decides this is the only proper way to approach the "most unreal of cities." Upon disembarking, he requests a gondola to take him to the Lido steamer dock, as he intends to stay by the sea. While his luggage is being handled, the drunk old man from the ship approaches him again, making lewd farewells, his false teeth falling out. Aschenbach escapes.

In the gondola, Aschenbach notes its coffin-like appearance and its association with death. The gondolier, a brutal-looking man with a foreign accent, rows towards the open sea instead of the steamer dock. Aschenbach protests, but the gondolier insists he is going to the Lido and claims the public steamer cannot carry luggage. Annoyed by the man's insolence but feeling powerless, Aschenbach lets the gondolier continue, even having a fleeting thought that he might be in the hands of a criminal. When he asks the fare, the gondolier simply says, "You will pay." Aschenbach threatens not to pay, but the gondolier remains unperturbed. A boat of musical brigands briefly joins them, singing for money, which Aschenbach provides.

They arrive at the Lido dock. Aschenbach goes to a hotel to get change, and when he returns, the gondola and gondolier have vanished. An old man with a grappling hook informs him the gondolier was unlicensed and "a bad man." Aschenbach shrugs, pays the old man, and proceeds to the beach hotel.

At the hotel, Aschenbach is shown to a room with a sea view. He reflects on how loneliness intensifies experiences, and the strange encounters of his journey continue to disturb him. He takes tea on the terrace and walks along the boardwalk. Later, in the hotel lobby, he observes other guests and is astonished by the beauty of a fourteen-year-old Polish boy, Tadzio, who is with his sisters and governess. Tadzio's face, with honey-colored hair and a "godlike seriousness," reminds Aschenbach of Greek sculpture. He notes the stark contrast between Tadzio's pampered appearance and his sisters' severe, nun-like attire. Aschenbach suspects Tadzio might be sickly due to his pale skin. The family leaves for dinner, and Tadzio's eyes meet Aschenbach's. Aschenbach dines, regretting his distance from their table, and spends the night dreaming.

The next day, the weather remains poor, with a foul smell from the lagoon. Aschenbach feels depressed and considers leaving, recalling a past illness in Venice. At breakfast, he sees Tadzio enter the buffet-room. The boy's graceful movements and "godlike beauty" again astound Aschenbach. He decides to stay. On the beach, Aschenbach observes Tadzio playing. He notices Tadzio's "scorn and detestation" towards a Russian family, which makes the boy seem more complex and worthy of deeper sympathy. Aschenbach deduces the boy's name is Tadzio. He watches Tadzio bathe, emerging from the sea like a "frail god," inspiring Aschenbach with a sense of myth. He feels a "paternal affection" for the boy.

Later, in the lift, Aschenbach sees Tadzio up close for the first time. He notices Tadzio's "indescribably agreeable smile" but also that his teeth are "jagged and pale," suggesting he is "very frail, sickly," and "will not grow old." Aschenbach feels a peculiar "gratification or reassurance" at this thought.

That afternoon, Aschenbach takes a vaporetto to Venice. The city's oppressive sultriness, mixed odors, and crowded streets make him feel unwell, with a fever and pounding head. He decides he must leave Venice, which he now deems unhealthy for him. He plans to go to another watering place. On his gondola ride back to San Marco, the gondolier, in league with local merchants, repeatedly tries to make him stop for purchases, breaking the city's spell.

Back at the hotel, Aschenbach announces his departure for the next morning. He settles his accounts and prepares his luggage. He sleeps restlessly, already regretting his decision, feeling it was hasty. At breakfast, the hotel porter tries to rush him out, but Aschenbach insists on finishing his meal in peace. Just as he is about to leave, Tadzio enters the buffet-room. Tadzio passes Aschenbach, lowering his eyes, then raising them with a "delicious manner." Aschenbach silently bids him "Good-bye" and "God bless you!"

He leaves the hotel on foot, taking the public steamboat. On the journey across the lagoon, he feels "painful regret," realizing how deeply attached he is to Venice. The thought of never seeing the city again is "insufferable." He feels his physical defeat (his illness) is dishonorable and a challenge to stay. At the station, in a state of intense conflict, he learns his large trunk has been mistakenly sent to Como. Aschenbach is "convulsed with an adventurous delight" at this mishap. He declares he cannot travel without his trunk and decides to return to the beach hotel to await its return. He manages to redeem his ticket and returns to the Lido on the company's motorboat, feeling a "comically dreamlike" sense of fate driving him back.

The hotel manager apologizes for the luggage error and provides Aschenbach with a new room. Tired but content to be back, Aschenbach sits by his window. He sees Tadzio returning from the sea and feels an "exhilaration of his blood, a conflict of pain and pleasure," realizing Tadzio was the true reason it was so difficult to leave. He makes a spontaneous gesture of "welcome, of calm acceptance."

Days pass with beautiful weather. Aschenbach, now permanently settled in his new room, is enchanted by the Lido's comfortable rhythm and Venice's proximity. He, usually a disciplined worker, finds his will relaxed and feels happy, contrasting this with his rigorous life in the mountains. He sees Tadzio almost constantly, spending hours on the beach watching him. He admires Tadzio's beauty, comparing his movements to a "frail god" and his body to a "statue." Aschenbach feels that in Tadzio, he is seeing "the beautiful itself, form as the thought of God." This fills him with a "drunkenness" and inspires him to write, making his style emulate Tadzio's "godlike" form. He produces a short, admired prose piece. After working, he feels exhausted, as if his conscience is troubled.

One morning, he is tempted to approach Tadzio on the beach but is overcome by a pounding heart and shortness of breath, failing to speak to him. He thinks "Too late!" but then realizes he doesn't want "soberness," finding his "intoxication too precious." He stops thinking about leaving, sending for more money, his only concern now Tadzio's possible departure. He embraces the sun and sea air, letting the invigoration fuel his emotions. His nights are filled with "happy unrest." He wakes at dawn, experiencing a vivid, mythical vision of Eros and a "strewing of roses," whispering Tadzio's name.

He continues to observe Tadzio, sometimes seeing him as Hyacinth, the youth loved by gods and destined to die. Aschenbach notes the unspoken connection between them, the "tense respect" and "unsatisfied, unnaturally repressed desire." He observes Tadzio subtly acknowledging his presence, walking closer to his spot on the beach, and their glances meeting. One evening, he sees Tadzio returning from the city, looking particularly beautiful. Their eyes meet, and Tadzio smiles at Aschenbach, a "deep, fascinated, magnetic smile" like Narcissus, "coquettish, inquisitive, and slightly tortured," "infatuated, and infatuating." Aschenbach, feeling he has received a "fatal gift," flees to the dark park and, overwhelmed, whispers, "I love you!"

During his fourth week, Aschenbach makes "sinister observations." The number of hotel guests is diminishing, especially Germans. The barber, when questioned, evasively mentions "the plague." Aschenbach goes to Venice, following Tadzio's family. He notices a "peculiar odour" in the air, "sweetish and drug-like," which he realizes he'd been smelling for days. He sees municipal warnings about gastric diseases and canal water, recognizing them as euphemisms. He questions a shop proprietor, who gives an evasive answer about police precautions. On the steamer, he smells disinfectant.

Back at the hotel, Aschenbach reads newspapers, finding official denials of rumors about a disease. He realizes the German and Austrian guests left due to this. He is angry at the cover-up but also feels a "dark contentment" that the city's "wicked secret" aligns with his own passion. He fears Tadzio's departure above all else. He begins to actively pursue Tadzio, stalking him through Venice, even following his gondola in another, bribing his gondolier. He gets lost and exhausted but is "drunk" with his pursuit. He returns late one evening and, in "utter drunkenness," lays his head against the hinge of Tadzio's door.

He has moments of clarity, questioning his actions and thinking of his ancestors' strict principles. He rationalizes his infatuation by connecting it to a historical view of Eros and heroism. He continues to seek reliable news about the pestilence, finding conflicting reports. He questions the hotel manager, who gives an evasive answer about police regulations.

That evening, a band of strolling singers performs at the hotel. Aschenbach watches, his "passion lames the sense of discrimination." Tadzio is nearby. Aschenbach notices the guitar player, whose appearance (snub-nosed, reddish eyebrows, active Adam's-apple) reminds him of the first stranger at the cemetery. He also detects a "strong carbolic smell" from the singer. Aschenbach questions the singer about the disinfection, who evasively denies a plague. Aschenbach, realizing the truth, pays him generously. Hotel employees question the singer, who assures them he kept quiet. The singer performs a final, derisive song with a rhythmic laugh, which becomes infectious. Aschenbach is caught in a "trance" by the laughter, the "hospital smell," and Tadzio's nearness. He notices Tadzio's serious expression, seemingly mirroring his own. He also observes Tadzio's quick breathing and stretching, indicating lung congestion, and repeatedly thinks, "He is sickly, he will probably not grow old," feeling a "rakish gratification."

The next day, Aschenbach visits an English travel bureau, where a clerk finally reveals the truth: an Indian cholera epidemic is raging in Venice. It spread from the Ganges delta, through Asia, and reached Mediterranean ports. Cases were found in Venice in May but were kept secret by authorities to protect tourism, despite the resignation of the chief health officer. The plague is severe, with 80% fatality, causing a "drying" of the victim. Hospitals are full, and the burial island is busy. The city's demoralization has led to increased crime and debauchery. The Englishman advises Aschenbach to leave immediately, as a quarantine is imminent.

Aschenbach leaves the office, feeling "feverishly excited, triumphant in his possession of the truth," but also a "bad taste" and "weird horror." He considers warning Tadzio's mother but realizes he doesn't truly want to. He whispers, "It must be kept silent!" and "I will keep silent!" He feels intoxicated by his share in the secret, finding "egregious sweetness" in the chaos, and decides to remain in Venice.

That night, he has a frightful dream of a pagan ritual, a raging mob, and a "deep coaxing flute." He hears the word "Tadziu" wailed. He fights against the experience but is drawn into the "excesses of the extreme sacrifice," smelling "the pungent smell of the bucks, the scent of moist bodies, and a waft of stagnant water, with another smell, something familiar, the smell of wounds and prevalent disease." He feels caught in a "blinding deafening lewdness" and tastes the "unchastity and fury of decay."

He awakens "unnerved, shattered, and hopelessly under the power of the demon." He no longer cares about being noticed. Guests are fleeing, but Tadzio and his family remain. Aschenbach feels that death might remove all disturbing elements, leaving him alone with the boy. Moral laws seem to have dropped away. He wants to please Tadzio, detests his aging body, and visits the hotel barber to rejuvenate his appearance. The barber dyes his hair black, curls it, and applies cosmetics to his face, making him look younger. The barber says, "Now the gentleman can fall in love unhesitatingly." Aschenbach feels "happy as in a dream." He wears a red necktie and a broad-brimmed straw hat.

A storm wind rises, bringing rain and the smell of "things rotting." Aschenbach imagines food is poisoned. He tracks Tadzio through the diseased city, using "disgraceful subterfuges" to follow. Tadzio, walking behind his companions, occasionally turns to confirm Aschenbach is still following. Aschenbach, "drunk with the knowledge," follows until he loses sight of Tadzio. Exhausted and thirsty, he buys and eats overly ripe strawberries. He rests on the steps of a cistern in a quiet square, smelling carbolic acid. He reflects on his past dignified self and his current state of moral dissolution, recalling the philosophical discussion from his dream about the perilous path of beauty for artists, leading to intoxication and the "precipice." He concludes that poets "necessarily go astray" and that their art is a "precarious undertaking." He ends his internal monologue by saying, "And now I am going, Phaedrus. You stay here; and when you no longer see me, then you go too."

A few days later, Aschenbach feels unwell, experiencing vertigo and malaise. In the hotel lobby, he sees Tadzio's family's luggage and learns they are leaving after lunch. He accepts this news without visible emotion. He goes to the beach, which now has an "air of autumn" and is almost abandoned. Tadzio is playing with his remaining companions. A wrestling match breaks out between Tadzio and Jaschu, ending with Jaschu pinning Tadzio's face in the sand, nearly strangling him. Aschenbach is enraged and almost intervenes, but Jaschu releases Tadzio. Tadzio, pale and rumpled, slowly moves away from his companions towards the water.

Tadzio lingers at the water's edge, then wades to a sand-bank. He stands facing the open sea, then walks along the narrow stretch of exposed ground, isolated from his companions and the mainland. He stops and, with one hand on his hip, turns his upper body in a "beautiful twist," looking over his shoulder towards the shore. Aschenbach, watching, feels as though Tadzio is smiling and nodding to him, "signalling to come out," and "vaguely guiding towards egregious promises." As often before, Aschenbach stands up to follow him.

Minutes later, Aschenbach collapses into his chair. He is brought to his room. On the same day, the world receives news of his death.

The generated summary covers all the events, characters, and plot points mentioned in the original summary, but it also extends significantly beyond the scope of the original, providing a comprehensive summary of the entire novel "Death in Venice."

**Detailed Justification of Missing or Extra Details:**

**Missing Details (from Original, in Generated Summary's Overlapping Section):**

1.  **Thematic Context of the Year:** The original mentions the year as "the year in which...so grave a threat seemed to hang over the peace of Europe." The generated summary places it in "19--" but omits this specific thematic detail about the looming European conflict.
