summary_llm:
This is a detailed plot summary of the provided text, "Great Expectations."

**Chapter I.**
The narrator, Philip Pirrip, who calls himself Pip, is an orphan living with his much older sister, Mrs. Joe Gargery, and her husband, Joe Gargery, the blacksmith. His parents and five infant brothers are buried in the churchyard. On a raw afternoon, Pip encounters a fearful, coarse-looking man with an iron on his leg, who threatens to cut Pip's throat if he doesn't comply. The man demands Pip's name and where he lives. After emptying Pip's pockets of a piece of bread, which he devours, the man threatens to eat Pip's cheeks. He then orders Pip to bring him a file and "wittles" (food) to the old Battery tomorrow morning, threatening to tear out his heart and liver if he fails. The man also mentions a "young man hid with me" who is even more terrible and has a "secret way" of harming boys. Pip, terrified, promises to obey and is made to swear an oath. The man then limps away towards the river, passing a gibbet, which makes Pip imagine him as a pirate come to life. Pip runs home, deeply frightened.

**Chapter II.**
Pip describes his sister, Mrs. Joe, as a harsh woman who claims to have raised him "by hand," often using her "hard and heavy hand" on both Pip and Joe. Joe is a mild, good-natured blacksmith. Pip arrives home to find Joe alone, who tells him Mrs. Joe has been out looking for him with "Tickler," a wax-ended cane. Mrs. Joe returns, punishes Pip with Tickler, and throws him at Joe. She scolds Pip for being in the churchyard and for being a burden. Pip, remembering his promise to the convict, secretly hides his slice of bread and butter in his trousers leg. Joe notices Pip hasn't eaten, leading Mrs. Joe to hit Joe's head against the wall. Pip is then forced to drink a nasty medicine called Tar-water, and Joe is also made to drink some. Pip is tormented by guilt over the planned theft and fear of the convict and his unseen "young man." It is Christmas Eve, and Pip, while stirring pudding, finds the hidden food unmanageable, so he hides it in his garret bedroom. He overhears Joe and Mrs. Joe discussing "conwicts" escaping from "the Hulks" (prison-ships), which increases his terror, believing he is destined for prison. At dawn, Pip steals bread, cheese, mincemeat, brandy, a meat bone, and a pork pie from the pantry, and a file from Joe's forge, then flees to the marshes.

**Chapter III.**
Pip makes his way through the misty, damp marshes, feeling accused by everything around him. He gets lost and encounters a second man, also in coarse grey with an iron on his leg, whom he identifies as the "young man" mentioned by the first convict. This man curses at Pip and stumbles away into the mist. Pip soon finds the first convict at the Battery, cold and hungry. Pip gives him the file and the stolen food. The convict eats ravenously, asking Pip if he brought anyone with him. Pip denies it. When Pip mentions seeing the "young man," the convict is enraged, demanding to know where he is, and begins furiously filing at his own leg iron. Pip, again terrified, slips away and runs home.

**Chapter IV.**
Pip expects to find a Constable at home but discovers the robbery is still undetected. Mrs. Joe is busy preparing for Christmas dinner, which will include Mr. Wopsle (the church clerk), Mr. and Mrs. Hubble (the wheelwright), and Uncle Pumblechook (Joe’s uncle). Pip is treated as an "offender" and feels immense guilt. Uncle Pumblechook arrives with wine and calls Pip "Sixpennorth of halfpence." During dinner, Pip is subjected to lectures on gratitude and is compared to "swine" by Mr. Wopsle and Pumblechook. Joe tries to comfort Pip with gravy. When Mrs. Joe offers Pumblechook brandy, Pip is horrified, as he had refilled the bottle with tar-water. Pumblechook drinks it, suffers a violent, spasmodic fit, and rushes out, gasping "Tar!" Mrs. Joe and Joe tend to him. Pip realizes the pork pie will be discovered. In a panic, he runs from the house, only to collide with a party of soldiers at the door, one of whom holds out handcuffs.

**Chapter V.**
The soldiers' arrival interrupts the dinner. The sergeant explains they need the blacksmith to mend handcuffs for escaped convicts. Joe agrees to fix them, estimating it will take two hours. The sergeant mentions they are closing in on two convicts on the marshes. Pip realizes the handcuffs are not for him. Mrs. Joe offers beer and wine, and Pumblechook, having recovered from the tar-water incident, suggests wine over brandy. Pip reflects on how the excitement of the convict hunt makes the company enjoy themselves. Joe finishes the repair, and he, Pip, and Mr. Wopsle join the soldiers in the pursuit. Pip, riding on Joe's back, fears his convict will think he betrayed him. They hear shouts and sounds of struggle. They find the two convicts fighting in a ditch. Pip's convict declares he "took him" (the other convict) and gave him up. The other convict, bruised, claims his companion tried to murder him. Pip's convict boasts of escaping the prison-ship alone and dragging the other back. Torches are lit, and Pip's convict sees Pip, giving him an unreadable look. Cannon shots signal the convicts are expected on board. At a hut, Pip's convict confesses to stealing food and a pie from the blacksmith's. Joe, understanding, says he's welcome to it. The convict is then taken to a boat and rowed to the "black Hulk," a prison-ship.

**Chapter VI.**
Pip feels guilty towards Joe for his theft but is too cowardly to confess, fearing he would lose Joe's confidence. Joe carries a sleepy Pip home. At home, Joe tells the visitors about the convict's confession. Pumblechook invents a fantastical story about how the convict broke into the house. Pip is sent to bed, still burdened by his secret.

**Chapter VII.**
Pip describes his limited childhood education and his apprenticeship to Joe. He occasionally works odd jobs, with his earnings going into a money-box. Mr. Wopsle's great-aunt runs a chaotic evening school and a small shop, assisted by her granddaughter, Biddy, an orphan. Biddy helps Pip learn to read, write, and cipher. One winter night, a year after the marsh incident, Pip writes a letter to Joe, who is amazed. Joe then reveals his own difficult childhood, marked by an abusive, alcoholic father, which prevented his education. Joe explains he married Mrs. Joe, who "governs" them, and he cannot "rise" against her. Mrs. Joe and Pumblechook return from market, and Mrs. Joe announces that Miss Havisham wants Pip to "play" at her house. Pumblechook takes credit for this opportunity. Pip is cleaned and dressed, then taken by Pumblechook to Miss Havisham's.

**Chapter VIII.**
Pip spends the night at Pumblechook's. The next morning, Pumblechook subjects Pip to arithmetic questions during a meager breakfast. They arrive at Miss Havisham's dismal, barred house. Estella, a pretty but proud young lady, admits Pip but turns Pumblechook away. Estella leads Pip through the dark house to Miss Havisham, who is dressed in a faded bridal gown, sitting in a room where all the clocks are stopped at twenty minutes to nine. Miss Havisham, whose heart is "broken," demands Pip "play" for her. Pip is unable. Miss Havisham then tells Estella to play cards with Pip, instructing her, "You can break his heart." Estella scorns Pip's "coarse hands" and "thick boots." Pip feels ashamed. Miss Havisham asks Pip what he thinks of Estella; he whispers that she is proud, pretty, and insulting. Estella wins the game. Pip is then given food in the courtyard and treated insolently by Estella. He cries in humiliation. Exploring the deserted brewery and garden, Pip has a terrifying illusion of Miss Havisham hanging from a beam. Estella taunts him for crying. Pip returns to Pumblechook's, deeply affected by his commonness and Estella's contempt.

**Chapter IX.**
Pip's sister demands details about Miss Havisham's, punishing him for vague answers. Pumblechook also presses him for information. Pip lies extravagantly, inventing stories about a black velvet coach, immense dogs, and flags and swords. Joe is dismayed by the lies. Pumblechook and Mrs. Joe speculate about Pip's future wealth. Pip confesses his lies to Joe, expressing shame for his commonness and his desire to be a gentleman for Estella. Joe, in his simple wisdom, tells Pip that "lies is lies" and that true improvement comes from honesty. Joe recounts his own difficult childhood. Pip, despite Joe's kindness, goes to bed still longing to be uncommon and despising his home. He dreams his expectations are cancelled.

**Chapter X.**
Pip resolves to learn from Biddy to become "uncommon." He describes the ineffective school and Biddy's quiet competence. One evening, Pip goes to the Three Jolly Bargemen to fetch Joe and encounters a "secret-looking man" who stirs his rum with a file. Pip recognizes the file as Joe's and realizes the man knows his convict. The man gives Pip a shilling, wrapped in two one-pound notes. Joe, upon discovering the notes, attempts to return them, but the man is gone. Pip is haunted by the man and the file, fearing his connection to the convicts.

**Chapter XI.**
Pip returns to Miss Havisham's, where Estella leads him to a different part of the house, a gloomy room with other relatives (Camilla, Sarah Pocket, Cousin Raymond) who are all "toadies and humbugs." They discuss a relative, Matthew, who lacks "sense of the proprieties." Estella slaps Pip's face on their way to Miss Havisham's room. They encounter a burly gentleman on the stairs who warns Pip to behave. Miss Havisham, unchanged, sets Pip to the task of pushing her in a wheeled chair around her rooms. The relatives make insincere remarks. Miss Havisham reveals it is her birthday and that the decayed bride-cake was brought on this day, stating that when she dies and is laid on the table, it will be "the finished curse upon him." Estella and Pip play cards. Later, in the garden, Pip fights and defeats a "pale young gentleman." Estella, with a "bright flush," allows Pip to kiss her cheek, but he feels it is given contemptuously. Pip returns home late, feeling his commonness.

**Chapter XII.**
Pip is anxious about the fight and fears punishment. He continues his visits to Miss Havisham, pushing her chair. She asks about his future, and he tells her he will be apprenticed to Joe. Miss Havisham prefers his ignorance and gives him no money beyond a guinea on his birthday, which becomes an annual custom. Estella is always present, sometimes cold, sometimes familiar, sometimes hateful. Miss Havisham delights in Estella's growing beauty and encourages her to "break their hearts." Pip confides everything to Biddy. At home, Pumblechook and Mrs. Joe continue to speculate about Pip's prospects. Miss Havisham eventually tells Pip he should be apprenticed at once and asks Joe to bring his indentures. Mrs. Joe reacts with a violent "Rampage."

**Chapter XIII.**
Joe, dressed in his uncomfortable Sunday clothes, accompanies Pip to Miss Havisham's. Mrs. Joe insists on going to town with them. At Miss Havisham's, Joe, flustered, addresses Pip instead of Miss Havisham throughout the interview. Miss Havisham asks if Joe expects a premium for Pip's apprenticeship, and Joe, through Pip, says no. Miss Havisham gives Pip twenty-five guineas for Joe, which Joe, still addressing Pip, accepts with gratitude. Miss Havisham tells Joe that Pip's good behavior is his reward, and he should expect no more. Joe, bewildered, is led out by Pip. At Pumblechook's, Joe, with a "subtle design," tells Mrs. Joe that Miss Havisham sent her compliments and gave the money to "his friends" (Mrs. Joe), not Pip. Pumblechook and Mrs. Joe are delighted, believing Pumblechook is the benefactor. Pip is formally bound apprentice to Joe at the Town Hall. They celebrate at the Blue Boar, where Pumblechook takes credit and lectures Pip. Pip feels wretched and realizes he will never like Joe's trade.

**Chapter XIV.**
Pip feels ashamed of his home and his trade, seeing them as "coarse and common," and wishes Miss Havisham and Estella would never see them. He feels the burden of his apprenticeship but never complains to Joe, who remains faithful. Pip is haunted by the fear of Estella seeing him as a common blacksmith.

**Chapter XV.**
Pip's formal schooling ends. He tries to teach Joe, hoping to make him less common for Estella's sake, but Joe learns nothing. Pip suggests visiting Miss Havisham, but Joe reminds him she said her premium was "all." Pip insists on showing gratitude. Orlick, Joe's journeyman, demands a half-holiday if Pip gets one, leading to a quarrel with Mrs. Joe and a fight between Joe and Orlick, which Joe wins. Mrs. Joe collapses and is carried into the house. Pip visits Miss Havisham, receives his annual guinea, and is told to return next birthday. Pip notices Biddy's self-improvement and realizes he has been ungrateful. On a walk, Pip confesses to Biddy his desire to be a gentleman because of Estella's contempt. Biddy questions his motives and advises him against it, but comforts him. They encounter Orlick, whom Biddy fears. Pip's mind is conflicted between Biddy and Estella. Pip's apprenticeship is prematurely ended.

**Chapter XVIII.**
In his fourth year of apprenticeship, Pip is at the Three Jolly Bargemen when Mr. Wopsle reads a newspaper account of a murder. A "strange gentleman" (Mr. Jaggers), whom Pip recognizes as the man he met on the stairs at Miss Havisham's, challenges Wopsle's legal opinions. Jaggers reveals he is looking for Joe Gargery and Pip. Jaggers requests a private conference at their home. There, Jaggers, a London lawyer, informs Joe that Pip has "great expectations" and must be removed from his current life to be brought up as a gentleman. He states Pip must always be called Pip, and the benefactor's identity will remain a secret, with Pip forbidden to inquire. Jaggers will be Pip's guardian and provides him with money for education and new clothes. Joe, deeply moved, refuses any compensation for losing Pip, stating no money can replace "the little child." Jaggers then offers Joe a "present," but Joe, enraged by Jaggers's manner, tells him to "come out!" if he's going to "bull-bait" him. Jaggers, after delivering his final instructions, leaves. Joe, bewildered, repeatedly says "Astonishing!" At Pumblechook's, Joe, following a subtle plan, tells Mrs. Joe that Miss Havisham sent her compliments and gave the money to Mrs. Joe, not Pip. Pumblechook and Mrs. Joe are delighted, believing Pumblechook is Pip's benefactor. Pip is formally bound apprentice to Joe at the Town Hall. Pip feels wretched and realizes he will never like Joe's trade, feeling ashamed of his home and Joe.

**Chapter XIX.**
Pip's outlook brightens with his new prospects. Joe burns Pip's indentures, freeing him. Pip feels a "sublime compassion" for the villagers and plans to help them. He reflects on his past with the convict, believing him "dead to me." Pip goes to the old Battery and falls asleep, wondering if Miss Havisham intends him for Estella. He wakes to find Joe beside him, who says he "thought I’d foller" for the last time. Pip assures Joe he will never forget him. Pip, wishing Joe were "better qualified for a rise in station," asks Biddy to help Joe "on, a little" in his learning and manners. Biddy asks if Joe isn't "proud" and if he doesn't know his manners are fine as they are. Pip, provoked, accuses Biddy of envy. Biddy calmly states her loyalty and that a gentleman should not be unjust. Pip, feeling remorse, walks away. The next morning, Pip orders fashionable clothes from Mr. Trabb, who becomes deferential. Trabb's boy, however, expresses disdain for Pip's new status. Pumblechook fawns on Pip, claiming credit for his fortune. Pip visits Miss Havisham, who gloats over Sarah Pocket's jealousy. Pip kisses Miss Havisham's hand. On his last evening at home, Pip dresses in his new clothes for Joe and Biddy, but everyone is sad. Pip plans to leave alone, fearing the contrast with Joe. He has a hurried breakfast, kisses his sister and Biddy, embraces Joe, and leaves. Joe and Biddy throw old shoes after him. At the village finger-post, Pip breaks into tears, feeling his ingratitude. He travels to London.

**Chapter XX.**
Pip arrives in London, finding it immense and dirty. He goes to Mr. Jaggers's office in Little Britain. Jaggers is in court, so Pip waits in his dismal office, observing strange objects and two ghastly casts of faces. He takes a walk in Smithfield, a filthy place, and sees Newgate Prison. He encounters a minister of justice who offers to show him trials and the gallows. Pip then observes people waiting for Jaggers, including two "secret men," crying women, and an excitable Jew. Jaggers arrives, dismisses his followers, and then speaks to a client, Mike, about a witness. Jaggers is disgusted by the witness. Jaggers then informs Pip of his arrangements: he is to stay at Barnard's Inn with young Mr. Pocket (the pale young gentleman from the fight). He will receive a liberal allowance. Jaggers suggests Wemmick, his clerk, walk Pip there. Wemmick, a dry man with a mechanical smile, describes London as a wicked place. They arrive at Barnard's Inn, which Pip finds shabby and dismal. Mr. Pocket, Junior, arrives, and they recognize each other as the combatants from Miss Havisham's garden.

**Chapter XXI.**
Pip and Herbert Pocket (the pale young gentleman) laugh at their past encounter. Herbert apologizes for the fight. Herbert explains Miss Havisham had considered him as a potential suitor for Estella but rejected him. He reveals Estella is adopted and raised by Miss Havisham to "wreak revenge on all the male sex." Herbert promises to tell Pip the full story. Pip confirms Jaggers is his guardian and Miss Havisham's solicitor. Herbert explains his father is Miss Havisham's cousin. Pip finds Herbert frank and kind, but unlikely to be successful. Pip tells Herbert his story and asks for guidance on manners. Herbert suggests Pip call him "Handel" and offers advice on table etiquette. Herbert then recounts Miss Havisham's story: she was a spoiled heiress who fell in love with a "showy man" (Compeyson) who was not a gentleman. Compeyson extracted money from her and then abandoned her on their wedding day, at twenty minutes to nine, the time all the clocks in Satis House stopped. Miss Havisham, after an illness, laid the house waste. Herbert adds that Compeyson and Miss Havisham's half-brother, Arthur, were suspected of conspiring to defraud her. Pip wonders why Compeyson didn't marry her. Herbert says he may have been married already. Herbert describes his own grand but currently unprofitable financial aspirations. Pip feels a sense of reproach for having left Joe and his home. They visit Mr. Pocket's house in Hammersmith, where Pip observes the chaotic upbringing of the six "tumbling up" Pocket children, overseen by two nurses, Flopson and Millers, and their oblivious mother, Mrs. Pocket, who is obsessed with titles. Mr. Pocket is a perplexed but kind gentleman.

**Chapter XXII.**
Pip and Herbert, now friends, recount their first fight. Herbert explains Miss Havisham had considered him as a suitor for Estella, but he was rejected. He reveals Estella is adopted and raised by Miss Havisham to take revenge on men. Herbert promises to tell Pip the full story of Miss Havisham's past. Pip confirms Jaggers is his guardian and Miss Havisham's man of business. Herbert explains his father, Matthew Pocket, is Miss Havisham's cousin, but not in her favor. Pip finds Herbert amiable but not destined for great wealth. Pip tells Herbert his story, emphasizing the secrecy of his benefactor, and asks for advice on polite society. Herbert suggests Pip call him "Handel" (after "The Harmonious Blacksmith"). Herbert then recounts Miss Havisham's history: she was a spoiled heiress whose father was a wealthy brewer. She had a half-brother, Arthur. She fell in love with a "showy man" (Compeyson) who defrauded her and abandoned her on their wedding day, at twenty minutes to nine, the time all the clocks in Satis House stopped. Her half-brother was suspected of conspiring with Compeyson. Pip, though impressed by Herbert's grand financial plans, feels Herbert will not be successful. Pip feels a sense of guilt for leaving Joe and his home. They visit Mr. Pocket's house in Hammersmith, where Pip observes the chaotic household and Mrs. Pocket's obliviousness. Pip is introduced to Drummle and Startop, other students of Mr. Pocket. Pip resolves to learn rowing to compete with Drummle. He also observes a drunken cook and Mrs. Pocket's absurd reactions.

**Chapter XXIII.**
Mr. Pocket welcomes Pip. Mrs. Pocket, raised to marry a title, is helpless in domestic matters. Mr. Pocket, a kind but perplexed man, is a "Grinder" (tutor) to young gentlemen. Pip is introduced to Drummle and Startop, other students. Drummle is sulky and proud, Startop is delicate and kind. The servants run the household. Mrs. Coiler, a toady neighbor, flatters Pip and expresses pity for Mrs. Pocket. Pip learns Drummle is an heir to a baronetcy. The cook mislays the beef, causing Mr. Pocket to despair. Mrs. Coiler flatters Pip. The children are brought in; Mrs. Pocket is oblivious to the baby's danger with nutcrackers. Mr. Pocket despairs over the children's neglect. Pip decides to take up rowing. The cook is found drunk. Mrs. Pocket blames the housemaid.

**Chapter XXIV.**
Pip settles into his room and frequently travels to London. Mr. Pocket informs Pip that Jaggers intends for him to be educated to "hold his own" as a gentleman. Mr. Pocket becomes Pip's tutor. Pip decides to keep his room in Barnard's Inn. He asks Jaggers for money to buy furniture. Jaggers, in his bullying manner, gives Pip twenty pounds. Wemmick, Jaggers's clerk, explains Jaggers's professional detachment and shows Pip the office, including casts of executed clients. Wemmick reveals his "portable property" philosophy. Wemmick invites Pip to his home in Walworth, the "Castle," and tells him to observe Jaggers's housekeeper, Molly, calling her a "wild beast tamed." Pip witnesses Jaggers's intimidating presence in a police court.

**Chapter XXV.**
Drummle and Startop are described. Herbert becomes Pip's intimate friend. Pip's relatives (Camilla, Georgiana) visit, fawning on him. Pip contracts expensive habits and debts, and Herbert follows. They join "The Finches of the Grove," an expensive club. Herbert, despite his financial struggles, remains hopeful. Pip receives a letter informing him of Mrs. Joe's death.

**Chapter XXXV.**
Pip is deeply affected by Mrs. Joe's death, feeling remorse and indignation towards her assailant. He writes to Joe, promising to attend the funeral. At his hometown, Pumblechook, still claiming to be Pip's benefactor, expresses false sympathy for Pip's "fall in fortune." Joe, in his mourning clothes, is deeply saddened. Biddy is helpful and modest. Pip notices Pumblechook's hypocrisy. The funeral procession, orchestrated by Trabb, is ostentatious. Mrs. Joe is buried near Pip's parents. Pumblechook continues to make self-serving remarks. Pip, Joe, and Biddy have a quiet dinner. Pip asks Biddy if she knows what became of Orlick, and she reveals she saw him near the lane the night Mrs. Joe died, and again since. Pip vows to drive Orlick out of the country. Biddy gently reminds Pip of Joe's unwavering love and duty. Pip, feeling remorse, asks Biddy why she seems distant. Biddy reveals she is leaving to be mistress of the new school and will help care for Joe. She also reveals that Orlick attacked Mrs. Joe, using the filed-off leg iron, and is now in jail. Pip is horrified. Pip leaves Joe and Biddy, feeling his ingratitude and the mists rising, as if to confirm he will not return.

**Chapter XXXVI.**
Pip turns twenty-one, and Jaggers gives him a five hundred pound bank-note and an annual allowance, but refuses to reveal the benefactor's identity, reiterating the secrecy. Pip infers that Miss Havisham has not taken Jaggers into her confidence about Estella. Pip asks Wemmick for advice on helping Herbert financially. Wemmick, in his "office" persona, advises against it, but in his "Walworth" persona, agrees to help. Pip visits Wemmick's "Castle" in Walworth, a whimsical home with a drawbridge and cannon, where Wemmick lives with his deaf "Aged Parent." Wemmick, with Miss Skiffins (his future wife), helps Pip arrange a secret partnership for Herbert with a merchant named Clarriker, using Pip's money. Herbert is overjoyed, unaware of Pip's involvement.

**Chapter XXXVII.**
Pip continues to be tormented by Estella, who uses him to tease other admirers. Estella tells Pip she is going to live with Mrs. Brandley in Richmond and that Pip is to take her to Satis House for a day. Pip realizes Estella is Miss Havisham's instrument of revenge against men. During a visit to Satis House, Estella and Miss Havisham have a heated argument. Estella declares she is "what you have made me" and has "no heart." Miss Havisham, distraught, cries, "What have I done!" Pip asks Miss Havisham about Estella's parentage. Miss Havisham reveals Jaggers brought Estella to her as an orphan child when she was two or three. Pip realizes Molly, Jaggers's housekeeper, is Estella's mother. Miss Havisham, in a fit of passion, accidentally sets herself on fire. Pip heroically saves her, suffering severe burns to his hands and arm. Miss Havisham, in her delirium, repeatedly cries, "What have I done!" and "Take the pencil and write under my name, ‘I forgive her.’" Pip decides to return to London.

**Chapter XXXVIII.**
Pip is tormented by Estella's presence, who uses him to tease other admirers. He loves her despite her cruelty. Estella tells Pip she is going to live in Richmond and that he is to take her to Satis House. Pip realizes Estella is Miss Havisham's instrument of revenge. During a visit, Estella and Miss Havisham argue. Estella declares she is "what you have made me" and has "no heart." Miss Havisham, distraught, cries, "What have I done!" Pip asks Miss Havisham about Estella's parentage. Miss Havisham reveals Jaggers brought Estella to her as an orphan child. Pip realizes Molly, Jaggers's housekeeper, is Estella's mother. Miss Havisham accidentally sets herself on fire. Pip saves her, suffering severe burns. In her delirium, Miss Havisham repeatedly cries, "What have I done!" and "Take the pencil and write under my name, ‘I forgive her.’" Pip returns to London.

**Chapter XXXIX.**
Pip, now twenty-three, lives in the Temple. Herbert is on a business trip. On a stormy night, Pip hears a footstep on the stairs. He finds a strange, muscular, weather-beaten man, about sixty, with long iron-grey hair, holding out both hands to him. Pip recognizes him as his convict from the marshes. The man, who calls himself Provis, reveals he is Pip's benefactor. He boasts of making Pip a gentleman with his earnings from sheep-farming in the "new world" (New South Wales), where he was sent for life. He explains he risked his life by returning to England, where it is a felony punishable by death. Pip is horrified and repulsed by the man he now knows as Magwitch. Magwitch takes out a thick pocket-book, full of papers, and tells Pip it's all his. Pip, stunned, struggles to comprehend his situation. He learns Magwitch was tried in London and that Jaggers defended him. Magwitch reveals he was the man who was "low" and that he is here "for good." Pip, in a frenzy of fear and dislike, asks how Magwitch can be kept safe. Magwitch, after some resistance, agrees to Pip's plan to keep him hidden. He produces a small black Testament and makes Herbert swear an oath of secrecy. Pip is horrified to realize that his "great expectations" come from a convict.

**Chapter XL.**
Pip realizes he cannot keep Magwitch concealed in his chambers due to the nosy old female and her niece who look after the rooms. He decides to announce that his uncle has unexpectedly come from the country. While groping for a light, he stumbles over a man crouching in a corner of the staircase. The man eludes him. The watchman confirms a stranger asked for Pip earlier. Pip is troubled by the lurker and the possibility that Magwitch brought someone with him. Pip lights a fire and dozes, then wakes to daylight. He struggles to process his situation. Magwitch emerges from Herbert's room. Pip learns his real name is Abel Magwitch, and he was christened Abel. Magwitch admits he was a "warmint" (criminal) from birth. He confirms he was tried in London and Jaggers defended him. He eats ravenously and uncouthly. He insists Pip must have horses and live like a gentleman. He shows Pip his overflowing pocket-book, declaring it all Pip's. Pip, in a frenzy, demands to know what precautions can be taken. Magwitch insists he is not "low" anymore. He reveals the danger is "Death" by hanging if he is caught. Pip suggests quiet lodging nearby and confiding in Herbert. Magwitch agrees to the lodging but insists on seeing Herbert first to judge his physiognomy and make him swear on his black Testament. Pip is horrified by Magwitch's past and his presence. He almost decides to abandon Magwitch and enlist for India, but the thought of Herbert's return stops him. Herbert returns, and Pip, after a moment of panic from Magwitch, tells Herbert the whole secret. Magwitch makes Herbert swear on the Testament.

**Chapter XLI.**
Herbert is astonished and dismayed by Magwitch's revelation. Magwitch, oblivious to their repulsion, boasts of making Pip a gentleman. Pip and Herbert are anxious for Magwitch to leave. Pip takes Magwitch to his lodging in Essex Street. Herbert and Pip then discuss what to do. Pip is convinced he cannot accept any more money from Magwitch and feels he is "fit for nothing" but to be a soldier. Herbert dissuades him, suggesting soldiering won't help repay Magwitch. Herbert points out the danger: if Pip renounces Magwitch, Magwitch might recklessly expose himself to capture, as his fixed idea is to see Pip thrive. Pip is horrified by the thought of being Magwitch's "murderer." They agree the main thing is to get Magwitch out of England. Pip realizes he knows nothing of Magwitch's life. Herbert suggests Pip ask Magwitch for his story. They go to bed. The next morning, Magwitch, full of plans for Pip, tells his life story: "In jail and out of jail, in jail and out of jail, in jail and out of jail." He was an orphan, a "ragged little creetur," who became hardened. He met Compeyson, a gentlemanly swindler, at Epsom races twenty years ago. Compeyson made Magwitch his "pardner" in forging and passing stolen notes, but exploited him. Magwitch also reveals Compeyson was involved with a "rich lady" (Miss Havisham) and her half-brother, Arthur, who died with "the horrors" of seeing a woman in white. Magwitch describes their trial, where Compeyson, due to his gentlemanly appearance and Jaggers's defense, received a lighter sentence (seven years) than Magwitch (fourteen years). Magwitch swore to smash Compeyson's face. He escaped the prison-ship, found Compeyson on the marshes, fought him, and dragged him back, leading to their recapture. Magwitch was then sent for life. Herbert shows Pip a note confirming Arthur was Miss Havisham's half-brother and Compeyson was her lover.

**Chapter XLII.**
Magwitch recounts his life: "In jail and out of jail." He was an orphan, a "warmint," who became hardened and was constantly "took up." He met Compeyson, a gentlemanly swindler, at Epsom races. Compeyson exploited him in a scheme of forgery and stolen notes. Magwitch also reveals Compeyson was involved with a "rich lady" (Miss Havisham) and her half-brother, Arthur, who died with "the horrors" of seeing a woman in white. Magwitch describes their trial, where Compeyson, due to his gentlemanly appearance and Jaggers's defense, received a lighter sentence (seven years) than Magwitch (fourteen years). Magwitch swore to smash Compeyson's face. He escaped the prison-ship, found Compeyson on the marshes, fought him, and dragged him back, leading to their recapture. Magwitch was then sent for life. Herbert shows Pip a note confirming Arthur was Miss Havisham's half-brother and Compeyson was her lover.

**Chapter XLIII.**
Pip is tormented by the contrast between Estella and Magwitch. He resolves never to speak of Estella to Magwitch. Pip decides he must see Estella and Miss Havisham before going abroad. He goes to Richmond, but Estella has gone to Satis House. Pip returns to London. Herbert and Pip decide not to mention going abroad until Pip returns from Satis House. Pip, feigning an obligation to Joe, leaves Magwitch in Herbert's care. He plans to get Magwitch away by water, under the pretense of making purchases. Pip travels to his hometown by coach. At the Blue Boar, he encounters Bentley Drummle, who is also there. They exchange hostile words, each trying to assert dominance. Drummle reveals he is there to see "the lady" and implies a connection to Estella. Pip is enraged but cannot act. Drummle leaves to ride to the marshes. Pip, deeply disturbed, goes to Satis House.

**Chapter XLIV.**
Pip finds Miss Havisham and Estella in the dressing-room. Pip perceives that Estella knows he has discovered his benefactor. Pip tells Miss Havisham he has found out who his patron is, and it is not a fortunate discovery. He states he is as unhappy as she could have meant him to be. He reminds her that when he first came, he was a "chance boy" hired to "gratify a want or a whim." Miss Havisham confirms this. Pip then tells her that Jaggers had nothing to do with it. Pip accuses Miss Havisham of leading him on in his mistake, punishing her "self-seeking relations." He defends Matthew and Herbert Pocket, stating they are generous and upright, unlike the other relations. Pip asks Miss Havisham to provide money to help Herbert secretly establish a partnership, explaining it must be done without Herbert's knowledge. Miss Havisham agrees to give him nine hundred pounds for this purpose. She asks Pip to write "I forgive her" under her name on her ivory tablets after her death. Pip, deeply moved, says he can forgive her now. Miss Havisham drops to her knees, weeping, crying, "What have I done!" Pip comforts her, confirming Estella is married. Miss Havisham confesses she "stole her heart away, and put ice in its place." Pip asks about Estella's parentage. Miss Havisham says she doesn't know who Estella's father is, but Jaggers brought her the two or three-year-old orphan child. Pip is convinced Molly is Estella's mother. Pip leaves, feeling a presentiment he will never return. In the brewery, he has a momentary illusion of Miss Havisham hanging from a beam. He returns to her room and sees her engulfed in fire. Pip heroically saves her, suffering severe burns to his hands and arm. Miss Havisham is seriously hurt and delirious, repeatedly crying, "What have I done!" and "Take the pencil and write under my name, ‘I forgive her.’" Pip decides to return to London.

**Chapter L.**
Pip's hands and arm are severely burnt. Herbert nurses him. Herbert tells Pip that Magwitch (Provis) has been very communicative and revealed more of his past. He explains that the jealous woman Magwitch had trouble with was Molly, who murdered another woman by strangulation. Jaggers defended Molly, and she was acquitted. Molly and Magwitch had a child, whom Molly swore to destroy and make Magwitch never see again, on the night of the murder. Magwitch, fearing he would be forced to testify against Molly and cause her death, hid himself. Compeyson, knowing this, used it to control Magwitch. Herbert reveals that this happened about twenty years ago, and the child would have been about Pip's age when he first met Magwitch. Pip, in a moment of shocking realization, understands that Molly is Estella's mother, and Magwitch is Estella's father.

**Chapter LI.**
Pip is determined to confirm Estella's parentage with Jaggers. He goes to Jaggers's office, his bandaged arm aiding his purpose. He gives Jaggers Miss Havisham's authority for the £900 for Herbert. Pip then reveals he knows Estella's mother and father. Jaggers is startled when Pip names Magwitch as Estella's father. Pip explains Magwitch makes no claim and has no knowledge of Estella's existence. Jaggers, after a moment of surprise, listens to Pip's full account, carefully avoiding any direct admissions himself. Pip makes a passionate appeal to Jaggers to be more frank, reminding him of his love for Estella. Jaggers, softening slightly, then presents a hypothetical case that mirrors Molly's and Magwitch's story: a woman (Molly) conceals her child (Estella) from the father (Magwitch) and gives it to her legal adviser (Jaggers), who then places the child with an eccentric rich lady (Miss Havisham) to be raised. Jaggers explains his motives were to save one child from a life of crime and to control the mother. He then argues that revealing the secret now would harm all involved, especially Estella. Pip, Jaggers, and Wemmick (who is present) all agree to keep the secret. Pip then asks Wemmick for advice on helping Herbert financially. Wemmick, in his "office" persona, advises against it, but Pip, remembering his "Walworth" persona, resolves to ask him at Walworth. Pip leaves, still troubled by the prison taint, and sees Estella waving from a coach window.

**Chapter LII.**
Pip finalizes the arrangement for Herbert's partnership with Clarriker, paying the money. Herbert is to go to the East to manage a branch-house. Pip receives a coded note from Wemmick, instructing him to prepare for Magwitch's escape. Herbert suggests Startop help them, as Pip's arm is injured. They plan to take Magwitch downriver by ebb-tide, hide, and then hail a foreign steamer. Pip receives a dirty, anonymous letter, warning him to come alone to the sluice-house by the limekiln on the marshes tonight for information about "your uncle Provis." Pip, despite his fears, decides to go. He leaves a note for Herbert, feigning a visit to Miss Havisham. At his hometown, Pip encounters Drummle at the Blue Boar, who is there for Estella. They have a tense exchange. Pip goes to the sluice-house, finds it empty, and is suddenly caught in a noose from behind. His assailant is Orlick, who ties him to a ladder. Orlick reveals he lured Pip there for revenge, blaming Pip for costing him his job and for giving him a "bad name" to Biddy. Orlick confesses to attacking Mrs. Joe with the filed leg-iron, saying Pip was "favoured" while he was "bullied and beat." He also reveals he was the lurker on Pip's stairs. Orlick, now working for "new companions" who are "a match for your uncle Provis," threatens to kill Pip and dispose of his body in the limekiln, warning him of "Compeyson, Magwitch, and the gallows!" Pip is saved by the timely arrival of Herbert and Startop, who, guided by Trabb's Boy, had followed Pip after finding his anonymous letter. They subdue Orlick, who escapes. Pip, Herbert, and Startop return to London, Pip's arm still throbbing. Pip rests, then feels strong and well on Wednesday morning, ready for the escape.

**Chapter LIV.**
On a cold March day, Pip, Herbert, and Startop set off in Pip's boat from the Temple stairs. Herbert and Startop row, Pip steers. Their plan is to go downriver with the ebb tide, hide below Gravesend, and then hail a foreign steamer on Thursday morning. Pip feels relief at finally executing the plan. They pass Old London Bridge and the shipping. At Mill Pond Bank, they pick up Magwitch, who is disguised as a river-pilot. Magwitch expresses his joy at seeing Pip. He is the least anxious of the group, hoping to see Pip become a gentleman abroad. Magwitch reflects on his past and the value of freedom. They continue downriver, passing the Custom House. As night falls, they feel they are being followed. They find a lonely public-house and decide to stay there. The "Jack" of the causeway mentions a "four-oared galley" that might be Custom House officers, making them uneasy. Pip sees two men looking at their boat from his window. The next morning, Pip and Magwitch walk to a distant point, where the boat picks them up. As they row into the steamer's track, a four-oared galley shoots out from the bank and pulls alongside them. The man holding the lines identifies Magwitch as Abel Magwitch, a "returned Transport," and apprehends him. The galley runs abroad of their boat, causing confusion. Magwitch starts up, leans across his captor, and pulls the cloak from the shrinking sitter in the galley, revealing the face of Compeyson. Compeyson's face fills with "white terror," a cry is heard, and a loud splash. Their boat sinks, and the two convicts are gone. Pip is taken aboard the galley. Magwitch is found swimming, manacled, and taken aboard. Compeyson is not found. Magwitch has a severe chest injury and a deep cut on his head. He tells Pip he believes he went under the steamer's keel and fought Compeyson underwater. The officer confirms their going overboard. The officer takes charge of Magwitch's possessions, including the pocket-book. Pip is allowed to accompany Magwitch to London, but Herbert and Startop must go by land. Pip's repugnance to Magwitch has melted away; he now sees a benefactor. Magwitch's breathing is painful. Pip realizes Magwitch's possessions will be forfeited to the Crown. Magwitch asks Pip to visit him "by chance alonger Wemmick" and promises to be true to him. Pip realizes Magwitch need never know his hopes of enriching Pip have perished.

**Chapter LV.**
Magwitch is taken to the Police Court. His trial is delayed for an officer from his prison-ship to identify him. Compeyson, who would have testified, is dead. Pip retains Jaggers's assistance, who, on Magwitch's behalf, admits nothing. Pip tells Jaggers his plan to keep Magwitch ignorant of his forfeited wealth. Jaggers is querulous but confirms the forfeiture is inevitable. Compeyson's body is found, and notes in his pockets reveal Magwitch's banking house and lands, confirming Magwitch's ignorance of his lost fortune. Magwitch is committed for trial in a month. Herbert informs Pip he must leave for Cairo for a business opportunity. Pip, lonely, asks Herbert to keep the offer open for a few months. Herbert agrees and says he will leave at the end of the week, and that Clara's father, Mr. Barley, is dying. Pip takes leave of Herbert. Wemmick explains that Compeyson knew of Magwitch's return and was determined to bring him to justice, making Magwitch's capture inevitable. Wemmick invites Pip to his wedding. On Monday, Pip attends Wemmick's wedding to Miss Skiffins at a church in Camberwell Green. The Aged Parent is present. The wedding is unconventional and humorous. Pip drinks to the new couple and the Aged. Wemmick, in his Walworth persona, tells Pip that Jaggers must not know about his private life.

**Chapter LVI.**
Magwitch is very ill in prison. Pip visits him daily, reading to him and listening. Magwitch wastes away, showing submission and contrition. Jaggers's application to postpone the trial is refused. Magwitch is tried, found guilty of returning from transportation, and sentenced to death along with thirty-one other prisoners. Magwitch, barely able to speak, says, "My Lord, I have received my sentence of Death from the Almighty, but I bow to yours." Pip earnestly hopes Magwitch will die before his execution. He writes petitions to the Home Secretary and the Crown. Pip's daily visits are shortened. Magwitch's health declines rapidly. After ten days, Magwitch, with a last effort, thanks Pip for never deserting him. Pip, holding Magwitch's hand, tells him, "You had a child once, whom you loved and lost... She lived, and found powerful friends. She is living now. She is a lady and very beautiful. And I love her!" Magwitch raises Pip's hand to his lips, then gently lets it sink. His head drops, and he dies. Pip prays, "O Lord, be merciful to him a sinner!"

**Chapter LVII.**
Pip, now deeply in debt and very ill, gives notice to quit his chambers. He suffers from fever and hallucinations, often confusing real people with Joe. He is arrested for debt. Joe arrives and nurses Pip back to health, having been called by Biddy. Pip is overcome with remorse and gratitude for Joe's unwavering kindness. Pip learns that Miss Havisham died about a week after his illness, leaving most of her property to Estella, but £4,000 to Mr. Matthew Pocket due to Pip's account of him. Other relatives received small legacies. Joe also tells Pip that Orlick has been arrested for breaking into Pumblechook's house and is in jail. Pip slowly recovers, feeling like "little Pip again" in Joe's care. As Pip regains strength, Joe becomes a little less easy with him, calling him "sir" again, which Pip realizes is Joe's way of acknowledging their changed stations and preparing for Pip's departure. Pip resolves to tell Joe everything on Monday. On Monday morning, Pip finds a letter from Joe, stating he has "departured" because Pip is well and will do better without him. Enclosed is a receipt for Pip's debt, which Joe has paid. Pip resolves to follow Joe to the forge, confess his failings, and ask Biddy to marry him or to help him find a new occupation abroad.

**Chapter LVIII.**
News of Pip's financial ruin has reached his hometown. The Blue Boar is cold towards him. At breakfast, Pumblechook expresses false sympathy for Pip's "brought low" state and continues to claim credit for his past fortunes, telling the landlord and waiter that Pip is ungrateful and that Providence caused his downfall. Pip, disgusted, leaves and walks towards Joe and Biddy, feeling relief as he leaves arrogance and untruthfulness behind. He finds the schoolhouse closed and the forge closed. He sees Joe and Biddy, arm in arm, in the best parlour. Biddy announces, "It’s my wedding-day!... and I am married to Joe!" Pip is thankful he never confessed his hope of marrying Biddy to Joe. He expresses his love and gratitude to them both, confessing his ill repayment. He announces he is going abroad and will work to repay Joe's debt. He asks them to forgive him and to tell their future child that he honored them. Joe and Biddy forgive him. Pip goes to his old room, then eats and drinks with them, and they walk him to the finger-post. Pip sells his possessions, pays his creditors, and leaves England to join Herbert. He becomes a clerk at Clarriker and Co., and later a partner. Herbert marries Clara. Years later, Clarriker reveals Pip's secret financial help to Herbert, who is moved and amazed. Pip realizes his old idea of Herbert's inaptitude was actually his own.

**Chapter LIX.**
Eleven years later, Pip returns to his native place. He finds Joe, hale and strong, by the kitchen fire, with a child named Pip sitting on Pip's old stool. Joe reveals they named the child Pip for his sake, hoping he would be like him. Pip takes the child to the churchyard, where the child points out the tombstones of Philip Pirrip and Georgiana. Pip talks with Biddy, who has a little girl. Pip suggests Biddy give or lend him the child Pip. Biddy gently tells him he "must marry." Pip says he doesn't think he will marry, as he is settled with Herbert and Clara. Biddy asks if he "don’t fret for her" (Estella). Pip replies that his "poor dream... has all gone by." Pip secretly intends to revisit the site of the old house that evening for Estella's sake. He had heard she led an unhappy life, was separated from her cruel husband (Drummle), who died two years prior. Pip walks to the ruined garden, now enclosed by a fence. He sees a solitary figure, which he recognizes as Estella. She says she is "greatly changed" and wonders he knows her. Her beauty's freshness is gone, but her majesty and charm remain, with a "saddened, softened light" in her eyes and a "friendly touch" in her hand. They sit on a bench. Estella says she has never been back. She reveals the garden ground is her only possession she has not relinquished, the subject of her "only determined resistance." She says it is finally "to be built on" and she came to take leave of it. She asks if Pip still lives abroad and does well. She says she has often thought of him and has given the remembrance of what she "had thrown away" a place in her heart. Pip replies she has always held her place in his heart. Estella says she is glad to take leave of him. Pip says parting is painful. Estella reminds him of his past words, "God bless you, God forgive you!" and says suffering has taught her to understand his heart. She hopes she is "bent and broken, but—I hope—into a better shape." She asks him to say they are friends. Pip says, "We are friends," and they rise. Estella says, "And will continue friends apart." Pip takes her hand, and they leave the ruined place. As the evening mists rise, Pip sees "no shadow of another parting from her."
