summary_llm:
This detailed summary is based solely on the provided text, without external knowledge or interpretation.

**ACT I**

**SCENE I: Elsinore. A platform before the castle. Night.**
The play opens with Francisco on guard duty at Elsinore Castle. Bernardo arrives to relieve him. Francisco, feeling "sick at heart" and cold, departs. Bernardo is soon joined by Horatio and Marcellus. Horatio is skeptical about a "dreaded sight" that Bernardo and Marcellus claim to have seen twice before. They have brought Horatio to witness it. As Bernardo begins to recount the previous sightings, the Ghost appears, looking exactly like the recently deceased King of Denmark. Horatio is filled with fear and wonder. He attempts to speak to the Ghost, charging it to reveal its purpose, but it silently stalks away. Horatio, now convinced, notes the Ghost wore the same armor as the late King when he fought Norway, and believes its appearance "bodes some strange eruption to our state." The Ghost reappears. Horatio confronts it again, asking if it has a voice, if it knows of any good deed that can be done, if it is "privy to thy country's fate," or if it has "uphoarded... extorted treasure." The Ghost is about to speak when a cock crows, and it "started like a guilty thing" and vanishes. Horatio explains that spirits retreat at the cock's crow. He suggests they inform young Hamlet about the apparition, believing the spirit, though dumb to them, will speak to him. They agree to impart what they have seen.

**SCENE II: A room of state in the palace.**
Trumpets announce the entrance of King Claudius, Queen Gertrude, Polonius, Hamlet, Laertes, and attendants. The King addresses the court, acknowledging the recent death of his brother, King Hamlet, but stating that discretion has tempered their grief, allowing him to marry his "sometime sister, now our queen." He thanks the court for their approval. Laertes then requests permission to return to France, having fulfilled his duty by attending the King's coronation. Polonius, Laertes's father, confirms his son's persistent request, and the King grants Laertes leave.
The King then turns to Hamlet, asking why he remains gloomy. Hamlet responds cryptically, "A little more than kin, and less than kind," and "I am too much i'the sun." The Queen urges Hamlet to stop mourning, reminding him that death is common. Hamlet asserts his grief is genuine and internal, far exceeding outward show. The King advises Hamlet to cease his "unmanly grief," calling it "impious stubbornness." He reminds Hamlet that he is "most immediate to our throne" and asks him to consider him as a father. The Queen pleads with Hamlet to stay in Denmark and not return to Wittenberg. Hamlet agrees to obey. The King expresses joy at Hamlet's compliance and orders cannons to fire in celebration.
After the court exits, Hamlet delivers a soliloquy, expressing profound despair and suicidal thoughts, lamenting that God has forbidden self-slaughter. He finds the world "weary, stale, flat, and unprofitable," an "unweeded garden." He bitterly recalls his father's death less than two months prior, comparing him to Hyperion, and his mother's hasty marriage to his uncle, Claudius, whom he compares to a satyr. He calls his mother "Frailty" and notes she married his uncle before her mourning shoes were old. He resolves to hold his tongue.
Horatio, Bernardo, and Marcellus enter. Hamlet greets Horatio, his fellow student. Horatio reveals he came for King Hamlet's funeral. Hamlet sarcastically remarks it was for his mother's wedding, noting the quick succession. Horatio then tells Hamlet that he, along with Marcellus and Bernardo, saw King Hamlet's ghost on the platform the previous night. Hamlet is shocked and questions them about the Ghost's appearance, noting its armor, pale face, and grizzled beard. He decides to join their watch that night, intending to speak to the apparition. He makes them swear to keep the sighting secret, even if he should "put an antick disposition on" (act strangely) in the future. Hamlet suspects "foul play" and believes "Foul deeds will rise... to men's eyes."

**SCENE III: A room in Polonius's house.**
Laertes prepares to depart for France. He warns his sister, Ophelia, about Hamlet's affections, dismissing them as a fleeting "fashion, and a toy in blood," not a lasting love. He explains that Hamlet, as a prince, cannot choose his own wife, as the "safety and the health of the whole state" depend on his decision. Laertes advises Ophelia to protect her honor and be wary of Hamlet's advances. Ophelia promises to remember his lesson but playfully warns him not to be a hypocrite, showing her the "thorny way to heaven" while he treads "the primrose path of dalliance."
Polonius enters and chides Laertes for his delay. He then gives Laertes a series of precepts for conduct, emphasizing self-reliance, careful selection of friends, caution in quarrels, attentive listening, reserved speech, appropriate dress, and avoiding borrowing or lending. His most important advice is, "To thine ownself be true; And it must follow, as the night the day, Thou canst not then be false to any man." Laertes bids farewell to Ophelia, reminding her of his words.
After Laertes leaves, Polonius immediately questions Ophelia about what Hamlet has said to her. Ophelia admits Hamlet has made "many tenders Of his affection." Polonius dismisses these as insincere and calls Ophelia a "green girl, Unsifted in such perilous circumstance." He forbids her from speaking or talking with Lord Hamlet from that time forth. Ophelia promises to obey.

**SCENE IV: The platform. Night.**
Hamlet, Horatio, and Marcellus are on watch. The air is bitterly cold. They hear trumpets and cannon fire, which Hamlet explains is the King celebrating with a "rouse" (drinking bout), a custom he finds dishonorable. The Ghost appears. Hamlet addresses it directly, calling it "Hamlet, King, father: Royal Dane," and demands to know why it has left its grave. He asks if it is a spirit of health or a damned goblin. The Ghost beckons Hamlet to follow it alone. Horatio and Marcellus warn Hamlet not to go, fearing it might lead him to madness or harm. Hamlet, undeterred, declares his life is worth nothing and his soul is immortal. He breaks free from his companions, threatening anyone who tries to stop him, and follows the Ghost.

**SCENE V: A more remote part of the platform. Night.**
The Ghost leads Hamlet to a secluded area. It tells Hamlet its hour is almost come and it must return to "sulphurous and tormenting flames" to "fast in fires" until its "foul crimes" are purged. The Ghost reveals it is King Hamlet's spirit and commands Hamlet to "Revenge his foul and most unnatural murder." It explains that the official story of his death, a serpent sting, is a lie. The "serpent that did sting thy father's life Now wears his crown"—Hamlet's uncle, Claudius.
The Ghost describes Claudius as an "incestuous, that adulterate beast" who, with "witchcraft of his wit," seduced Queen Gertrude, winning her to "shameful lust." The Ghost details the murder: Claudius stole upon him while he slept in his orchard in the afternoon, pouring "juice of cursed hebenon" into his ears. This poison swiftly coursed through his body, killing him instantly. King Hamlet died "Of life, of crown, of queen, at once despatch'd," without confession or last rites, sent to his account "With all my imperfections on my head."
The Ghost charges Hamlet to avenge him but warns Hamlet not to "Taint not thy mind, nor let thy soul contrive Against thy mother aught: leave her to Heaven," and to her own conscience. The Ghost fades with the approach of dawn, urging Hamlet to "remember me."
Hamlet, horrified, vows to erase all other thoughts and only remember the Ghost's commandment. Horatio and Marcellus return, finding Hamlet distraught. Hamlet refuses to tell them what the Ghost said, calling it "wonderful" but also "much offence." He makes them swear again, by his sword, never to reveal what they have seen, and also to swear that if he should "put an antick disposition on" (act strangely) in the future, they will not give any indication that they know why. The Ghost's voice from beneath the ground reinforces the oath. Hamlet laments, "The time is out of joint;--O cursèd spite, That ever I was born to set it right!"

**ACT II**

**SCENE I: A room in Polonius's house.**
Ophelia enters, frightened, and tells Polonius that Lord Hamlet came to her in a disheveled state: his doublet unbraced, pale, knees knocking, and with a piteous look. She describes Hamlet taking her wrist, holding her hard, then studying her face intently, sighing profoundly, and finally leaving without looking back, his eyes fixed on her until he was out of sight. Polonius concludes that Hamlet is "Mad for thy love." Ophelia confirms that, as Polonius commanded, she "did repel his letters, and denied His access to me." Polonius believes this rejection is what "hath made him mad" and decides they must inform the King.

**SCENE II: A room in the castle.**
The King and Queen welcome Rosencrantz and Guildenstern, Hamlet's childhood friends. They express concern over Hamlet's "transformation" and ask them to stay at court to cheer him up and discover the cause of his affliction. Rosencrantz and Guildenstern agree to obey.
Polonius enters, claiming he has found "The very cause of Hamlet's lunacy." After a verbose introduction, he states that Hamlet is mad due to "neglected love" for Ophelia. He reads a love letter from Hamlet to Ophelia. Polonius explains that he forbade Ophelia from seeing Hamlet or receiving his tokens, and that Hamlet, "repuls'd," fell into sadness, then weakness, then "lightness," and finally "the madness wherein now he raves." The King and Queen are skeptical but agree to test this theory. Polonius proposes that they "loose my daughter to him" while he and the King hide and observe their interaction.
Hamlet enters, reading a book. The King and Queen withdraw. Polonius attempts to speak with Hamlet, who responds with cryptic and seemingly mad remarks, calling Polonius a "fishmonger" and warning him to keep his daughter "not walk i'the sun" lest she "conceive." Hamlet reads from his book, claiming it contains "Slanders" about old men being wrinkled and lacking wit. Polonius, aside, notes, "Though this be madness, yet there's method in it." Polonius leaves, planning the meeting between Hamlet and Ophelia.
Rosencrantz and Guildenstern enter. Hamlet greets them warmly but quickly discerns they were "sent for" by the King and Queen, which they confess. Hamlet expresses his deep melancholy, describing the earth as a "steril promontory" and man as a "quintessence of dust" that "delights not me,--nor woman neither." Rosencrantz reveals that they "coted" (overtook) players on the way, and they are coming to offer service. Hamlet expresses interest. Hamlet explains that the players' decline in popularity is due to his uncle being king, as those who scorned his father now pay for his uncle's picture. He hints at something "more than natural."
Polonius re-enters, announcing the players' arrival. Hamlet continues to act erratically, making jokes about Polonius's age and quoting lines from a ballad about Jephthah and his daughter, which Polonius recognizes as "still harping on my daughter."
The Players enter. Hamlet welcomes them and asks for a passionate speech, specifically Æneas's tale to Dido, focusing on Priam's slaughter. The First Player recites a dramatic speech about Pyrrhus killing Priam and the "mobled queen" (Hecuba) running barefoot. Polonius is moved to tears. Hamlet praises the player and instructs Polonius to treat the players well, as they are "the abstract and brief chronicles of the time." Hamlet asks the First Player if they can perform "The murder of Gonzago" tomorrow night, and if he could "study a speech of some dozen or sixteen lines" to insert into it. The player agrees.
Alone, Hamlet delivers a soliloquy, chastising himself for his inaction and lack of emotion compared to the player's feigned passion for Hecuba. He calls himself a "dull and muddy-mettled rascal" and a "coward" for not avenging his father. Hamlet devises a plan: he will have the players perform a scene "like the murder of my father" before his uncle (the King). He will "observe his looks" and "tent him to the quick." If the King "blench," Hamlet will know the Ghost's story is true, as the Ghost could be the devil abusing his "weakness and my melancholy." He concludes, "The play's the thing Wherein I'll catch the conscience of the king."

**ACT III**

**SCENE I: A room in the castle.**
The King questions Rosencrantz and Guildenstern about Hamlet's distraction. They report that he admits to being distracted but won't reveal the cause, keeping "aloof with a crafty madness." They mention that Hamlet showed joy at the arrival of the players and has arranged for them to perform before the King and Queen that night. Polonius confirms this. The King and Queen are pleased by Hamlet's interest in the play and encourage Rosencrantz and Guildenstern to further engage him.
The King asks Gertrude to leave so he and Polonius can "closely sent for Hamlet" to "affront Ophelia" by accident. They will hide and observe to determine if Hamlet's suffering is due to "the affliction of his love." The Queen expresses hope that Ophelia's beauty will be the cause of Hamlet's wildness and bring him back to his "wonted way." Ophelia also hopes so.
Polonius instructs Ophelia to walk and read a book, using the "show of such an exercise" to "colour Your loneliness." He muses that "with devotion's visage And pious action, we do sugar o'er The devil himself." The King, aside, agrees, feeling a "lash" to his conscience. The King and Polonius hide.
Hamlet enters and delivers his "To be, or not to be" soliloquy, contemplating suicide as an escape from life's suffering, but fearing the unknown "dreams" that may come "in that sleep of death." He concludes that "conscience does make cowards of us all."
Ophelia approaches. Hamlet greets her, asking her to remember his sins in her prayers. Ophelia attempts to return "remembrances" (gifts) from Hamlet. Hamlet denies ever giving them and questions her honesty and fairness, suggesting that beauty corrupts honesty. Hamlet declares he never loved her and tells her to "Get thee to a nunnery," warning her against being a "breeder of sinners." He confesses to being "proud, revengeful, ambitious" and calls all men "arrant knaves." Hamlet asks where her father is, and upon hearing he is home, tells Ophelia to ensure the doors are shut upon him so he can "play the fool nowhere but in's own house." Hamlet continues his tirade, saying if she marries, she will not escape calumny, and should marry a fool. He condemns women's "paintings," "jig," "amble," "lisp," and "wantonness." He declares there will be "no more marriages: those that are married already, all but one, shall live; the rest shall keep as they are." He exits.
Ophelia is devastated, lamenting the "noble mind... o'erthrown" and the loss of Hamlet's "noble and most sovereign reason."
The King and Polonius re-enter. The King concludes that Hamlet's behavior is not love-sickness or madness, but "something in his soul, O'er which his melancholy sits on brood." He decides to send Hamlet to England immediately, under the pretext of demanding neglected tribute, hoping the change of scenery will cure him. Polonius still believes Hamlet's grief stems from "neglected love." He suggests that after the play, the Queen should speak with Hamlet alone, and he will hide and listen to their conversation. If that fails, then Hamlet should be sent to England or confined. The King agrees, stating, "Madness in great ones must not unwatch'd go."

**SCENE II: A room in the castle.**
Hamlet instructs a Player on the art of acting, emphasizing naturalness, temperance, and avoiding over-the-top performances or ad-libbing by clowns. Horatio enters. Hamlet praises Horatio as a just and constant man, not a slave to passion, and confides in him about the play. Hamlet reveals that one scene in the play mirrors his father's death. He asks Horatio to observe the King closely during that scene, promising to "rivet" his own eyes to the King's face. If the King shows guilt, then the Ghost's story is true; otherwise, it was a "damned ghost."
The King, Queen, and court enter to watch the play. Hamlet continues to act erratically, making suggestive remarks to Ophelia and commenting on his mother's cheerful demeanor so soon after his father's death. He notes it's been "twice two months" since his father died. The Prologue enters and delivers a brief, rhyming introduction. Hamlet calls it "brief, my lord," and Ophelia adds, "As woman's love."
The Player King and Queen then perform. The Player King expresses his impending death and his love for his wife. The Player Queen vows never to remarry if he dies, calling a second marriage "treason" and wishing curses upon herself if she breaks her vow, stating, "None wed the second but who kill'd the first." Hamlet, aside to Horatio, calls this "wormwood." He asks Ophelia how she likes the play. The Queen remarks, "The lady doth protest too much, methinks." Hamlet assures her the Player Queen will keep her word.
The King asks if there is "no offence in't." Hamlet assures him it's "poison in jest," and calls the play "The mouse-trap," explaining it's "the image of a murder done in Vienna." He identifies the characters as Gonzago (the Duke) and Baptista (his wife), and states that the murderer "gets the love of Gonzago's wife." Lucianus, the Player King's nephew, enters and pours poison into the sleeping Player King's ears. Hamlet explains that Lucianus poisons the King "for his estate." The King, visibly disturbed, cries, "Give me some light: away!" and exits with the entire court in a panic.
Hamlet and Horatio are left alone. Hamlet exults that the Ghost's word is proven true, as the King reacted to the poisoning scene. Rosencrantz and Guildenstern return. Guildenstern reports that the King is "marvellous distempered" with "choler" (anger) and the Queen is in "great affliction of spirit" and wishes to speak with Hamlet in her closet before he goes to bed. Hamlet, still acting mad, deflects their questions about his "distemper" and advancement. He refuses to play a recorder, comparing it to their attempt to "play upon me" and "pluck out the heart of my mystery."
Polonius enters, also summoning Hamlet to the Queen. Hamlet mocks Polonius by making him agree that a cloud looks first like a camel, then a weasel, then a whale. Hamlet agrees to go to his mother. Alone, he resolves to "speak daggers to her, but use none," reminding himself not to be unnatural towards her.

**SCENE III: A room in the same.**
The King expresses his unease with Hamlet's madness and decides to send him to England with Rosencrantz and Guildenstern immediately, to collect "neglected tribute" and to put "fetters upon this fear." He intends for Hamlet to be killed in England. Polonius enters, reporting that Hamlet is going to his mother's closet. Polonius plans to hide "Behind the arras" to "hear the process" of their conversation, believing the Queen will "tax him home." He reiterates that "some more audience than a mother" should overhear. The King, alone, attempts to pray, confessing his "rank offence" of murder. He admits he cannot truly pray because he still possesses the "effects for which I did the murder, My crown, mine own ambition, and my queen." He struggles with his guilt.

**SCENE IV: The Queen's chamber.**
Polonius instructs the Queen to be "round with him" (plain) and tell Hamlet his "pranks have been too broad." He then hides behind the arras. Hamlet enters. He and his mother exchange sharp words. Hamlet accuses her of offending his father, and she accuses him of offending his. When the Queen threatens to send others to speak to him, Hamlet forces her to sit down, intending to show her "the inmost part of you." The Queen, fearing for her life, cries for help. Polonius, from behind the arras, also cries for help. Hamlet, thinking it's the King, cries "A rat?" and stabs through the arras, killing Polonius. Hamlet pulls back the arras, discovers Polonius's body, and dismisses him as a "wretched, rash, intruding fool."
Hamlet then confronts his mother, accusing her of a "bloody deed" almost as bad as killing a king and marrying his brother. The Queen is shocked by the accusation of regicide. Hamlet shows her two pictures: one of his father (Hyperion-like, god-like) and one of Claudius (a "mildew'd ear, Blasting his wholesome brother"). He berates her for choosing Claudius, calling him a "murderer and a villain," a "vice of kings," who stole the crown and put it in his pocket. The Queen is deeply distressed, seeing "black and grainèd spots" in her soul.
The Ghost re-enters, visible only to Hamlet. It reminds Hamlet not to forget his purpose and to "whet thy almost blunted purpose," and to step between his mother and her "fighting soul." The Queen, seeing Hamlet speak to "incorporeal air," believes he is mad. She cannot see the Ghost. Hamlet describes the Ghost to his mother, who still sees nothing. The Ghost exits.
Hamlet insists he is not mad, offering to re-word everything he said. He urges her to confess to heaven, repent, and avoid his uncle's bed. The Queen's heart is "cleft in twain." Hamlet tells her to throw away the "worser part" and live purer. He bids her good night and tells her to "Assume a virtue, if you have it not." Hamlet expresses repentance for killing Polonius and says he will "answer well The death I gave him." He states he must be "cruel, only to be kind." He exits, dragging Polonius's body.

**ACT IV**

**SCENE I: A room in the castle.**
The King questions the Queen about Hamlet's sighs. The Queen reports that Hamlet, in a "lawless fit" of madness, killed Polonius, mistaking him for a "rat" behind the arras. The King expresses regret that it wasn't him and immediately decides to ship Hamlet to England. He sends Rosencrantz and Guildenstern to find Hamlet, speak fairly to him, and bring Polonius's body to the chapel. The King tells Gertrude they must call their wisest friends to "countenance and excuse" this "vile deed." He acknowledges that Hamlet is "lov'd of the distracted multitude" and cannot be harshly punished openly. Rosencrantz returns, unable to get Hamlet to reveal where the body is. The King orders Hamlet brought before him.
Hamlet is brought in. The King asks where Polonius is. Hamlet cryptically replies, "At supper," then "not where he eats, but where he is eaten," referring to worms. He suggests Polonius is in heaven, or if not, the King can find him by his smell in the lobby within a month. The King informs Hamlet he must go to England for his "especial safety." Hamlet agrees, bidding farewell to his "dear mother" (the King), explaining that "Father and mother is man and wife; man and wife is one flesh; and so, my mother." He exits for England. The King instructs Rosencrantz and attendants to follow Hamlet and hasten him aboard. Alone, the King reveals his secret plan: he has sent "letters conjuring to that effect" to England, demanding "The present death of Hamlet." He will not be joyful until it is done.

**SCENE II: A room in the castle.**
The Queen initially refuses to speak with Ophelia, but Horatio persuades her, saying Ophelia is "distract" and might "strew Dangerous conjectures in ill-breeding minds." Ophelia enters, singing fragmented, mournful songs about a dead love ("He is dead and gone, lady") and scattering imaginary flowers. Her songs and words are disjointed, indicating madness. The King enters and observes Ophelia's madness, attributing it to "Conceit upon her father." Ophelia sings about Saint Valentine's day and a maid who "Never departed more" after being let in. She distributes imaginary flowers, giving rosemary for remembrance, pansies for thoughts, fennel and columbines, and rue (herb of grace) to the King and Queen, noting the Queen can wear her rue "with a difference." She mentions violets withered when her father died. She exits, still singing. The King orders Horatio to follow Ophelia and watch her. The King laments that "When sorrows come, they come not single spies, But in battalions!"
Marcellus enters, warning the King that "The young Laertes, in a riotous head," is leading a rebellion, with the rabble crying, "Laertes shall be king!" Laertes enters, armed, with followers. He demands his father from the King. The Queen tries to interpose. Laertes, enraged, declares his loyalty to hell and vows to be "reveng'd Most throughly for my father." The King, asserting his divinity, assures Laertes he is guiltless of Polonius's death and offers to help him find the truth.
Ophelia re-enters, fantastically dressed with straws and flowers, still singing her mad songs. Laertes is heartbroken, calling her "O rose of May!" and lamenting that her wits are "as mortal as an old man's life." Ophelia continues to sing and distribute imaginary flowers, explaining their symbolic meanings (rosemary for remembrance, pansies for thoughts, fennel for flattery, columbines, rue for sorrow, daisy, violets). She exits. Laertes, overcome with grief, vows revenge. The King promises Laertes that he will help him find justice for his father's death, and "where the offence is let the great axe fall."
Bernardo enters with letters from Hamlet. One is for the King, one for the Queen. The King reads his letter aloud. Hamlet's letter states he is "set naked on your kingdom" and will beg leave to see the King tomorrow to "recount the occasion of my sudden and more strange return." A postscript says "alone." The King is puzzled, wondering if others have returned or if it's a trick. Laertes recognizes Hamlet's handwriting and is filled with a desire for revenge.
The King proposes a plan to Laertes: he will arrange a fencing match between Hamlet and Laertes. The King will praise Laertes's skill, knowing Hamlet is "remiss, Most generous, and free from all contriving," and will not inspect the foils. Laertes will choose an "unbated" (unblunted) sword, and in a "pass of practice," "Requite him for your father." Laertes eagerly agrees, adding that he will anoint his sword with a "mortal" poison from a "mountebank," so that even a scratch will be fatal. The King adds a backup plan: he will prepare a poisoned "chalice" for Hamlet to drink from if he escapes the sword.
The Queen enters, announcing, "Your sister's drown'd, Laertes." She describes Ophelia falling into a brook while hanging garlands from a willow tree, unable to save herself. Laertes, despite forbidding his tears, expresses his grief, saying, "The woman will be out." He exits, filled with a "speech of fire" (rage) that his tears are drowning. The King tells Laertes to strengthen his patience, promising a "living monument" for Ophelia and that they will "put the matter to the present push."

**ACT V**

**SCENE I: A churchyard.**
Two gravediggers (clowns) discuss whether Ophelia, who "wilfully seeks her own salvation" (suicide), should receive a Christian burial. The First Clown argues that the coroner found it Christian burial, implying she drowned in self-defense, and humorously dissects the legal definition of an "act" of drowning. The Second Clown states that if she hadn't been a "gentlewoman," she wouldn't have received Christian burial. The First Clown agrees, lamenting that "great folks should have countenance... to drown or hang themselves, more than their even christian." The First Clown poses riddles, asking who builds stronger than a mason, shipwright, or carpenter. The Second Clown guesses "gallows-maker," but the First Clown reveals it's a "grave-maker," whose "houses... last till doomsday."
Hamlet and Horatio enter, observing the gravedigger singing cheerfully while digging up skulls. Hamlet comments on the gravedigger's lack of feeling, attributing it to custom. The gravedigger throws up a skull. Hamlet muses on its former owner, imagining it as a politician or lawyer. Hamlet questions the gravedigger about whose grave it is and how long he's been a gravedigger. The gravedigger reveals he started the day King Hamlet overcame Fortinbras, which was also the day young Hamlet was born, making Hamlet thirty years old. The gravedigger produces a skull, identifying it as Yorick's, the King's jester, whom Hamlet knew well. Hamlet holds the skull, reminiscing about Yorick's "infinite jest" and how he was carried on his back. He contemplates mortality, imagining Alexander the Great's dust stopping a bung-hole.
A funeral procession enters, but with "maimèd rites," indicating a doubtful death (suicide). Hamlet and Horatio hide. Laertes questions the Priest about the limited ceremony. The Priest confirms that because her death was "doubtful," only "great command o'ersways the order" to allow her virgin rites; otherwise, she would be buried in unsanctified ground with "Shards, flints, and pebbles" thrown on her. Laertes, enraged by the priest's churlishness, declares that violets will spring from Ophelia's flesh and she will be a "ministering angel" when the priest lies howling.
Hamlet realizes it is Ophelia's funeral, exclaiming, "What, the fair Ophelia!" The Queen scatters flowers on the grave, saying, "Sweets to the sweet: Farewell!" She expresses her hope that Ophelia would have been Hamlet's wife, not buried. Laertes, overcome with grief, leaps into the grave, wishing to be buried with her. Hamlet reveals himself, confronting Laertes and grappling with him in the grave. He declares his love for Ophelia was greater than "forty thousand brothers" love. The King and Queen separate them. The Queen claims Hamlet is mad. Hamlet rants about his love and willingness to outdo Laertes in grief. He exits. The King tells Horatio to follow Hamlet and assures Laertes that they will "put the matter to the present push," referring to their revenge plot. He promises Ophelia a "living monument."

**SCENE II: Hall in the castle.**
Hamlet apologizes to Horatio for his outburst at Laertes, recognizing that Laertes's grief mirrors his own. Osric, a foppish courtier, enters. Hamlet mocks his affected language and behavior. Osric delivers a message from the King: the King has wagered six Barbary horses against six French rapiers and poignards that Hamlet will win a fencing match against Laertes. The wager is that in a "dozen passes," Laertes will not exceed Hamlet by three hits. Hamlet agrees to the match, despite a "gain-giving" (misgiving) in his heart, stating, "we defy augury: there is a special providence in the fall of a sparrow."
The King, Queen, Laertes, and court enter. The King asks Hamlet to take Laertes's hand. Hamlet apologizes to Laertes for his "madness," claiming he "shot my arrow o'er the house, And hurt my brother." Laertes accepts the apology, stating he is "satisfied in nature" but will reserve his "revenge" until a "wise and uncharged judgment" confirms his honor is not stained. Foils are brought. Laertes finds one too heavy. Hamlet chooses one. The King announces the wager and prepares a "chalice" of wine, into which he drops a "union" (pearl), which he secretly poisons. He proclaims he will drink to Hamlet's health and orders cannons fired.
Hamlet and Laertes begin to fence. Hamlet scores the first hit. Osric confirms it. The King offers Hamlet the poisoned cup, but Hamlet defers drinking until after the next bout. Hamlet scores a second hit. The Queen drinks from the poisoned cup, despite the King's warning, saying, "I have, my lord; I pray you, pardon me." The King, aside, realizes "It is the poison'd cup; it is too late." Laertes, aside, expresses a pang of conscience but resolves to hit Hamlet.
They play the third bout. Laertes wounds Hamlet with the poisoned, unbated rapier. In the ensuing scuffle, they exchange rapiers, and Hamlet wounds Laertes with the same poisoned weapon. The Queen falls, declaring, "The drink, the drink! I am poison'd." She is carried off. Laertes falls, revealing his treachery: Hamlet is slain, having "not half an hour's life," and the "treacherous instrument is in thy hand, Unbated and envenom'd." He confesses that "the foul practice Hath turn'd itself on me" and that "Thy mother's poison'd: I can no more: the king, the king's to blame."
Hamlet, realizing the poison, stabs the King, calling him "incestuous, murd'rous, damnèd Dane," and telling him to "Follow my mother." The King is borne away, mortally wounded. Laertes, dying, exchanges forgiveness with Hamlet, absolving him of his and his father's death, and asking for his own absolution. Laertes dies.
Hamlet, dying, tells Horatio to live and "Report me and my cause aright To the unsatisfied," as he has no time to tell his story. Horatio attempts to drink the remaining poison from the cup, but Hamlet snatches it away, insisting Horatio live to tell his tale. Hamlet declares, "The potent poison quite o'ercrows my spirit; The rest is silence." He dies. A dead march is heard afar off, and the curtain descends.
value_gemini:
The generated summary is significantly more detailed and extensive than the original summary. While the original provides a concise, high-level overview of the plot, the generated summary reads like a scene-by-scene synopsis of the play, incorporating numerous specific details, dialogue snippets, and character motivations that are not present in the original.

**Analysis of Coverage:**

**Events:**
*   **Covered:** The generated summary covers almost all major events described in the original summary, from the initial appearance of the ghost and its revelation of Claudius's murder, through Hamlet's feigned madness, the "Mousetrap" play, Polonius's death, Ophelia's madness and drowning, Laertes's return and the revenge plot, and the final fencing match leading to the deaths of Gertrude, Laertes, Claudius, and Hamlet. The level of detail for these events is far greater than in the original.
*   **Missing:** The most significant omission in the generated summary is the entire resolution of the play after Hamlet's death. The original summary explicitly includes:
    1.  The arrival of Fortinbras, the Norwegian prince, with his army and ambassadors from England.
    2.  The report from the English ambassadors that Rosencrantz and Guildenstern are dead.
    3.  Fortinbras taking power of the kingdom.
    4.  Horatio fulfilling Hamlet's last request to tell his tragic story.
    5.  Fortinbras ordering Hamlet to be carried away in a manner befitting a fallen soldier.
    This entire concluding sequence, which provides closure to the narrative and establishes the new political order in Denmark, is completely absent from the generated summary.

**Characters:**
*   **Covered:** All major characters mentioned in the original summary (Watchmen, Horatio, King Hamlet (ghost), Claudius, Queen Gertrude, Prince Hamlet, Rosencrantz, Guildenstern, Polonius, Ophelia, Laertes) are covered in the generated summary, often with much more detail regarding their actions and dialogue.
*   **Missing:** Fortinbras and the English ambassadors, who are crucial to the play's resolution, are entirely missing from the generated summary.
*   **Extra:** The generated summary provides more detailed roles and dialogue for minor characters like Osric and the Gravediggers, and elaborates on the "Players," which are only briefly mentioned in the original.

**Plot Points:**
*   **Covered:** The generated summary meticulously covers almost all core plot points, including the inciting incident (ghost's revelation), Hamlet's internal conflict and delay, the development of Claudius's guilt, the various schemes and counter-schemes, and the tragic climax.
*   **Missing:** The ultimate resolution of the plot, specifically the transfer of power and the final disposition of the main characters' stories (e.g., Horatio's role as storyteller, Hamlet's honorable burial), is entirely absent. This leaves the narrative incomplete compared to the original summary.

**Detailed Justification of Missing or Extra Details:**

**Missing Details (from Original in Generated):**

1.  **Fortinbras's Arrival and Ascension to Power:** The original summary clearly states, "At this moment, a Norwegian prince named Fortinbras... enters with ambassadors from England... He moves to take power of the kingdom." The generated summary ends abruptly with Hamlet's death, completely omitting Fortinbras's crucial role in the play's conclusion and the establishment of a new ruler for Denmark. This is a major plot point, not a minor detail.
2.  **Report of Rosencrantz and Guildenstern's Deaths:** The original mentions, "ambassadors from England, who report that Rosencrantz and Guildenstern are dead." This provides closure for these characters, whose fate was sealed by Claudius's letter. The generated summary does not include this.
3.  **Horatio's Role as Storyteller:** The original states, "Horatio, fulfilling Hamlet’s last request, tells him Hamlet’s tragic story." While the generated summary includes Hamlet's request to Horatio to "Report me and my cause aright," it does not show Horatio actually fulfilling this role or the context of Fortinbras receiving the story.
4.  **Hamlet's Honorable Burial:** The original concludes with "Fortinbras orders that Hamlet be carried away in a manner befitting a fallen soldier." This final act of respect for Hamlet is missing from the generated summary.

**Extra Details (in Generated not in Original):**

The generated summary is replete with details not found in the original, making it a much longer and more comprehensive synopsis. These include:
1.  **Scene-by-Scene Structure:** The generated summary is organized by Act and Scene, a structural choice that inherently leads to more detail than the original's continuous narrative.

summary_llm:
The story begins with Jane, a young orphan, living at Gateshead Hall with her aunt, Mrs. Reed, and her cousins, Eliza, John, and Georgiana. Jane is frequently bullied by John Reed and treated with disdain by Mrs. Reed and her daughters. On a cold, rainy day, Jane is excluded from the family circle and retreats to a window-seat to read a book of pictures. John Reed discovers her, verbally abuses her, and then physically attacks her, throwing a book that cuts her head. In a fit of rage, Jane retaliates, calling John a "murderer" and "slave-driver." Mrs. Reed, alerted by the commotion, orders Jane to be locked in the red-room, a seldom-used, imposing chamber where her late uncle, Mr. Reed, died.

Locked in the red-room, Jane is terrified and feels unjustly punished. She reflects on her miserable life at Gateshead and the broken promise Mr. Reed made Mrs. Reed swear on his deathbed: to raise Jane as one of her own children. Overwhelmed by fear and a vivid imagination, Jane believes she sees a light and a ghost, causing her to scream. Mrs. Reed, Bessie (the nurse), and Miss Abbot (the lady's-maid) come to her aid, but Mrs. Reed, believing Jane is feigning, locks her back in, where Jane loses consciousness.

Jane wakes in her own bed, attended by Bessie and an apothecary, Mr. Lloyd. She overhears Bessie and another servant discussing her "fit" and Mrs. Reed's harshness. Mr. Lloyd questions Jane about her unhappiness, and she reveals her lack of family and the abuse she suffers. She expresses a desire to leave Gateshead. Mr. Lloyd suggests she go to school. Jane overhears Bessie and Miss Abbot discussing her parents, learning that her father was a poor clergyman, her mother was disowned by her family for marrying him, and both died of typhus fever shortly after Jane's birth. Miss Abbot expresses disdain for Jane, calling her an "underhand little thing."

Mr. Lloyd recommends to Mrs. Reed that Jane be sent to school. Mrs. Reed readily agrees, eager to be rid of her. Mr. Brocklehurst, the manager of Lowood School, visits Gateshead. Mrs. Reed tells him Jane has a tendency to deceit and asks him to keep a strict eye on her. Mr. Brocklehurst, a stern, hypocritical man, questions Jane about religion and morality, then publicly labels her a liar and a "castaway" before his own richly dressed wife and daughters, who are visiting. He orders Jane to stand on a stool for hours as punishment. During this ordeal, another pupil, Helen Burns, offers Jane a comforting smile, despite herself being frequently punished and humiliated by a harsh teacher, Miss Scatcherd.

Jane and Helen become friends. Helen, a patient and devout girl, teaches Jane about endurance, forgiveness, and a belief in a spiritual world beyond earthly suffering. Lowood School is depicted as a harsh environment with inadequate food, clothing, and heating. A typhus epidemic breaks out, killing many girls. Helen, suffering from consumption, is moved to a separate room. Jane, unaware of the severity of Helen's illness, visits her one night and they share a tender farewell. Helen dies peacefully in Jane's arms.

After the epidemic, public inquiry leads to significant improvements at Lowood. Jane thrives, spending six years as a pupil and two as a teacher. Miss Temple, the kind superintendent, becomes a mother figure and friend to Jane. However, Miss Temple eventually marries and leaves Lowood, causing Jane to feel a renewed sense of loneliness and a longing for a new life beyond the school's confines.

Jane decides to seek a new situation and advertises for a governess position. She receives a reply from Mrs. Fairfax of Thornfield Hall. After obtaining permission from Mr. Brocklehurst and a reluctant Mrs. Reed (who states she has "long relinquished all interference"), Jane leaves Lowood. On her journey to Thornfield, she encounters a mysterious, grim-faced man whose horse has slipped on ice. She helps him, and he later reveals himself to be Mr. Rochester, the master of Thornfield Hall.

At Thornfield, Jane meets Mrs. Fairfax, the kind housekeeper, and Adèle Varens, her young French pupil. Adèle is Mr. Rochester's ward, the daughter of a French opera-dancer, Céline Varens, with whom he had a past affair. Mr. Rochester, a moody and enigmatic man, frequently travels but returns to Thornfield. He engages Jane in long, probing conversations, revealing his cynical views on life and his past "errors" and "dissipation" in Europe. He confesses he was once deeply infatuated with Céline, but discovered her infidelity and mercenary nature. He took Adèle in out of a sense of duty, though he doubts she is his child.

Jane develops a deep affection for Mr. Rochester, despite his perceived flaws and his apparent courtship of the beautiful but haughty Blanche Ingram, a guest at Thornfield. During a house party, Mr. Rochester disguises himself as a gipsy fortune-teller and, in a private interview, subtly reveals his true feelings for Jane and his disdain for Blanche. He then confesses to Jane that he feigned interest in Blanche to make Jane jealous and realize her own love for him.

A terrifying incident occurs: a "demoniac laugh" and a struggle are heard from the third storey of the house. Jane discovers Mr. Rochester's bed curtains on fire and saves him. Mr. Rochester attributes the incident to Grace Poole, a servant, but Jane suspects a deeper mystery. Later, she is called to Mr. Rochester's room again and finds Mr. Mason, a visitor from the West Indies, stabbed and bleeding. Mr. Rochester makes Jane tend to Mason, forbidding her to speak to him, and then secretly removes Mason from the house with a surgeon. He tells Jane that Grace Poole is a "singular" person and orders her to keep silent about the events.

Mr. Rochester proposes marriage to Jane. Overjoyed, Jane accepts. However, on their wedding day, a solicitor, Mr. Briggs, interrupts the ceremony, declaring an impediment: Mr. Rochester is already married. Mr. Mason, who is present, confirms that he is the brother of Mr. Rochester's living wife, Bertha Mason. Mr. Rochester, furious but resigned, admits the truth: he married Bertha fifteen years ago in Jamaica, but she is mad, from a family prone to insanity. He describes her violent, intemperate nature and the deceit of her family, who hid her condition for her fortune. He leads the wedding party to the third storey, where Bertha is kept confined under the care of Grace Poole. Bertha is revealed as a wild, "clothed hyena" who attacks Mr. Rochester. He subdues her, then defiantly asks the clergyman and lawyer to judge him.

Mr. Briggs then reveals that Jane's uncle, John Eyre of Madeira, is dead and has left her his entire fortune of twenty thousand pounds. He explains that John Eyre, upon receiving Jane's letter announcing her marriage, learned of Mr. Rochester's existing wife from Mr. Mason and sent Mr. Briggs to prevent the bigamous marriage.

Devastated by the discovery of Mr. Rochester's existing marriage and his deception, Jane flees Thornfield Hall in the night, leaving all her possessions except a small parcel and twenty shillings. She wanders for two days, destitute and starving, before collapsing on the doorstep of Moor House. She is discovered by the Rivers family: St. John, Diana, and Mary, who take her in and nurse her back to health. To avoid discovery, Jane gives the false name "Jane Elliott."

During her recovery, Jane learns that the Rivers are her cousins, and St. John reveals that her uncle, John Eyre, was also their uncle, and that he left his fortune to Jane. Jane insists on dividing her inheritance equally among her three cousins and herself, giving each five thousand pounds. She then takes a position as a village schoolmistress in Morton, a nearby village, finding purpose in teaching poor girls.

St. John Rivers, a zealous and ambitious clergyman, reveals his intention to become a missionary in India. He falls in love with Rosamond Oliver, a beautiful and wealthy local girl, but suppresses his feelings, believing she is not suited to be a missionary's wife. He asks Jane to marry him and accompany him to India as his "helpmeet and fellow-labourer," arguing that she is "formed for labour, not for love." Jane refuses, recognizing that he does not love her as a wife and that such a marriage would stifle her spirit. St. John is deeply displeased but gives her time to reconsider.

One night, while contemplating St. John's offer, Jane hears Mr. Rochester's voice calling her name from a great distance. Convinced it is a supernatural summons, she realizes her true love and duty lie with him. She tells St. John she must find out what has become of Mr. Rochester.

Jane returns to Thornfield Hall, finding it a blackened ruin. The innkeeper at "The Rochester Arms" tells her the Hall burned down. He recounts that Bertha Mason set the fire, and when Mr. Rochester tried to save her, she jumped from the roof to her death. Mr. Rochester, in his efforts to save others, was severely injured: he lost an eye, his other eye was blinded by inflammation, and one hand was crushed and amputated. He now lives as a blind and crippled recluse at Ferndean Manor, attended only by old John and his wife.

Jane immediately goes to Ferndean. She finds Mr. Rochester, blind and disfigured, but recognizes him instantly. She reveals her identity, and he is overwhelmed with joy and disbelief. Jane tells him about her inheritance. She pledges to stay with him as his companion, nurse, and eyes. He confesses his remorse for his past actions and his newfound faith in God, acknowledging that his suffering was a just chastisement that humbled him. He reveals that the night Jane heard his voice, he was praying for her return, and he heard her voice reply.

Jane and Mr. Rochester marry in a quiet ceremony. Mr. Rochester eventually regains partial sight in one eye, enough to dimly see the world and, two years later, to see their first-born son, who has inherited his father's original "large, brilliant, and black" eyes. Jane and Edward live a life of deep happiness and complete union. Diana and Mary Rivers marry and visit them annually. St. John Rivers goes to India as a missionary, dedicating his life to God's work, and is expected to die there, content in his service.

summary_llm:
The story begins in a classroom with the arrival of a new, awkward country boy named Charles Bovary, who is about fifteen. He struggles to fit in, is mocked by his classmates and master, and his name is eventually identified as "Charles Bovary." Despite initial difficulties, he proves to be a conscientious student. His background is then revealed: his father, Monsieur Charles Denis Bartolome Bovary, a retired assistant-surgeon-major, had squandered his wife's dowry and failed at farming. Charles's mother, initially loving, became bitter due to her husband's infidelity and idleness, taking over household management. Charles's upbringing was a mix of maternal spoiling and paternal Spartan ideals. He received irregular lessons from the curé before being sent to school in Rouen at eighteen, where he was a mediocre student. He later studied medicine, initially diligently, but eventually succumbed to idleness, frequenting public-houses and engaging in romantic pursuits. He failed his first medical examination but passed a second attempt after intense study.

Charles decides to practice medicine in Tostes, succeeding an old doctor whose death his mother had anticipated. His mother then arranges his marriage to Heloise Dubuc, a forty-five-year-old widow with an income. Heloise proves to be controlling, ugly, and constantly complaining, making Charles's married life difficult and restrictive.

One night, Charles is called to the Bertaux farm, eighteen miles away, to set a broken leg. His wife, Heloise, expresses concern about the dark journey. At the farm, Charles treats Monsieur Rouault, a well-to-do widower, and is assisted by his daughter, Emma. Charles is captivated by Emma's delicate hands and striking dark eyes. He begins visiting the farm frequently, enjoying Emma's company, which makes his wife, Heloise, jealous. Heloise confronts Charles, accusing him of neglecting her for a "town miss" and disparaging Emma's family. Charles, weary of the conflict, promises to stop his visits. Shortly after, the notary managing Heloise's property absconds with her money, revealing her fortune to be largely non-existent and mortgaged. Charles's father is furious, blaming his wife for the poor match. Heloise falls ill and dies a week later. Charles is saddened, realizing she had loved him.

After a period of mourning, old Rouault visits Charles, pays him for the treatment, and invites him back to the Bertaux. Charles, now independent and with an increased medical practice, returns to the farm. He becomes infatuated with Emma, observing her closely, and they share intimate moments, discussing their pasts and dreams. Charles resolves to marry her. Old Rouault, eager to marry off his daughter and in need of money, approves of Charles. The wedding is planned for the following spring. Emma, dreaming of a grand event, prepares her trousseau, but her father insists on a traditional country wedding. The wedding takes place with many guests, lasting sixteen hours.

The wedding is a boisterous affair with elaborate food and entertainment. Charles, not being facetious, does not shine. The next day, he is openly affectionate with Emma. Two days later, they leave for Tostes. Upon arrival, Emma discovers the bridal bouquet of Charles's first wife, which Charles removes to the attic. Emma begins redecorating their home and Charles buys her a dogcart. Charles is happy, finding joy in Emma's presence. However, Emma feels unfulfilled, questioning the meaning of "felicity, passion, rapture" from her romantic books.

Emma's past is further explored, detailing her convent education where she read romantic novels and dreamed of grand passions, but eventually found religious life boring. She initially believed her marriage to Charles was the "wondrous passion" she sought, but now finds her calm life unfulfilling. She finds Charles's conversation commonplace and his lack of diverse skills disappointing. Charles's mother visits, criticizing Emma's spending and "fine ways," leading to friction. Emma tries to force herself to love Charles, but his passion seems unextraordinary. She takes solitary walks, lamenting her boredom and dreaming of a different, more exciting life. She receives an invitation to a ball at the Marquis d'Andervilliers' château, Vaubyessard, after Charles cured the Marquis's abscess.

At the luxurious château, Emma is dazzled by the aristocratic setting and refined guests. She experiences new sensations and observes the elegant manners. During the ball, she waltzes with a Viscount, feeling a "torpor" and resting her head on his breast. She sees peasants looking in from outside, which makes her past life seem distant and unreal. The next day, after a quick luncheon and a tour of the stables, the Bovarys return to Tostes. On the way, Charles finds an emblazoned cigar-case, which Emma, scornful of his smoking, throws into the cupboard. Emma dismisses their servant, Nastasie, for rudeness. Emma feels a profound change after the ball, filled with regret for her mundane life.

Emma frequently takes out the cigar case, wondering if it belonged to the Viscount and his mistress. She reads ladies' journals and romantic novels, imagining a luxurious life in Paris. She replaces Nastasie with Félicité, an orphan she tries to train as a lady's maid. Charles works hard, but Emma finds his habits and appearance irritating. She yearns for something extraordinary. She gives up music and drawing, feeling her life is a "dark corridor" of ennui. She suffers from palpitations and giddiness, leading Charles to consider moving. While tidying, Emma burns her wedding bouquet. In March, the pregnant Bovarys move to Yonville-l'Abbaye.

Yonville-l'Abbaye is described as a stagnant market town. On their arrival, Monsieur Homais, the local chemist, introduces himself and invites himself to dinner. At dinner, Emma meets Léon Dupuis, a notary's clerk, and they discover a shared romantic sensibility, contrasting with Charles and Homais's pragmatic views. Emma gives birth to a daughter, Berthe, and faints upon hearing it's a girl. She chooses the name Berthe, and Homais becomes godfather, giving pharmaceutical gifts. Charles's father, visiting, causes a scene at the baptism by baptizing Berthe with champagne. Emma visits Berthe at the nurse's house, accompanied by Léon, and they share a moment of "common sympathy." Léon feels bored with Yonville and is drawn to Emma, but an "abyss" seems to separate them.

In colder weather, Emma observes Léon from her window. Homais, a frequent dinner guest, gossips and offers advice. A bond forms between Emma and Léon through shared reading. Emma gives Léon a rug, sparking gossip. Léon struggles to declare his love. On a snowy Sunday, during a visit to a yarn-mill, Emma feels contempt for Charles and is drawn to Léon's charm. She regrets not having loved Léon. Her love for Léon eventually fades due to his absence, and she feels a "terrible cold." She indulges in whims and tries to read serious books, but remains unfulfilled. She suffers from fainting spells and spits blood. Charles's mother visits, suggesting Emma needs manual work and criticizing her reading. They decide to stop Emma reading novels.

On a market day, Monsieur Rodolphe Boulanger, a wealthy landowner, visits Charles. Charles treats Rodolphe's ploughman, who faints during a bloodletting, as does Justin, Homais' apprentice. Emma helps revive them. Rodolphe, observing Emma, finds her pretty and bored with Charles, and resolves to seduce her. He plans to use the upcoming agricultural show as an opportunity.

At the agricultural show, Rodolphe and Emma walk together, avoiding Lheureux. Rodolphe criticizes provincial life and expresses his unfulfilled desires, holding Emma's hand. A councillor gives a long speech. Rodolphe whispers to Emma, advocating for passions over societal conventions, and declares they were destined to meet. He takes her hand, and she doesn't withdraw it. The councillor announces prizes, and an old servant, Catherine Leroux, receives a medal. Rodolphe and Emma part after the banquet and fireworks. Homais publishes a self-aggrandizing article about the show.

Six weeks later, Rodolphe visits Emma, having deliberately delayed to heighten her desire. He claims he didn't want to return but was compelled by his love for her. Emma is flattered and sobs. He confesses his love and asks to tour her house. Charles enters, and Rodolphe pretends to have been discussing Emma's health. Charles suggests Emma take up riding, and Rodolphe offers a horse. Emma initially refuses but agrees to get a riding habit. Rodolphe arrives with two horses, and they ride into the forest. They dismount, and Rodolphe declares his love. Emma resists, but eventually yields to him, leaning on his shoulder and giving herself up. They return to Yonville. Charles, oblivious, buys a cob for Emma. Emma feels a "second puberty" and tastes love without remorse.

They exchange letters and meet regularly. Emma visits Rodolphe at his house before dawn, throwing her arms around him and declaring her love. She continues these secret visits, but Rodolphe eventually tells her her visits are imprudent. Emma becomes anxious about being discovered. She encounters Captain Binet, who is duck hunting, and gives a flimsy excuse for her early morning walk. Emma worries Binet will gossip. At Homais' shop, she is stifled by Binet's presence. Emma and Rodolphe arrange to meet at night in the garden. Rodolphe makes jokes about Charles, which embarrass Emma. Emma becomes sentimental, exchanging tokens of love, but Rodolphe's indifference grows. Their relationship becomes monotonous. Old Rouault sends a turkey and a letter, reminding Emma of her past. Emma is filled with renewed unhappiness.

Homais convinces Charles to operate on Hippolyte's club-foot, promising celebrity. Emma encourages Charles. Charles, with Homais's help, constructs a machine and performs the tenotomy. The operation is initially deemed a success, and Homais writes a glowing article. However, Hippolyte's condition worsens, leading to gangrene. Charles calls in Monsieur Canivet, a celebrated surgeon, who amputates Hippolyte's leg and criticizes Charles and Homais. Charles is devastated, fearing ruin and ridicule. Emma feels humiliation and rage towards Charles, regretting her marriage. She pushes Charles away. That evening, Rodolphe finds Emma waiting for him, and their affair resumes.

Emma and Rodolphe's affair continues. Emma suggests they run away, but Rodolphe dismisses the idea. Emma's repulsion for Charles intensifies. She spends lavishly on herself and gifts for Rodolphe, accumulating debts with Lheureux. She buys Hippolyte a wooden leg, then another, at Charles's expense. Lheureux, the draper, supplies Emma's whims, accumulating bills. Emma uses a power of attorney to sell a property, but Lheureux manipulates her into signing more bills, taking a large commission. Charles's mother discovers Emma's extravagance and the power of attorney. A quarrel ensues, and Charles's mother leaves after Emma, in a fit of hysterics, gives her the power of attorney to burn. Emma makes Charles sign another power of attorney. One night, Emma does not return home, causing Charles great anxiety. She lies about her whereabouts, gaining more freedom for her escapades with Léon. Léon, now her lover, becomes her "mistress," adopting her tastes and writing her copied love poems.

Léon invites Homais to Rouen, who, eager for a Parisian experience, agrees. Emma is angered by Léon's delay due to Homais. Homais drinks and talks excessively at a cafe, discussing women and science. Léon finally escapes Homais and finds Emma furious. He apologizes, and she asks him to return immediately. Homais again intercepts Léon, dragging him to a friend's. Léon eventually returns to the hotel, but Emma has left in anger. Their love becomes less passionate. Emma receives a bill from Lheureux's associate, Vincart, and is served a summons for 8,000 francs. She rushes to Lheureux, who reveals his secret association with the notary and her extensive debts. He suggests she sell her property, then manipulates her into signing four bills for 1,000 francs each, taking a large discount. Charles's mother returns, criticizing Emma's spending. Emma, enraged, gives her mother-in-law the power of attorney, who burns it. Emma has hysterics. Charles defends Emma, and his mother leaves. Emma makes Charles sign another power of attorney. One night, Emma does not return home, causing Charles great anxiety. She lies about her whereabouts, gaining more freedom for her escapades with Léon. Léon, now her lover, becomes her "mistress," adopting her tastes and writing her copied love poems.

Emma is stoical when the bailiff arrives to inventory their possessions for distraint. She sends Félicité to keep Charles away. The next day, Emma desperately seeks money from brokers in Rouen, but all refuse. She goes to Léon, asking for 8,000 francs. Léon is shocked and claims he cannot help. Emma, frustrated, suggests he get money from his office. Léon promises to ask a rich friend, Morel, and bring the money the next day. Emma is not convinced. Returning to Yonville, she sees the Viscount, which deepens her despair. She encounters Homais and the blind beggar, to whom she gives her last five-franc piece.

The next morning, Emma sees a bill announcing the sale of her furniture. Félicité gives her a summons for 8,000 francs. Félicité suggests she go to Monsieur Guillaumin, the notary. Guillaumin, who is secretly associated with Lheureux, knows about her debts. He subtly flirts with her, then makes advances, declaring his love and seizing her. Emma recoils, accusing him of taking advantage of her distress, and leaves. Filled with rage and despair, she runs to Nurse Rollet's house, then, in an "ecstasy of heroism," decides to go to Rodolphe at La Huchette.

Emma finds Rodolphe smoking by the fire. She asks for his advice but cannot speak. He compliments her, but she replies bitterly. He offers a vague excuse for their past breakup, which Emma pretends to believe. She tells him of her suffering and asks for three thousand francs, revealing her ruin and the imminent sale of her furniture. Rodolphe turns pale and calmly says he doesn't have the money. Emma accuses him of never loving her and points out his expensive possessions. She reminds him of her sacrifices and his broken promises. Rodolphe remains calm, repeating, "I haven't got them." Emma leaves, feeling the world crushing her. She experiences a brief moment of madness, seeing Rodolphe's face everywhere.

In a desperate act, she runs to Homais' shop, slips in, and asks Justin for the key to the "Capharnaum" (where the arsenic is kept), claiming she wants to kill rats. Justin, astonished by her pallor, gives her the key. She goes to the third shelf, seizes the blue jar, and eats the white powder. Justin cries out, but Emma tells him to be silent. She returns home, calm. Charles, distracted by the news of the distraint, returns to find Emma gone. She comes back, writes a letter, and tells Charles to read it tomorrow, forbidding questions. She lies down, feeling a bitter taste. She is seized with sickness and vomits, with Charles noticing a white sediment. Emma denies taking anything. She begins to groan, her body convulsing. Charles, on his knees, asks what she ate. She faintly says, "Well, there--there!" He reads her letter: "Accuse no one." He realizes she is poisoned.

Félicité runs to Homais, who spreads the news. Charles is distraught. Homais writes to other doctors. Charles tries to read his medical dictionary. Homais suggests an antidote and an analysis. Charles collapses, sobbing. Emma tells him she won't trouble him anymore, saying it "had to be." She asks for Berthe, but recoils at the mention of the nurse, which reminds her of her adulteries. Berthe is frightened by Emma's appearance. Charles takes Berthe away. Doctor Canivet arrives, prescribes an emetic, and Emma vomits blood. Her body is covered with spots, and she screams horribly. Doctor Lariviere, a renowned surgeon and Charles's old master, arrives. He examines Emma and tells Charles, "There is nothing more to be done." Homais, eager to impress Lariviere, prepares a breakfast and discusses Emma's symptoms and various poisons. Justin drops plates when Homais asks about the arsenic.

Abbe Bournisien arrives with the holy oil. Emma, in a temporary lull, finds joy in the violet stole and kisses the crucifix. The priest performs extreme unction, anointing her eyes, nostrils, mouth, hands, and feet, listing her worldly sins. Emma asks for her looking-glass and cries. Her breathing becomes rapid, her tongue protrudes, her eyes roll and grow pale. The death-rattle begins. The blind man's song is heard outside. Emma raises herself, cries, "The blind man!" and laughs an "atrocious, frantic, despairing laugh" before falling back, dead.

Charles is in shock, crying "Farewell!" Homais and Canivet drag him away. Charles is led downstairs, weeping. Homais returns to write letters, prepare a potion for Charles, invent a lie about Emma mistaking arsenic for sugar, and write an article. Homais returns to Charles, who is staring blankly. The priest helps Charles with funeral arrangements. Charles dictates his wishes: Emma to be buried in her wedding dress, with three coffins, and a large piece of green velvet. Homais criticizes the expense, but Charles dismisses him. Charles blasphemes against God.

Homais and Bournisien sit vigil over Emma's body, arguing about prayer and Christianity. Charles continually returns to Emma's room, contemplating her, hoping to revive her. Charles's mother arrives and argues with him about funeral expenses. Charles is left alone, then receives visitors who sit in silence. Homais returns with disinfectants. Emma is dressed for burial. As they put on her wreath, black liquid issues from her mouth. Homais helps. The priest and chemist resume their vigil, dozing and arguing. Charles comes to bid Emma farewell, lifts her veil, and cries out in horror. They drag him downstairs. Félicité cuts some of Emma's hair for Charles. The undertaker's men arrive. Charles endures the hammering. Emma is placed in three coffins. Old Rouault arrives and faints.

Old Rouault, having received Homais' ambiguous letter, rides frantically to Yonville, experiencing dizziness and hallucinations. He arrives distraught and falls into Charles's arms. Homais separates them, urging dignity. The funeral procession proceeds. Hippolyte, with his new leg, is present. Charles, at the head, walks erect. The coffin is lowered into the grave. Bournisien throws in earth, followed by Homais, and then Charles, who cries "Adieu!" and tries to throw himself into the grave. He is led away, feeling a vague satisfaction that it is over. Old Rouault smokes a pipe. Homais notes the absence of Binet and Tuvache. Lheureux and others deplore Emma's death. Old Rouault leaves, promising Charles a turkey. Charles and his mother talk late into the night, and she plans to live with him. Justin is found weeping at Emma's grave, revealing he was the potato thief.

Berthe is brought back to Charles, asking for her mamma. Charles is heartbroken. Money troubles continue, with Lheureux pressing for payment. Charles pledges exorbitant sums to keep Emma's belongings. His mother leaves after another quarrel. Everyone takes advantage of Charles, presenting bills for services Emma never received. Félicité runs away with Theodore, stealing Emma's remaining clothes. Charles receives news of Léon's marriage. Charles finds Rodolphe's letter in Emma's desk, revealing her affair. He is distraught, but his vague jealousy is lost in his immense woe. He adopts Emma's preferences, buying patent leather boots and wearing white cravats. He sells his silver and furniture, but keeps Emma's room as it was. He spends evenings with Berthe, mending her toys.

No one visits them now. Justin has run away. Homais' children no longer see Berthe. The blind man, whom Charles could not cure, tells travelers of Homais' failed attempt, leading Homais to conduct a secret campaign against him in the newspaper, resulting in the blind man's confinement in an asylum. Homais, emboldened, becomes a public figure, attacking priests and promoting progress. He writes a book and yearns for the Legion of Honour. He designs a grass plot in his garden to represent the cross of the Legion of Honour.

Charles, still grieving, finds Rodolphe's portrait among Emma's letters, confirming her infidelity. He is distraught and neglects his patients. He walks in the garden, weeping, and takes Berthe to the cemetery. He visits Madame Lefrancois to speak of Emma. One day, at a market, Charles meets Rodolphe. They both turn pale. Rodolphe offers him a beer. Charles stares at Rodolphe, seeing Emma in his face, and wishes he was him. Rodolphe talks about agriculture. Charles, in a "sombre fury," fixes his eyes on Rodolphe, then says, "I don't blame you now," adding, "It is the fault of fatality!" Rodolphe finds this remark "offhand" and "comic."

The next day, Charles is found dead in the arbour, his head back, eyes closed, holding a lock of Emma's hair. Canivet performs a post-mortem but finds nothing. After everything is sold, 12 francs 75 centimes remain, used to send Berthe to her grandmother. The grandmother dies, and old Rouault is paralyzed. An aunt takes Berthe, sending her to work in a cotton-factory. Three doctors fail to succeed in Yonville due to Homais' attacks. Homais thrives, gains an enormous practice, and is respected by authorities. He receives the cross of the Legion of Honour.
