book_title: Twenty Thousand Leagues under the Sea-Jules Verne
summary_llm:
The year 1866 was marked by a mysterious phenomenon: an enormous, spindle-shaped, phosphorescent object, much larger and faster than any known whale, was sighted by numerous vessels across the globe. Initial reports from ships like the *Governor Higginson* and the *Columbus* confirmed its aquatic nature and incredible speed. Later, the *Helvetia* and *Shannon* estimated its length at over 350 feet. Public opinion was divided between believing it was a colossal sea monster or a powerful submarine vessel. This mystery turned into a serious danger when incidents like the *Moravian* striking an uncharted rock and the *Scotia* sustaining a two-yard hole in its hull were attributed to the "monster," making sea travel perilous.

M. Pierre Aronnax, an Assistant Professor in the Museum of Natural History in Paris, arrived in New York in March 1867, having followed the phenomenon in the papers. After the submarine vessel hypothesis was rejected by governments, Aronnax published an article on April 30, proposing the existence of a gigantic, powerfully organized marine mammal, perhaps an enormous narwhal with a destructive horn, capable of inflicting such damage. His article gained traction, and the United States government commissioned the frigate *Abraham Lincoln*, under Commander Farragut, to hunt the creature.

After two months without a sighting, news arrived that the monster had been seen in the North Pacific. Aronnax received an invitation from the Secretary of Marine to join the expedition. Despite his weariness, Aronnax accepted, eager to pursue the creature. He summoned his devoted Flemish servant, Conseil, who calmly agreed to accompany him. They boarded the *Abraham Lincoln*, a fast frigate, just before it departed Brooklyn.

On board, Aronnax met Ned Land, a renowned Canadian harpooner, who, despite his skill with marine mammals, was skeptical about the existence of the "unicorn." Aronnax tried to convince Ned by explaining the immense pressure at ocean depths and the incredible strength an animal living there would require, but Ned remained unconvinced, only conceding that such an animal would indeed need to be incredibly strong.

The *Abraham Lincoln* sailed rapidly, rounding Cape Horn and entering the Pacific. For three months, the crew, motivated by a $2,000 reward, diligently watched the sea, but only sighted common whales. Impatience grew, and Commander Farragut promised to abandon the search in three days if the monster didn't appear. On November 5, as the deadline approached, Ned Land suddenly cried out, "The very thing we are looking for—on our weather beam!"

An intense, inexplicable electric light illuminated the sea. Aronnax identified it as an electrical gigantic narwhal. The creature approached the frigate with astonishing speed, encircling it with luminous rings. Commander Farragut attempted to escape, but the animal matched their velocity. After a day-long chase, during which the *Abraham Lincoln*'s cannon fire proved ineffective, Captain Farragut decided to attack while the monster seemed motionless. Ned Land threw his harpoon, striking a hard body. The electric light vanished, and two enormous waterspouts erupted, followed by a fearful shock that threw Aronnax overboard.

Aronnax, struggling in the dark, was saved by Conseil, who had followed him into the sea. Conseil reported that the frigate's screw and rudder were broken. As Aronnax's strength failed, he was rescued by Ned Land, who revealed that he had found footing on the "gigantic narwhal" itself, which he discovered was made of "sheet iron." Aronnax realized the "monster" was a human-made submarine vessel.

Suddenly, the submarine began to move. Aronnax, Ned, and Conseil clung to its upper part. After a long night, the vessel began to sink. A panel opened, a man appeared, and then eight masked men forcibly brought them inside.

They were imprisoned in a dark, iron cabin, which was then flooded with intense electric light. Two men entered, one of whom was the tall, calm, and energetic chief. Aronnax, Ned, and Conseil tried to communicate in French, English, German, and Latin, but the men showed no understanding. The strangers left. A steward brought them clothes and a meal of sea-produce, served on elegant dishes marked with the letter "N" and the motto "MOBILIS IN MOBILI." Aronnax deduced "N" was the commander's initial.

After a night of sleep, Aronnax noticed the air was heavy. Suddenly, fresh air circulated, indicating the submarine had surfaced to renew its air supply. Ned Land, frustrated by hunger, attacked the steward when he finally appeared. At that moment, the commander spoke in French, stopping Ned.

The commander, who introduced himself as Captain Nemo, revealed he understood all their languages but had chosen to observe them. He identified them and stated they had "troubled his existence" by pursuing him. Aronnax explained they believed they were chasing a sea monster. Captain Nemo declared he was not a "civilized man," had broken all ties with humanity, and lived independently of its laws. He offered them continued hospitality on board his vessel, the *Nautilus*, on the condition that they would remain prisoners and, at times, be confined to their cabins to prevent them from seeing what "ought not to be seen." Ned Land refused to give his word of honor, but Aronnax accepted, realizing they had no choice. Captain Nemo then revealed his intention to show Aronnax the "land of marvels."

Captain Nemo led Aronnax through the *Nautilus*, a magnificent vessel with a library of 12,000 books, a museum of natural and artistic treasures, and a smoking room where cigars were made from seaweed. He explained that electricity, generated from sodium extracted from seawater, powered everything on board: light, heat, motion, and even the pumps that stored breathable air. The *Nautilus* was 232 feet long, made of a double hull of steel plates, and could travel at 50 miles an hour. Captain Nemo detailed how it submerged and surfaced using water reservoirs and inclined planes, and how a powerful electric reflector illuminated its path. He confirmed the collision with the *Scotia* was accidental, but the encounter with the *Abraham Lincoln* was a defensive act. He revealed he had secretly constructed the *Nautilus* from parts sourced globally, assembled on a desert island, and that he was immensely wealthy from treasures found in the ocean.

The *Nautilus* then began its journey across the Pacific, following the Kuro-Scivo current. Aronnax, Ned, and Conseil were amazed by the transparent windows of the saloon, which allowed them to observe the vibrant submarine life. One day, they discovered the wreck of "The Florida, Sunderland," with corpses still bound to its deck, a grim reminder of the ocean's dangers.

Later, near Vanikoro, the island where La Perouse's expedition was lost, Captain Nemo revealed he had found a tin box containing La Perouse's final instructions, confirming the fate of his crew. He stated that a coral tomb was a peaceful grave, adding, "Yes, sir, of sharks and men," hinting at his animosity towards humanity.

The *Nautilus* entered the dangerous Torres Strait, where it ran aground on a coral reef. Captain Nemo, confident in the upcoming full moon's tide, granted Aronnax, Ned, and Conseil permission to go ashore on Gilboa Island. Ned Land was overjoyed at the prospect of fresh meat. On the island, they gathered bread-fruit, cabbage-palms, and yams. Ned successfully hunted a hog and several kangaroos, and Conseil caught a rare "drunk" bird of paradise. As they celebrated, stones thrown by natives interrupted them.

They rushed back to their boat, pursued by hundreds of Papuan savages. On board the *Nautilus*, Captain Nemo, absorbed in playing his organ, calmly dismissed Aronnax's concerns about the natives. He explained that the *Nautilus* was invulnerable. The next morning, as the tide rose, the natives surrounded the vessel. Aronnax and Conseil were fishing when a native's stone broke a rare shell. Conseil retaliated by shooting the native's amulet bracelet. Captain Nemo then ordered the hatches closed. He explained to Aronnax that he had no intention of harming the "poor creatures" but would prevent them from boarding. At the precise moment of high tide, Captain Nemo activated an electric current on the platform's rail, repelling the Papuans with powerful shocks. The *Nautilus* then floated free and left the Torres Strait.

The *Nautilus* sped into the Indian Ocean, where Aronnax observed phosphorescent seas and vast shoals of fish. Captain Nemo conducted experiments on ocean temperature at extreme depths, reaching 16,000 yards. Later, in the Atlantic, they encountered a troop of whales being attacked by cachalots. Captain Nemo, despising the destructive nature of whalers, refused Ned Land permission to hunt the whales. Instead, he used the *Nautilus* as a formidable weapon, ramming and tearing through the cachalots, turning the sea red with blood. He then collected milk from a dead whale, which he offered to Aronnax.

The *Nautilus* continued its southerly course, navigating through immense icebergs towards the Antarctic Pole. On March 18, it became completely blocked by an immovable barrier of ice. Captain Nemo, undeterred, announced his intention to reach the pole by going *under* the ice. He explained that the *Nautilus* could navigate the open waters beneath the icebergs. After two days of navigating under the ice, during which the *Nautilus* repeatedly struck the ice ceiling, Aronnax and his companions suffered from dwindling air supply and growing despair. Captain Nemo devised a plan to inject boiling water to prevent the ice from solidifying around them and then used the *Nautilus*'s weight and spur to break through the remaining ice. On March 21, 1868, at six in the morning, Captain Nemo announced, "The sea is open!"

They had reached the South Pole. Captain Nemo, standing on a volcanic peak, unfurled a black banner with a golden "N" and claimed possession of the region in his own name, declaring a six-month polar night over his new domains.

The journey northward began, but a violent shock soon imprisoned the *Nautilus* again, this time on its side, at 180 fathoms deep, struck by an overturning iceberg. Captain Nemo, though uneasy, calmly explained the situation. They managed to right the vessel but found themselves trapped in a narrow ice tunnel. With air supplies critically low, Captain Nemo ordered the injection of boiling water to prevent the ice from solidifying further. After days of desperate work, the *Nautilus* finally broke through the ice, and pure air flooded the vessel.

They traveled rapidly northward, passing Cape Horn and the Amazon River mouth. Ned Land's desire for escape grew, but Captain Nemo remained elusive. Aronnax confronted Captain Nemo, asking about their perpetual imprisonment. Captain Nemo, revealing a manuscript detailing his life and studies, reiterated that whoever entered the *Nautilus* could never leave. He dismissed Ned's desire for liberty, stating he kept them to protect his secret.

The *Nautilus* entered the Gulf Stream, encountering a violent hurricane. Captain Nemo, with "unaccountable caprice," braved the storm on the surface, seemingly courting death. Aronnax witnessed the immense power of the storm and the *Nautilus*'s resilience.

Later, near the Bank of Newfoundland, the *Nautilus* descended to the seabed, where Aronnax saw the transatlantic electric cable. On June 1, Captain Nemo stopped the *Nautilus* over a specific spot. He then revealed the wreck below was the French ship *Marseillais*, also known as "The Avenger," which had sunk heroically on that very day in 1794 rather than surrender.

The next day, June 2, a warship approached the *Nautilus*, firing upon it. Aronnax realized they were being hunted as a dangerous submarine. Ned Land attempted to signal the ship, but Captain Nemo violently stopped him, unfurling his black "N" flag and declaring, "I am the law, and I am the judge! I am the oppressed, and there is the oppressor! Through him I have lost all that I loved, cherished, and venerated—country, wife, children, father, and mother. I saw all perish! All that I hate is there!" He ordered Aronnax and his companions below, stating he would sink the ship.

Aronnax, Ned, and Conseil resolved to escape, but Captain Nemo submerged the *Nautilus* just as they were about to make their move. The *Nautilus* then rammed the warship below its waterline, passing through it like a needle. Aronnax witnessed the horrific destruction as the vessel sank, its crew drowning. Captain Nemo, a "terrible avenger," then went to his room, where he knelt before a portrait of a young woman and two children, bursting into sobs.

The *Nautilus* then sped northward at a frightful pace, constantly submerged. Aronnax, haunted by the violence, lost all sense of time. Ned Land, in despair, became silent. One morning, Ned woke Aronnax, announcing they were in sight of land and would escape that night. Aronnax agreed, determined to flee.

At ten o'clock that night, as the moon had not yet risen, Aronnax crept to the saloon, where he found Captain Nemo absorbed in playing his organ, murmuring, "Almighty God! enough! enough!" Aronnax rushed through the library to the boat, where Ned and Conseil were waiting. Ned sealed the boat's opening. Just as he was loosening the bolts, voices cried out, "The maelstrom! the maelstrom!"

They were on the dangerous coast of Norway, being drawn into the irresistible whirlpool. The *Nautilus* was caught in a spiral, and their boat, still fastened to its side, was carried along at giddy speed. The *Nautilus* cracked under the strain. Suddenly, the bolts gave way, and their boat was hurled into the maelstrom. Aronnax struck his head and lost consciousness.

Aronnax later awoke in a fisherman's hut on the Loffoden Isles, with Ned Land and Conseil safe beside him. He could not recall how they escaped the maelstrom. He revised his account of the incredible expedition, which had taken him 20,000 leagues in less than ten months. He wondered about the fate of the *Nautilus* and Captain Nemo, hoping that the captain's hatred had been appeased and that he would continue his peaceful exploration of the sea. Aronnax concluded that only Captain Nemo and himself had the right to answer the question of what lies in the deep.

It covers the main characters and the overarching narrative arc effectively. However, despite its extensive detail, it omits several distinct and important events and plot points that are present in the original summary.

**Analysis of Coverage:**

**Events, Characters, and Plot Points Covered:**
The generated summary successfully covers the vast majority of the narrative, including:
*   The initial sighting of the mysterious "sea monster" in 1866 and the subsequent shipwrecks.

*   Nemo's increasing reclusiveness and the revelation of his manuscript.
*   The encounter with the transatlantic telegraph cable and the story of "The Avenger."
*   The climactic revenge attack on the warship, Nemo's grief, and the subsequent escape attempt.
*   The maelstrom and the eventual awakening of Aronnax, Conseil, and Land on an island.

**Missing Details (compared to Original Summary):**

1.  **Part I Ending (Major Omission):** The original summary explicitly details the sequence where Nemo orders the captives to their quarters after eating drugged food, Aronnax is called to care for a wounded crew member who dies, and the captives attend a burial in a "breathtakingly beautiful underwater cemetery." This entire significant emotional and plot sequence is absent from the generated summary.
2.  **Underwater Walks and Hunting (Significant Omission):** The original mentions Aronnax being impressed by "the intimacy of their walks on the sea floor wearing suits and helmets with individual lanterns" and a "deep-sea hunting expedition in a submarine forest" using "electric guns." These unique experiences are not mentioned in the generated summary.
3.  **Collective Effort in Second Ice Trap (Significant Omission):** While the generated summary covers the *Nautilus* being trapped a second time and the dire air situation, it omits the detail that "The men all work together and take turns digging at the ice walls with axes. On board the Nautilus, they grow dizzy and faint with lack of oxygen." This highlights the shared struggle and physical toll.
4.  **Aronnax's Life Saved (Major Omission):** A crucial moment of heroism and character interaction is missing: "During this ordeal, Conseil and Land save Aronnax’s life by sharing their last portion of air with him."
5.  **Giant Squid Attack (Major Omission):** The original summary describes a dramatic encounter where "a group of giant squid who attack the vessel and kill one of the crew members before they can drive the creatures back into the sea." This famous and impactful event is completely absent from the generated summary.
6.  **Nemo's Explicit Threat of Drowning:** The original states that if the prisoners don't agree to the situation, Nemo "will drown them." The generated summary implies their lack of freedom but doesn't state this specific, stark threat.
7.  **Crew's Invented Language:** The original mentions Nemo's crew speaking their "own invented language." The generated implies a communication barrier but doesn't specify it as an invented language.
8.  **Caribbean Journey:** The original mentions the *Nautilus* speeding to the Caribbean, arriving by April 20. This specific leg of the journey is not mentioned in the generated summary.

**Extra Details (present in Generated Summary but not in Original Summary):**

The generated summary is significantly more detailed than the original, often providing specific names, dates, measurements, and descriptive elements that were not in the more concise original. Examples include:
*   Specific ship names involved in the initial sightings (*Governor Higginson*, *Columbus*, *Helvetia*, *Shannon*, *Moravian*, *Scotia*).
*   Specific dates (March 1867, April 30, Nov 5, March 18, March 21, 1868, June 1, June 2, 1794).
*   Specific measurements (350 feet length, two-yard hole, 12,000 books, 232 feet long, 50 mph, 16,000 yards depth, 180 fathoms deep).
*   Detailed descriptions of the *Nautilus*'s construction and power source (double hull of steel plates, sodium from seawater, water reservoirs, inclined planes, electric reflector).
*   Specific locations and events (Kuro-Scivo current, "The Florida, Sunderland" wreck, Vanikoro, La Perouse's expedition, Gilboa Island, specific plants/animals hunted, Amazon River mouth, Gulf Stream, Bank of Newfoundland, *Marseillais*).
*   More extensive quotes and internal thoughts (Nemo's full declaration during the revenge, Aronnax's identification of the "electrical gigantic narwhal," Nemo's organ playing and murmuring "Almighty God! enough! enough!").
*   Specific character actions and descriptions (Conseil shooting the amulet, Nemo playing the organ, Ned sealing the boat, Aronnax rushing through the library).

**Conclusion:**

The generated summary is remarkably comprehensive in its scope and detail, often providing a richer narrative than the original summary. However, its primary weakness lies in the omission of several key events and plot points that are explicitly mentioned in the original. These missing elements, such as the underwater burial, the giant squid attack, and the saving of Aronnax's life, are not minor details but rather distinct and memorable parts of the story as summarized in the original. While the generated summary adds a wealth of "extra" detail, it fails to cover *all* the events outlined in the original.

summary_llm:
The plot of "Ulysses" unfolds over a single day, June 16, 1904, primarily following the experiences and thoughts of Stephen Dedalus and Leopold Bloom in Dublin, culminating in their unexpected meeting and a final extended internal monologue from Molly Bloom.

**Part I: Stephen Dedalus**

**Chapter 1:** The day begins at the Martello tower in Sandycove, where Buck Mulligan, a medical student, performs a mock Mass, shaving with a bowl of lather. He calls out to Stephen Dedalus, who is displeased and sleepy. Haines, an English tourist, is also present. Mulligan teases Stephen about his name, his Greek studies, and his mother's death, suggesting Stephen's aunt believes he killed her because he refused to kneel and pray for his dying mother. Stephen recalls his mother's death, her wasted body, and the smell of wax and rosewood. Mulligan asks Stephen about Haines, calling him a "ponderous Saxon" who thinks Stephen is not a gentleman. Stephen reveals Haines was "raving all night about a black panther" and expresses fear, stating he will leave if Haines stays. Mulligan borrows Stephen's handkerchief, calling it "snotgreen" and "the bard's noserag." He then gazes at the sea, calling it a "great sweet mother," a sentiment that troubles Stephen, who recalls his mother's painful death. Mulligan offers Stephen a shirt and "noserags" and teases him about wearing grey trousers despite killing his mother. He then jokes about Stephen having "general paralysis of the insane." Stephen points out a crack in the mirror Mulligan holds, calling it a "symbol of Irish art." Mulligan links arms with Stephen, kindly saying he has more spirit than others and suggesting they "Hellenise" Ireland. He proposes they work together and asks why Stephen doesn't trust him, suspecting Haines. Stephen reveals his resentment towards Mulligan for a comment made after his mother's death: "O, it’s only Dedalus whose mother is beastly dead." Mulligan dismisses it as a joke, arguing about the nature of death. A voice calls Mulligan from within the tower for breakfast. Mulligan tells Stephen to "chuck Loyola" and come down, advising him not to "mope." Stephen, left alone, reflects on his mother's memories and her death, feeling a deep sense of pain and reproach. Mulligan calls him again, saying Haines is apologizing for last night. Stephen agrees to come down, and Mulligan asks him to touch Haines for a guinea. Stephen mentions he gets paid that morning, and Mulligan asks for a loan of one of his four quid. Stephen agrees. Mulligan sings a Cockney song about coronation day. Stephen notices the forgotten shaving bowl and reflects on his past as a server. In the gloomy living room, Mulligan and Haines are by the fire. Haines opens the door, and Stephen locks it, putting the key in his pocket. They prepare and eat breakfast. A milkwoman arrives, and Mulligan flirts with her, then makes a loud statement about the country's poor health. Stephen notes her deference to Mulligan. Haines speaks Irish to her, and she identifies him as English. Mulligan explains Haines thinks Irish should be spoken in Ireland. The milkwoman charges for seven pints and three quarts. Mulligan finds a florin, calls it a "miracle," and gives it to her. Stephen adds that they owe twopence. The milkwoman leaves. Haines mentions visiting the National Library, and Mulligan suggests a swim first, teasing Stephen about washing once a month. Haines praises Stephen's "cracked lookingglass" comment. Bloom kicks Stephen's foot, and Mulligan says Stephen will speak on Hamlet. Haines mentions the milkwoman again. Stephen asks if he'd make money from it. Haines is unsure. Mulligan criticizes Stephen for asking about money. Stephen explains his need for money. Mulligan offers to lend him money, then strips off his gown, emptying his pockets, returning Stephen's handkerchief. He puts on his collar and tie, talking about gloves and boots. Stephen picks up his hat. Haines calls them, and they leave, Stephen locking the tower door with his key. Outside, Haines asks about the tower's rent. Mulligan says "Twelve quid," and Stephen adds "To the secretary of state for war." Haines asks Stephen about Hamlet, but Mulligan interrupts, saying Stephen needs three pints to discuss it. Mulligan jokes that Stephen proves "Hamlet’s grandson is Shakespeare’s grandfather and that he himself is the ghost of his own father." Stephen says he's tired. Haines mentions Elsinore. Mulligan chants a blasphemous song about "Joseph the Joiner." Haines finds it blasphemous but amusing. Stephen says he hears the song "three times a day." Haines asks if Stephen is a believer. Stephen says there's only one sense of the word. Haines offers him a cigarette. Haines asks if Stephen believes in a personal God. Stephen calls himself a "horrible example of free thought." Stephen thinks about the key, his rent, and eating Bloom's "salt bread." Haines says Stephen is his own master. Stephen replies he is a "servant of two masters, an English and an Italian." He adds a third who wants him for "odd jobs." He clarifies the English state and the Roman Catholic Church. Haines says an Irishman must think like that and that England has treated Ireland unfairly. Stephen thinks of heresies. Haines expresses concern about "German jews" taking over England. They walk down to the creek. Mulligan, in shirtsleeves, prepares to swim. A young man is already in the water. Mulligan's brother is mentioned as being in Westmeath. An elderly man scrambles out of the water. Mulligan crosses himself. The young man says "Seymour’s back in town," going into the army. Mulligan jokes about Seymour. Mulligan takes off his trousers and shirt, saying "Redheaded women buck like goats" and "My twelfth rib is gone, I’m the _Übermensch_." He asks if Stephen is coming in. Haines says later. Stephen says he's going. Mulligan asks for the key to keep his "chemise flat" and for twopence for a pint. Stephen gives him both. Mulligan plunges into the water. Haines smiles at Stephen, calling him "wild Irish." Mulligan calls out "The Ship, Half twelve." Stephen agrees and walks away, reflecting on his mother and his decision not to sleep in the tower.

**Chapter 2:** Stephen is teaching a class of schoolboys. He asks Cochrane about Tarentum and a battle, then Armstrong about Pyrrhus. The boys laugh at Armstrong's answer. Stephen defines a pier as a "disappointed bridge." He thinks about writing for Haines's chapbook and about history. The boys ask for a story. Talbot recites from "Lycidas." Stephen has internal thoughts about Aristotle and Plato. He gives the boys a riddle about a fox burying his grandmother, which they cannot solve. He gives the answer, and they react with dismay. A stick strikes the door, and a voice calls "Hockey!" The boys rush out. Sargent, a lingering boy, shows Stephen his copybook with "Sums" on the headline. Stephen asks if he understands them, and Sargent says no. Stephen helps him solve a problem, thinking about Sargent's mother and his own. He reflects on his mother saving him from being "trampled underfoot" and her death. He solves the problem, thinking of Shakespeare and Hamlet. Sargent copies the data, and Stephen tells him to go play. Mr. Deasy, the school director, appears, complaining about the boys. He asks Stephen to wait in his study. In the study, Stephen sees Stuart coins and a spooncase. Mr. Deasy enters, settles Stephen's payment (£3 12s). Stephen puts the money in his pocket, reflecting on it as "symbols soiled by greed and misery." Mr. Deasy advises him to save, calling money "power," and quotes Shakespeare. Stephen identifies the quote as Iago. Mr. Deasy asks about the "pride of the English." Stephen replies, "That on his empire... the sun never sets." Mr. Deasy corrects him, saying the proudest boast is "I paid my way." Stephen reflects on his own debts. Mr. Deasy talks about Irish history, O'Connell, and the famine. He mentions his ancestor, Sir John Blackwood, who voted for the union. Mr. Deasy asks Stephen to do him a favor by getting a letter for the press published, about foot-and-mouth disease. He types the end of the letter. Stephen reads the letter, which discusses the disease, Koch's preparation, and a cousin, Blackwood Price, who cures it in Austria. Mr. Deasy expresses concern about an embargo on Irish cattle and his difficulties with "intrigues" and "backstairs influence." He then states, "England is in the hands of the jews," linking it to national decay. Stephen questions this, defining a merchant as one who buys cheap and sells dear, "jew or gentile." Mr. Deasy says Jews "sinned against the light" and are "wanderers on the earth." Stephen replies, "Who has not?" Mr. Deasy asks what he means. Stephen says, "History... is a nightmare from which I am trying to awake." Mr. Deasy responds that "All human history moves towards one great goal, the manifestation of God." Stephen points to the window and says, "That is God." Mr. Deasy asks "What?" and Stephen replies, "A shout in the street." Mr. Deasy then talks about women bringing sin into the world, citing Helen of Troy and MacMurrough's wife, and Parnell's downfall. He ends with "For Ulster will fight And Ulster will be right." Stephen agrees to try to get the letter published in two papers. Mr. Deasy thanks him. As Stephen leaves, Mr. Deasy calls him back to say that "Ireland... has the honour of being the only country which never persecuted the jews... Because she never let them in." He laughs loudly.

**Chapter 3:** Stephen walks alone on Sandymount strand, reflecting on the "ineluctable modality of the visible" and "audible." He thinks about his ashplant, his boots, and the sea. He sees two women, Mrs. Florence MacCabe and another, coming down to the sea, and reflects on birth and his own mother. He thinks about his father's voice and his family (Uncle Si, Aunt Sally, Crissie, Walter). He imagines visiting them and their poverty. He reflects on his past, his studies in Paris, and his "Latin quarter hat." He remembers a telegram: "Mother dying come home father." He thinks about Mulligan's aunt believing he killed his mother. He walks on, seeing "mammoth skulls" of piled stones. He recalls Paris and Kevin Egan, an Irish exile. He thinks about lost leaders and betrayals. He feels the sand sinking under his feet and turns back towards the tower, but decides not to return there, feeling it's a "shut door of a silent tower." He sits on a rock, observing a dead dog and the sea. He sees a live dog running towards two figures, "the two maries." He reflects on Viking invaders and his own "blood" from them. He is startled by the dog's bark, thinking of himself as a "pretender." He thinks about a man drowned nine days ago and his own inability to save his mother. The dog sniffs the dead dog's carcass. A man kicks the dog away. The dog urinates against a rock and then digs in the sand, burying "his grandmother." Stephen recalls a dream about a "street of harlots" and a "creamfruit melon." He sees the two women again, "the red Egyptians," one with a bag of "spoils." He thinks about "Fumbally's lane" and "roguewords." He reflects on his "Hamlet hat" and his shadow. He writes on a rock, regretting forgetting slips from the library. He thinks about the "ineluctable modality of the ineluctable visuality" and a girl he saw in Hodges Figgis' window. He feels lonely and desires touch. He lies back, thinking of Kevin Egan and the sea. He thinks about his "ashplant" floating away and the "fourworded wavespeech" of the sea. He reflects on the drowned man and the "corpsegas" rising. He thinks about his bad teeth and whether to go to a dentist with his money. He picks dry snot from his nostril and places it on a rock. He sees a three-master ship sailing silently.

**Part II: Leopold Bloom**

**Chapter 4:** Mr. Leopold Bloom is in his kitchen, preparing breakfast. He likes "inner organs of beasts and fowls," especially grilled mutton kidneys. He makes tea and feeds his cat. He reflects on the cat's nature and intelligence. He decides to buy a pork kidney from Dlugacz's. He goes upstairs, pausing at his bedroom door, and tells his wife, Molly, he's going out. She grunts in response. He thinks about Molly's father, old Tweedy, and his stamp collection. He checks his hat for a "white slip of paper" and finds it "quite safe." He realizes he left his latchkey in his other trousers. He quietly closes the hall door. He walks through the streets, enjoying the warm morning, thinking of travel in the East. He passes Larry O'Rourke's pub, reflecting on how curates become successful publicans. He thinks about a "good puzzle" being to cross Dublin without passing a pub. He passes Saint Joseph's National school. He stops at Dlugacz's porkbutcher's, staring at sausages. He sees a girl at the counter and observes her hips, thinking about her strength and her "crooked skirt." He reads a page about a model farm in Kinnereth, Palestine, and thinks about olives and oranges. He buys a pork kidney. He watches the girl saunter away, thinking about her "sodachapped hands" and "crusted toenails." He reads about "Agendath Netaim," a planters' company in Palestine, and its potential for fruit groves. He thinks about Molly spitting out olives and his old friends Citron and Mastiansky. He reflects on the "dead sea" and "grey horror." He hurries home, feeling cold. He sees two letters and a card on the hall floor. One is for Molly, one for him from Milly, and a card for Molly. He enters the bedroom, half-closing his eyes. Molly asks who the letters are for. He tells her. He raises the blind, seeing Molly tuck her letter under her pillow. Molly asks for tea. He scalds the teapot and puts in tea. He unwraps the kidney, gives the blood-smeared paper to the cat, and fries the kidney. He sprinkles pepper. He opens his letter from Milly, which thanks him for a birthday present, mentions her photo business, a picnic, a concert, and a student named Bannon who sings Boylan's songs. Milly sends her best respects. Bloom reflects on Milly's age and her first birthday away from home, and the death of his son, Rudy. He thinks about Milly's growing independence and her "tomboy oaths." He feels a "soft qualm" about her ripening into womanhood. He thinks about taking a trip to Mullingar. The cat returns to the meat-stained paper and then wants to go out. Bloom feels "heavy, full" and goes to the outhouse, taking an old _Titbits_ magazine. He reads a story called "Matcham's Masterstroke" and eases his bowels. He reflects on the story's moral ending and envies the writer. He thinks about Molly dressing and her "lines in her eyes." He tears off half the story to wipe himself. He checks his black trousers and hears George's church bells tolling "Quarter to." He thinks, "Poor Dignam!"

**Chapter 5:** Mr. Bloom walks along Sir John Rogerson's Quay, past the sailors' home. He sees a boy and girl. He thinks about Dignam's funeral at eleven. He stops at the Belfast and Oriental Tea Company window, reads the labels, and adjusts his hat, finding a card behind the headband. He reads about Ceylon and the "garden of the world." He thinks about the weight of bodies in water. He unfolds a _Freeman_ newspaper and taps it against his leg. He goes into the post office and asks for letters for "Henry Flower Esq." He receives a letter. He reflects on soldiers and Maud Gonne's letter about them. He meets M'Coy, who asks about Molly and Dignam's funeral. Bloom tells him it's at eleven. M'Coy says he'll try to go and asks Bloom to put his name down if he can't make it. Bloom agrees. Bloom observes a stylish woman getting into a carriage. M'Coy tells him about hearing of Dignam's death from Bob Doran. Bloom thinks about the woman's "rich silk stockings." M'Coy continues his story. Bloom sighs. M'Coy asks about Molly, and Bloom says she's "tiptop" and has an engagement for a concert tour in Belfast. M'Coy expresses pleasure. Bloom thinks about Molly's name and a song. M'Coy asks who is organizing the tour, and Bloom says Blazes Boylan. M'Coy leaves, reminding Bloom to put his name down. Bloom reflects on M'Coy's "softsoaping." He walks towards Brunswick street, seeing hoardings. He thinks about seeing Mrs. Bandmann Palmer in "Leah" and his father's love for Kate Bateman. He recalls his father's grief and his own decision not to look at his father's dead face. He passes horses eating from nosebags. He draws Martha's letter from his pocket and folds it into the newspaper. He passes a cabman's shelter and hums "Là ci darem la mano." He turns into Cumberland street and opens Martha's letter. It contains a yellow flower. Martha expresses anger about the stamps he enclosed, calls him a "naughty boy," asks about his home, and wants to know the "real meaning of that word" (presumably "metempsychosis"). She longs to meet him and asks about his wife's perfume. Bloom smells the flower and places it in his heart pocket. He rereads the letter, reflecting on Martha's "indignant" tone and the possibility of a "love scrimmage." He throws the common pin from the flower on the road. He thinks about "two sluts" and "Mairy lost the pin of her drawers." He reflects on Martha's headache and her question about Molly's perfume. He tears up the envelope and scatters the shreds. He thinks about money and the Guinness brewery. He reaches All Hallows church, doffs his hat, and tucks the card behind the headband. He thinks about Father Conmee and the African Mission. He enters the church, observing a sodality and women kneeling for communion. He reflects on the "rum idea: eating bits of a corpse." He sits in a corner, kneeling on his newspaper. He sees the priest performing the ritual, thinking about Latin and "blind faith." He reflects on the priest's bald spot and the letters "I.H.S." He thinks about meeting Martha after the rosary and Peter Carey. He observes the priest rinsing the chalice with wine. He thinks about Molly's singing. He sees the priest bless the people. He stands up, discreetly buttoning his waistcoat. He leaves the church, thinking about the time and a lotion. He walks along Westland Row, realizing he left the recipe and his latchkey in his other trousers. He goes to Sweny's chemist, asks for the lotion, and buys a cake of lemon soap. He meets Bantam Lyons, who asks for his newspaper to check horse races. Bloom gives him the paper, saying he was "just going to throw it away." Lyons takes it, saying "I'll risk it." Bloom folds the paper, lodging the soap inside, and walks towards the baths, thinking about advertising. He eyes Hornblower at the porter's lodge. He anticipates a bath, thinking of his "pale body reclined in it at full, naked, in a womb of warmth."

**Chapter 6:** Martin Cunningham, Mr. Power, and Mr. Dedalus enter a funeral carriage. Mr. Bloom follows and sits in the vacant place. He reflects on the interest people take in corpses and the "unclean job" of preparing them. He realizes the soap is in his hip pocket. The carriage begins to move. They pass through Irishtown and Ringsend. Mr. Dedalus comments on the "fine old custom" of funerals. Bloom sees Stephen and points him out to Mr. Dedalus as his "son and heir." Mr. Dedalus is annoyed, calling Mulligan a "cad" and a "ruffian." Bloom silently reflects on his own lost son, Rudy. They discuss being late for the funeral. Bloom thinks about Molly and Milly. The carriage lurches, and Mr. Power notes "crumbs" on the seats, suggesting a "picnic party." Mr. Dedalus and Cunningham agree. Bloom is glad he took a bath. Mr. Dedalus sighs, saying "it’s the most natural thing in the world." They discuss other mourners. The carriage halts at the Grand Canal. Bloom thinks about whooping cough and his dog Athos. A raindrop falls. Mr. Dedalus curses the sky. They discuss Tom Kernan and Ben Dollard. Bloom reads the death notices in the paper, seeing Dignam's name. He remembers tearing up Martha's envelope. He thinks about the pointsman and a tram. They pass St. Mark's and the Queen's Theatre. Bloom thinks about seeing "Leah" or "Lily of Killarney." They see Blazes Boylan, and Mr. Dedalus salutes him. Bloom examines his fingernails, thinking about Boylan's "fascination" and his own "body getting a bit softy." Mr. Power asks about Molly's concert tour, and Bloom says it's going well, but he has "private business" in County Clare. He mentions J. C. Doyle and John MacCormack. Mr. Power mentions "Madame" (Molly). Bloom reflects on Smith O'Brien and a bunch of flowers. They pass a bootlace hawker. Bloom thinks about why the hawker was "struck off the rolls." He thinks about Molly's singing. Mr. Power asks about the woman Bloom keeps, and Bloom thinks it's not pleasant for the wife. They pass under the Liberator's form. Martin Cunningham nudges Mr. Power, saying "Of the tribe of Reuben." They see a "tall blackbearded figure" and Mr. Dedalus curses him. Bloom eagerly starts to tell a story about Reuben J and his son, but Martin Cunningham interrupts and tells the story of Reuben J's son falling into the Liffey and being rescued by a boatman, who was paid a florin. Mr. Dedalus comments, "One and eightpence too much." They pass Nelson's pillar. Martin Cunningham reminds them to look serious. Mr. Dedalus says poor Paddy wouldn't grudge them a laugh. Mr. Power expresses grief for Dignam. Martin Cunningham says Dignam died of a "breakdown, heart." Bloom thinks about alcohol. Mr. Power reflects on Dignam's "sudden death." Bloom says it's "the best death," with "no suffering." He thinks about the "dead side of the street." They see a tiny coffin for a child. Bloom thinks about his son Rudy. Mr. Power mentions suicide as the "greatest disgrace." Martin Cunningham calls it "temporary insanity." Mr. Dedalus calls a man who commits suicide a "coward." Bloom, about to speak, closes his lips. He thinks about Christian burial and a man found in the river. He thinks about Martin's wife and her drinking. The carriage speeds up. They pass the Mater Misericordiae hospital. The carriage stops again. Cattle pass by. Bloom suggests a tramline for animals. He also suggests "municipal funeral trams." Mr. Dedalus dismisses it. Martin Cunningham recalls a hearse capsizing. Bloom thinks about a corpse decomposing. They drive past Dunphy's corner. Bloom thinks about burying bodies in red. An empty hearse passes. They pass Crossguns bridge and the Royal Canal. Bloom thinks about a walking tour to see Milly by the canal. He salutes Paddy Dignam. They pass Brian Boroimhe house. Mr. Power asks about Fogarty. Mr. Dedalus quotes, "Though lost to sight... to memory dear." They turn towards Finglas road. They pass a stonecutter's yard. An old tramp sits on the curbstone. They pass gloomy gardens and the house where Childs was murdered. Bloom thinks about the "murderer's image in the eye of the murdered." He thinks about women and being careful. They arrive at Prospect cemetery. Bloom changes the soap from his hip pocket to his handkerchief pocket. He observes the "paltry funeral." He follows his companions. Mourners come out. He sees the coffin being carried in. He thinks about the number of funerals. He sees a lean-jawed woman and a girl. The mutes carry the coffin into the chapel. Martin Cunningham whispers to Mr. Power that Bloom's father poisoned himself, explaining Bloom's trip to Clare. Mr. Power is shocked. Bloom asks if Dignam was insured. Mr. Kernan says the policy was mortgaged and Martin is trying to get the youngster into Artane. Dignam left five children. Bloom expresses sadness. He thinks about outliving someone. Ned Lambert greets Mr. Dedalus. They discuss Dick Tivy. Ned Lambert says Martin is getting up a "whip for the youngsters." Mr. Dedalus asks about the eldest boy. They halt at the mortuary chapel. Bloom stands behind the boy with the wreath, thinking about O'Grady. The mutes carry the coffin in. Bloom kneels on his newspaper, holding his hat on his knee. A server and priest appear. The priest reads in Latin. Bloom thinks about the priest's appearance and the "bad gas" in the place. His kneecap hurts. The priest sprinkles holy water. Bloom thinks about the daily batch of corpses. The priest closes his book. Gravediggers carry the coffin out. Bloom follows, folding his paper. They walk towards the O'Connell circle. Mr. Dedalus weeps, thinking of his wife's grave. Mr. Power comforts him. Mr. Kernan and Bloom put on their hats. Mr. Kernan criticizes the service. Bloom assents. Mr. Kernan quotes, "_I am the resurrection and the life_." Bloom thinks about the physical reality of death. Corny Kelleher joins them. John Henry Menton asks who Bloom is. Ned Lambert says he is "Madame Marion Tweedy that was... the soprano. She’s his wife." Menton remembers dancing with her. He asks what Bloom does. Ned Lambert says he was a "traveller for blottingpaper." Menton asks why Molly married a "coon like that." Ned Lambert says she "has still" game and Bloom "does some canvassing for ads." The barrow turns into a side lane. John O'Connell, the caretaker, greets them. Mr. Dedalus jokes about visiting again. The caretaker tells a story about two drunks looking for Mulcahy's grave. Martin Cunningham explains it's "to cheer a fellow up." Bloom admires the caretaker's "prosperous bulk" and thinks about Keyes's ad. He thinks about his beard and the "ghost story" he could tell. He thinks about the "soil... fat with corpsemanure." He thinks about maggots and the caretaker's cheerful outlook. He thinks about his own death and his plot in Glasnevin with his mother and Rudy. The gravediggers begin to throw clay on the coffin. Bloom turns away. He thinks about what if Dignam was alive. He thinks about laws to ensure death. The clay falls softer. The caretaker puts on his hat. Hynes asks Bloom his Christian name and for M'Coy's name. Bloom gives "Leopold" and M'Coy's name. Hynes writes it down. Hynes asks about the "fellow in the macintosh." Bloom says he saw him. Hynes writes "M'Intosh." Bloom tries to correct him but Hynes doesn't hear. Bloom wonders where he disappeared to. A gravedigger comes by. The coffin is covered. The mourners disperse. Hynes suggests going by "the chief's grave." Mr. Power says some believe Parnell is not in his grave. Hynes says he is. Bloom walks alone, thinking about spending money on charity for the living. He thinks about cremation and the "Parsee tower of silence." He thinks about the smell of corpses. He sees the gates of the cemetery. He thinks about Mrs. Sinico's funeral and his father. He thinks about ghosts and not wanting to die. Martin Cunningham emerges, talking about solicitors. Menton's hat is crushed. Bloom points it out. Menton fixes it. Bloom feels "chapfallen." He thinks about Menton's "oyster eyes."

**Chapter 7:** Trams move around Nelson's pillar. Shoeblacks work outside the post office. Mailcars receive sacks of letters. Draymen roll barrels of Guinness. Red Murray and Mr. Bloom discuss an advertisement for Alexander Keyes. Bloom takes the cutting to the _Telegraph_ office. Red Murray suggests they can write a paragraph for Keyes. William Brayden, a "stately figure," enters the building. Red Murray whispers that his face is like "Our Saviour." Bloom suggests "Mario." Red Murray says "His grace phoned down twice." A telegram boy delivers a message. Bloom says Brayden is "one of our saviours." Bloom goes into the printing works, thinking of Dignam's funeral. He sees Hynes. He observes the machines. Hynes asks about the evening edition. Bloom tells Hynes the cashier is going to lunch. Hynes thanks him and hurries off. Bloom lays Keyes's cutting on Mr. Nannetti's desk. Keyes wants two crossed keys at the top of the ad. Bloom explains the "House of Keys" idea, linking it to the Manx parliament and home rule. Nannetti agrees to do it if Keyes renews for three months. Bloom thinks about spelling. He sees the first batch of papers come off the machine. Nannetti asks about the archbishop's letter. Bloom leaves to get the design for the ad. He passes old Monks, the "dayfather." He observes a typesetter reading backwards. He thinks about his father's hagadah book and the Passover. He thinks about "everybody eating everyone else." He leaves, thinking of phoning Nannetti. He hears laughter from the _Evening Telegraph_ office, recognizing Ned Lambert. He enters. Professor MacHugh is murmuring. Mr. Dedalus complains about a speech. Ned Lambert reads a flowery passage about Ireland. Mr. Dedalus says he's "changing his drink." MacHugh dismisses the "bombast." J. J. O'Molloy enters, looking "sad." He asks to see the editor. He turns pages of a file, thinking about his dwindling practice and gambling debts. Ned Lambert continues reading the flowery speech. MacHugh calls it "bombast." Mr. Dedalus curses it. Ned Lambert laughs. MacHugh calls him "Doughy Daw." The editor, Myles Crawford, enters, asking "What is it?" MacHugh calls him "the sham squire." Mr. Dedalus and Ned Lambert leave for a drink. Crawford's eyes rove towards Bloom. Ned Lambert asks Crawford to join them. Crawford talks about the "North Cork militia" winning in Ohio. Ned Lambert agrees. J. J. O'Molloy notes Ned's "incipient jigs." Crawford crows about "My Ohio!" MacHugh twangs dental floss. Bloom goes to the inner door to phone about an ad. Crawford discusses the leader with MacHugh. J. J. O'Molloy asks about the Canada swindle case. Bloom phones, getting information about an auction. Bloom bumps into Lenehan, who is picking up tissues. Lenehan complains about his knee. Newsboys shout outside. Bloom says he's going to Bachelor's Walk about Keyes's ad. Crawford tells him, "Begone! The world is before you." Bloom hurries out. Lenehan reads the tissues. MacHugh points out the newsboys following Bloom. Lenehan imitates Bloom's walk. Crawford asks where the others went. MacHugh says to the Oval for a drink. Crawford leaves. J. J. O'Molloy and Lenehan smoke. Crawford talks about the "Roman empire" and "fat in the fire." MacHugh discusses Roman civilization and "cloacae." Lenehan mentions Guinness. J. J. O'Molloy mentions Roman law. MacHugh says "Pontius Pilate is its prophet." J. J. O'Molloy asks about Chief Baron Palles. Lenehan wants to tell his riddle. Mr. O'Madden Burke and Stephen Dedalus enter. Lenehan calls them "mes enfants." Stephen hands over Mr. Garrett Deasy's letter. Crawford asks who tore it. Stephen blushes, explaining it's not his letter. Crawford jokes about Mrs. Deasy having "foot and mouth disease." Stephen asks if Deasy is a widower. Crawford says he is, and talks about an Irishman saving the Emperor's life. J. J. O'Molloy mentions "saving princes." MacHugh talks about loyalty to "lost causes" and the Greek language. Lenehan weeps for Pyrrhus and tells a limerick about MacHugh. Crawford takes the sheets. Lenehan tells his riddle: "What opera is like a railwayline?" "The Rose of Castile" (rows of cast steel). He pokes Mr. O'Madden Burke. MacHugh calls Stephen and O'Madden Burke "communards." J. J. O'Molloy jokes about them blowing up the Bastille. Crawford praises their talents. MacHugh mentions Bloom and "the gentle art of advertisement." O'Madden Burke mentions "Madam Bloom, the vocal muse." Lenehan coughs loudly. Crawford asks Stephen to write something with "a bite in it." Crawford talks about Ignatius Gallaher's journalism. He shows them a map with points related to a murder. Bloom is on the telephone. Crawford tells MacHugh to tell Bloom to "go to hell." Crawford explains Gallaher's "clever" alibi. Lenehan praises it. Crawford talks about "The Old Woman of Prince’s street" advertisement. MacHugh says hawkers were up before the recorder for selling postcards of Joe Brady. Crawford dismisses them. Crawford talks about great men at the bar. Stephen thinks about his mouth and kissing. J. J. O'Molloy argues with Crawford about bringing in famous orators. Crawford says Grattan and Flood wrote for the paper. J. J. O'Molloy mentions Bushe K.C. J. J. O'Molloy recounts Seymour Bushe's speech on the Childs murder case, contrasting Roman and Mosaic law. He mentions Michelangelo's Moses. Lenehan praises the speech. J. J. O'Molloy continues, describing the "stony effigy in frozen music." Stephen blushes when asked if he likes it. J. J. O'Molloy mentions Professor Magennis talking about Stephen and "the hermetic crowd." MacHugh recounts John F. Taylor's speech advocating the revival of Irish. He describes Taylor's appearance and then quotes his speech, comparing the English to Egyptian high priests and the Irish to Moses. Stephen thinks of Saint Augustine. Taylor's speech continues, contrasting the Egyptians' wealth and power with the Jews' nomadic life. Stephen's stomach growls. Taylor concludes by saying Moses would never have led his people out of bondage if he had listened to the Egyptians. J. J. O'Molloy notes Moses died without entering the promised land. Lenehan adds a sarcastic comment. MacHugh praises the oratory. Stephen suggests they adjourn. O'Madden Burke suggests Mooney's. Lenehan leads the way, saying they will refuse strong waters. Crawford fumbles for his keys, finding the "Foot and mouth" sheets. J. J. O'Molloy tells Stephen he hopes his theory will be published. MacHugh talks about the fall of empires. Newsboys yell "Racing special!" Stephen says he has a vision. Another newsboy passes. Stephen describes two "Dublin vestals" going up Nelson's pillar. MacHugh calls them "wise virgins." Stephen describes their journey, buying brawn and plums, and their fear of the pillar falling. He names them Anne Kearns and Florence MacCabe. Edy and Cissy are mentioned. Newsboys rush out. Crawford appears, talking with J. J. O'Molloy. MacHugh calls them. Bloom, breathless, catches Crawford, asking about Keyes's ad. A newsboy shouts about a "Terrible tragedy in Rathmines! A child bit by a bellows!" Bloom explains Keyes wants a renewal and a "par" in the _Telegraph_. Crawford tells Bloom to tell Keyes he can "kiss my arse." Bloom thinks about Stephen's boots. Bloom says he'll get the design and a "short par." Crawford loudly repeats his insult to Keyes. J. J. O'Molloy pulls a long face. They walk on. Stephen continues his story about the women on the pillar. Crawford calls it "copy." Stephen describes them pulling up their skirts. Crawford stops him, saying "No poetic licence." Stephen describes them peering at the "onehandled adulterer" (Nelson's statue). MacHugh likes the phrase. Stephen says it gives them a "crick in their necks" and they eat plums, spitting out the stones. Stephen laughs. Crawford says "So long as they do no worse." MacHugh compares Stephen to Antisthenes. They prepare to cross O'Connell Street. Crawford asks where the plums came from. MacHugh suggests a Latin phrase. Stephen calls his story "A Pisgah Sight of Palestine or The Parable of The Plums." MacHugh laughs, linking it to Moses. J. J. O'Molloy looks at the statue. MacHugh repeats "Onehandled adulterer." Crawford says it "tickled the old ones too."

**Chapter 8:** Mr. Bloom walks past a sweet shop, where a YMCA man gives him a throwaway. Bloom reads it, about "Elijah is coming." He thinks about his father's death and the "luminous crucifix." He thinks about phosphorus. He sees Dedalus's daughter outside Dillon's auctionrooms, thinking about families breaking up without a mother. He reflects on priests and their "butteries and larders." He thinks about the girl's "flitters" of dress. He sets foot on O'Connell Bridge, seeing a brewery barge. He thinks about rats in vats. He sees gulls and throws a crumpled paper ball to them, which they ignore. He throws Banbury cakes, and the gulls swoop. He reflects on poets and Shakespeare. He sees a rowboat with an ad for "Kino's Trousers." He thinks about advertising. He sees the timeball fall. He thinks about "metempsychosis" and Molly's wit. He sees sandwichmen for H.E.L.Y.'S, thinking about advertising ideas he had. He crosses Westmoreland street, thinking about his marriage, Milly's birth, and Molly's clothes. He thinks about his childhood and Molly's bath. He meets Mrs. Breen, who asks about Molly. Bloom says Milly has a job in Mullingar. Mrs. Breen says her husband, Denis, is "a caution to rattlesnakes" and is looking up libel law because someone sent him a postcard with "U. p: up" on it. She says he's going to sue for £10,000. Bloom expresses sympathy for Mrs. Purefoy, who is having a difficult birth in the lying-in hospital. He sees Cashel Boyle O'Connor Fitzmaurice Tisdall Farrell walking oddly. Mrs. Breen leaves to follow her husband. Bloom reflects on Breen's "lunatic" behavior and the postcard. He passes the _Irish Times_ office, thinking about other letters and Lizzie Twigg. He thinks about advertisements and horsey women. He thinks about Mrs. Miriam Dandrade. He thinks about Mrs. Purefoy and her "Methodist husband." He thinks about taxes and children. He stands at Fleet street crossing. He walks past Bolton's. He thinks about Mrs. Purefoy's labor. He sees pigeons flying over the Irish House of Parliament. He sees a squad of constables. He crosses under Tommy Moore's statue. He thinks about policemen. He sees John Howard Parnell, thinking about his brother and his "woebegone walk." He sees A.E. and a woman, thinking about vegetarianism and "dreamy, cloudy, symbolistic" people. He tries to blot out the sun with his finger. He thinks about Greenwich time and Professor Joly. He thinks about Molly and their past. He passes Adam court, seeing Bob Doran, who is on his "annual bend." He thinks about the Harp Theatre. He reflects on his own past happiness and Rudy. He passes Brown Thomas, seeing silks and ribbons. He thinks about his forearm and a scrape. He thinks about "perfume of embraces." He enters the Burton restaurant, finding the smell unpleasant and the eaters crude. He leaves, feeling hungry. He enters Davy Byrne's pub. Nosey Flynn greets him. Bloom orders burgundy and a cheese sandwich. He thinks about potted meat and cannibals. He thinks about hygiene and religions. Nosey Flynn asks about Molly's singing. Bloom says she's engaged for a tour. Flynn asks if Blazes Boylan is involved. Bloom feels a "warm shock." He says Boylan is the "organiser." Flynn tells a story about Boylan's luck with a boxing match. Davy Byrne comes forward. Flynn asks for a tip for the Gold Cup. Byrne says he doesn't bet. Bloom eats his sandwich. Flynn talks about horse racing and Lenehan's tip for "Sceptre." Bloom thinks about Molly fondling a dog. He drinks his wine, reflecting on food, oysters, and poison. He thinks about his past with Molly on Howth. He sees two flies stuck on the pane. He thinks about women's beauty and his own body. He goes to the yard. Davy Byrne asks if Bloom is in insurance. Flynn says he does canvassing for the _Freeman_. Byrne asks if he's in trouble. Flynn says no, and mentions Bloom buying cream for Molly. Flynn says Bloom is "in the craft" (Freemasonry). Byrne is surprised. Flynn tells a story about a woman hiding in a clock to learn their secrets. Byrne says Bloom is a "decent quiet man." Flynn says Bloom can't get drunk and checks his watch. Paddy Leonard and Bantam Lyons enter. Tom Rochford follows. They order drinks. Flynn asks about the "main drainage." Rochford has dyspepsia. Lyons winks about betting on a horse. Bloom leaves, raising three fingers. Lyons whispers that Bloom gave him the tip for the horse. Paddy Leonard scoffs. Bloom walks towards Dawson street, thinking about spinach and Röntgen rays. He sees a terrier choking up cud. He hums "Don Giovanni." He thinks about Keyes's ad and money. He thinks about buying silk petticoats for Molly. He passes a plumber's window. He thinks about the meaning of "teco." He passes a bookstore and a blind stripling. Bloom asks if the stripling wants to cross the street. The stripling doesn't answer. Bloom guides him across. He thinks about the stripling's senses and his name, Penrose. He thinks about women and their sense of smell. He feels his own hair and cheek. He sees the stripling go into Frederick street. He thinks about his own "whitey yellow" belly. He passes the Freemasons' hall. He sees a placard for the Mirus bazaar. He thinks about going to the library. He sees Stephen. His heart "quopped softly." He swerves towards the museum, feeling "wine in my face." He sees Stephen making for the museum gate. He thinks Stephen didn't see him. He feels his heart beating. He looks at the "cream curves of stone." He fumbles in his pocket for "Agendath Netaim." He thrusts it back. He thinks about "Afternoon she said." He searches his pockets for his handkerchief, the _Freeman_, his potato, his purse, and finds the soap. He feels "Safe!"

**Chapter 9:** At the National Library, the Quaker librarian, Mr. Lyster, purrs about "Wilhelm Meister." Stephen sneers about "Monsieur de la Palice." John Eglinton asks if Stephen has found "six brave medicals" to write "Paradise Lost." Stephen thinks of Cranly. He says he needs one more for "Hamlet." Russell, from his shadow, says these questions are "purely academic" and that "Art has to reveal to us ideas." Stephen says "The schoolmen were schoolboys first." Mr. Best enters, saying Haines has gone to buy Hyde's "Lovesongs of Connacht." Stephen thinks of Haines's baccy. Russell talks about lovesongs and the "living mother." Mr. Best mentions Mallarmé's prose poems about Hamlet. Stephen finishes his sentence: "The absentminded beggar." John Eglinton laughs. Stephen says Robert Greene called Shakespeare a "deathsman of the soul" and that the "bloodboltered shambles" of Hamlet is a forecast of the concentration camp. He thinks of Cranly. John Eglinton says Stephen thinks Hamlet is a ghost story. Stephen defines a ghost as "One who has faded into impalpability through death." He says Shakespeare is the ghost, playing the part of the spectre, speaking to his son's name, Hamnet. Russell interrupts, calling it "prying into the family life of a great man." Stephen thinks of the pound Cranly lent him. He thinks about paying it back. John Eglinton asks if he means to "fly in the face of the tradition of three centuries." Stephen says Shakespeare's wife died "sixtyseven years after she was born." Eglinton says the world believes Shakespeare "made a mistake." Stephen says "A man of genius makes no mistakes." The Quaker librarian enters. Eglinton asks what Socrates learned from Xanthippe. Stephen replies "Dialectic" and "how to bring thoughts into the world." Mr. Best asks about Ann Hathaway. Stephen says Shakespeare "had a good groatsworth of wit" and that "Ann hath a way." He describes Ann Hathaway as a "boldfaced Stratford wench" who seduced a younger man. He thinks about his own turn. Mr. Best mentions "Ryefield." Mr. O'Madden Burke says he's due at the _Homestead_. Eglinton asks if he'll be at Moore's tonight. Stephen thinks of "Yogibogeybox" and "Isis Unveiled." The Quaker librarian mentions Russell is gathering poets' verses. Stephen looks at his hat and ashplant. He thinks of "Cordelia." He tells Russell to give Deasy's letter to Mr. Norman. Russell says it will go in if important. Stephen sits down. The librarian asks if Stephen thinks Shakespeare's wife was unfaithful. Stephen says "Where there is a reconciliation, there must have been first a sundering." He thinks of "Christfox" and a "slack dishonoured body." The librarian closes the door. Stephen thinks about things that were not, like Caesar's life. He thinks about "coffined thoughts" and "Thoth, god of libraries." Eglinton says Shakespeare is "the most enigmatic." Mr. Best says "Hamlet is so personal." Stephen thinks of his own papers. Eglinton challenges Stephen's belief that Shakespeare is Hamlet. Stephen says "As we, or mother Dana, weave and unweave our bodies... so does the artist weave and unweave his image." He links this to a mole on his breast and the "ghost of the unquiet father" looking through the "image of the unliving son." Mr. Best says he feels Hamlet is "quite young." Stephen says the mole is "the last to go." Eglinton says if that were the "birthmark of genius," it would be a "drug in the market." The librarian mentions "the spirit of reconciliation." Stephen says there can be no reconciliation without sundering. He links this to Pericles and his daughter Marina. Eglinton calls it "sophists towards the bypaths of apocrypha." Stephen mentions Brandes. Stephen says Marina, Miranda, and Perdita represent what was lost being given back. Mr. Best murmurs about "L’art d’être grand." Stephen asks if a man will not see his own image reborn in his daughter. He thinks about love. He says a man with genius sees his own image as the "standard of all experience." The librarian hopes Mr. Dedalus will work out his theory and mentions Shaw and Frank Harris. Stephen mentions Goethe's saying: "Beware of what you wish for in youth because you will get it in middle life." He talks about Shakespeare's "untimely killed" belief in himself and the "goad of the flesh." He says the "poison poured in the porch of a sleeping ear" means King Hamlet's ghost could not know of the poisoning unless endowed by his creator. He links this to Shakespeare's "lean unlovely English" always turning "elsewhere, backward." He says Shakespeare is a "ghost, a shadow now." Buck Mulligan enters, saying "Amen!" He calls Stephen a "gaseous vertebrate." He reads a telegram from Stephen: "_The sentimentalist is he who would enjoy without incurring the immense debtorship for a thing done._" Mulligan says Stephen launched it from the "kips" and asks if he drank the four quid. He says the aunt will call on Stephen's father. He complains that he and Haines were "queer and sick" waiting for pints while Stephen sent his "conglomerations." Stephen laughs. Mulligan warns Stephen that Synge is looking for him to murder him for pissing on his halldoor. Stephen says that was Mulligan's "contribution to literature." Mulligan laughs. Stephen thinks of "Oisin with Patrick." An attendant says Mr. Lyster is wanted. The librarian talks to the attendant about the _Kilkenny People_ files. Bloom, "a patient silhouette," waits, listening. Mulligan calls Bloom "the sheeny" and "Ikey Moses." He says "Jehovah, collector of prepuces, is no more" and that he found him in the museum. He says Bloom knows Stephen and his father, and is "Greeker than the Greeks." Eglinton and Best want to hear more about Mrs. S. Stephen talks about Antisthenes and Penelope. He describes Shakespeare's wealth and his "twenty years" of dalliance. He recounts Manningham's story of Burbage and Shakespeare. Mulligan prays to "Blessed Margaret Mary Anycock!" Stephen asks what Penelope was doing in Stratford. He thinks of "one life is all." Mulligan challenges Eglinton about whom he suspects. Eglinton suggests Shakespeare was the "spurned lover." Stephen says "Love that dare not speak its name." Eglinton suggests Shakespeare "loved a lord." Stephen agrees, linking it to Socrates and his wives. He argues that Shakespeare "branded" Ann Hathaway with infamy by not mentioning her for 34 years. He says she had to borrow money. Eglinton mentions the will and widow's dower. Stephen says Shakespeare left her his "secondbest bed." Eglinton says "pretty countryfolk had few chattels." Stephen says Shakespeare was a "rich country gentleman" and asks why he didn't leave her his best bed. Mr. Best says there were two beds. Mulligan says "_Separatio a mensa et a thalamo_." Eglinton mentions famous beds. Stephen talks about Aristotle freeing his slaves and being kind to an old mistress. Mr. Best asks if he died so. Mulligan says he died "dead drunk." Mulligan recounts Dowden saying "life ran very high in those days" when asked about pederasty. Mr. Best says "The sense of beauty leads us astray." Eglinton says "You cannot eat your cake and have it." Stephen says Shakespeare "drew Shylock out of his own long pocket" and was a "cornjobber and moneylender." He links Shakespeare's plays to historical events and "jewbaiting." He thinks about "theolologicophilolological." Eglinton challenges him to prove Shakespeare was a Jew. Stephen says he was "made in Germany." Mr. Best calls him "myriadminded." Stephen begins to speak of Saint Thomas. Mulligan groans, "Ora pro nobis," and wails in Irish. All smile. Stephen speaks of Saint Thomas likening incest to "avarice of the emotions." He links Jews to intermarriage and avarice. He says a man who holds his rights over debts will hold them over his wife. Mulligan adds "Or his jennyass." Mr. Best says "Gentle Will is being roughly handled." Mulligan asks "Which will?" Eglinton says Ann's will to live is the will to die. Stephen prays "Requiescat!" He describes Ann in the "secondbest bed" and her later piety. Eglinton says "History shows that to be true" and that "a man’s worst enemies shall be those of his own house and family." He says Falstaff was not a family man. Stephen thinks of his father. He says a father is a "necessary evil" and that Shakespeare wrote Hamlet after his father's death. He argues that "Fatherhood... is unknown to man. It is a mystical estate... upon the void." He says "_Amor matris_... may be the only true thing in life." He thinks about his reasons. He talks about the "bodily shame" that sunders sons from fathers. He says Sabellius held the Father was His Own Son. He links Shakespeare to being the "father of all his race." Mulligan says "I am big with child. I have an unborn child in my brain. Pallas Athena! A play!" Stephen talks about Shakespeare's family, his mother's name in Arden, his son's death, and his brothers Gilbert, Edmund, and Richard. Eglinton asks "What's in a name?" Mr. Best asks for a good word for Richard. Mulligan sings a ditty. Stephen says two of Shakespeare's villains bear his brothers' names. Mr. Best hopes Edmund "catches it." Mr. Lyster quotes "But he that filches from me my good name..." Stephen says Shakespeare hid his name in the plays and revealed it in the sonnets. He describes a star at his birth. He thinks about his own name. Mr. Best mentions the "brother motive" in Irish myths and fairytales. The librarian asks about misconduct with one of the brothers. An attendant calls Mr. Lyster. Eglinton asks Stephen to speak of Richard and Edmund. Stephen says "A brother is as easily forgotten as an umbrella." He thinks of his whetstone. He talks about Shakespeare taking names from chronicles. He asks why Shakespeare chose the theme of the "false or the usurping or the adulterous brother." He says it sounds "uninterruptedly" from his plays. He links it to his daughter Susan's adultery. He laughs to free his mind. Eglinton says "The truth is midway. He is the ghost and the prince." Stephen agrees, saying he is "all in all." Mulligan clucks "Cuckoo! Cuckoo!" Eglinton praises Iago. Stephen says Shakespeare "returns after a life of absence to that spot of earth where he was born... and there... plants his mulberrytree... Then dies." Mulligan cries "Eureka!" and scribbles on a slip. Mr. Best says "Those who are married... shall live. The rest shall keep as they are." Eglinton calls Stephen a "delusion" and asks if he believes his own theory. Stephen says "No." Mr. Best asks if he will write it as a dialogue. Eglinton says he doesn't see why Stephen should expect payment. He mentions Herr Bleibtreu and the Rutland theory. Stephen thinks about belief. Eglinton says Stephen is the "only contributor to _Dana_ who asks for pieces of silver." Stephen asks for a guinea for his interview. Mulligan stands up, reads Stephen's telegram aloud, and complains about Stephen sending "conglomerations" while he and Haines waited for pints. Stephen laughs. Mulligan warns Stephen that Synge is looking for him. Stephen says that was Mulligan's "contribution to literature." Mulligan laughs. Stephen thinks of "Faunman he met in Clamart woods." An attendant calls Mr. Lyster. The librarian talks to Bloom (unseen by Stephen) about the _Kilkenny People_ files. Mulligan calls Bloom "the sheeny" and "Ikey Moses." He says he found "Jehovah, collector of prepuces" in the museum. He says Bloom knows Stephen and his father. Eglinton wants to hear more about Mrs. S. Stephen talks about Antisthenes and Penelope, Shakespeare's wealth, and the story of Burbage and the burgher's wife. Mulligan prays to "Blessed Margaret Mary Anycock!" Stephen asks what Penelope was doing. Mulligan raps the desk, challenging Stephen. Stephen talks about the "spurned lover" in the sonnets. Eglinton says "he loved a lord." Stephen agrees, linking it to Socrates. He argues that Shakespeare's wife was "hot in the blood." He challenges them to deny that Hamlet "branded her with infamy." He says she had to borrow money. Eglinton mentions the will and the "secondbest bed." Mr. Best says there were two beds. Mulligan says "_Separatio a mensa et a thalamo_." Stephen talks about Aristotle's death. Eglinton says he doesn't see why Stephen should expect payment. He mentions Herr Bleibtreu and the Rutland theory. Stephen thinks about belief. Eglinton says Stephen is the "only contributor to _Dana_ who asks for pieces of silver." Stephen asks for a guinea for his interview. Mulligan stands up, reads Stephen's telegram aloud, and complains about Stephen sending "conglomerations" while he and Haines waited for pints. Stephen laughs. Mulligan warns Stephen that Synge is looking for him to murder him for pissing on his halldoor. Stephen says that was Mulligan's "contribution to literature." Mulligan laughs. Stephen thinks of "Faunman he met in Clamart woods." An attendant says Mr. Lyster is wanted. The librarian talks to Bloom (unseen by Stephen) about the _Kilkenny People_ files. Mulligan calls Bloom "the sheeny" and "Ikey Moses." He says he found "Jehovah, collector of prepuces" in the museum. He says Bloom knows Stephen and his father, and is "Greeker than the Greeks." Eglinton and Best want to hear more about Mrs. S. Stephen talks about Antisthenes and Penelope, Shakespeare's wealth, and the story of Burbage and the burgher's wife. Mulligan prays to "Blessed Margaret Mary Anycock!" Stephen asks what Penelope was doing. Mulligan raps the desk, challenging Stephen. Stephen talks about the "spurned lover" in the sonnets. Eglinton says "he loved a lord." Stephen agrees, linking it to Socrates. He argues that Shakespeare's wife was "hot in the blood." He challenges them to deny that Hamlet "branded her with infamy." He says she had to borrow money. Eglinton mentions the will and the "secondbest bed." Mr. Best says there were two beds. Mulligan says "_Separatio a mensa et a thalamo_." Stephen talks about Aristotle's death. Mulligan says he died "dead drunk." Mulligan recounts Dowden saying "life ran very high in those days" when asked about pederasty. Mr. Best says "The sense of beauty leads us astray." Stephen talks about Shakespeare as a "cornjobber and moneylender" and links his plays to historical events. He thinks about "Mingo, minxi, mictum, mingere." Eglinton challenges him to prove Shakespeare was a Jew. Stephen says he was "made in Germany." Mr. Best calls him "myriadminded." Stephen talks about Saint Thomas likening incest to "avarice of the emotions." Mulligan groans. Stephen says a man who holds his rights over debts will hold them over his wife. Mulligan adds "Or his jennyass." Mr. Best says "Gentle Will is being roughly handled." Eglinton says Ann's will to live is the will to die. Stephen prays "Requiescat!" He describes Ann in the "secondbest bed" and her later piety. Eglinton says "History shows that to be true" and that "a man’s worst enemies shall be those of his own house and family." He says Falstaff was his "supreme creation." Stephen thinks of his father. He says a father is a "necessary evil" and that Shakespeare wrote Hamlet after his father's death. He argues that "Fatherhood... is unknown to man. It is a mystical estate... upon the void." He says "_Amor matris_... may be the only true thing in life." He thinks about his reasons. He talks about the "bodily shame" that sunders sons from fathers. He says Sabellius held the Father was His Own Son. He links Shakespeare to being the "father of all his race." Mulligan says "I am big with child. I have an unborn child in my brain. Pallas Athena! A play!" Stephen talks about Shakespeare's family, his mother's name in Arden, his son's death, and his brothers Gilbert, Edmund, and Richard. Eglinton asks "What's in a name?" Mr. Best asks for a good word for Richard. Mulligan sings a ditty. Stephen says two of Shakespeare's villains bear his brothers' names. Mr. Best hopes Edmund "catches it." Mr. Lyster quotes "But he that filches from me my good name..." Stephen says Shakespeare hid his name in the plays and revealed it in the sonnets. He describes a star at his birth. He thinks about his own name. Mr. Best mentions the "brother motive" in Irish myths and fairytales. The librarian asks about misconduct with one of the brothers. An attendant calls Mr. Lyster. Eglinton asks Stephen to speak of Richard and Edmund. Stephen says "A brother is as easily forgotten as an umbrella." He thinks of his whetstone. He talks about Shakespeare taking names from chronicles. He asks why Shakespeare chose the theme of the "false or the usurping or the adulterous brother." He says it sounds "uninterruptedly" from his plays. He links it to his daughter Susan's adultery. He laughs to free his mind. Eglinton says "The truth is midway. He is the ghost and the prince." Stephen agrees, saying he is "all in all." Mulligan clucks "Cuckoo! Cuckoo!" Eglinton praises Iago.
